member.name: T:Northwoods.Go.GoControl
member.summary: This graphical object provides a way to get the appearance and behavior from an existing Windows Forms Control.

remarks.para: A GoControl is a that manages a Windows Forms Control in a . The Control is automatically created when the becomes visible in the view, and is added to the view's Controls collection. By default the Control has the same size as the GoControl, and it moves around or changes size on the screen as the GoControl is scrolled around or resized.
is responsible for creating an instance of a Control. By default it just creates an instance of the Type, and gives it the 's in view coordinates.
This object keeps a hashtable mapping 's to Controls. finds any Control for this GoControl in a given . is responsible for making sure a Control exists; if returns null, it calls .

The most common use of GoControls is as in-place editors for a . for example, uses customized TextBox, ComboBox, and NumericUpDown Controls to allow the user to edit text. When used as an editor, a GoControl is added to a layer, not to a document. The use of the Control managed by the GoControl is effectively modal. The property is used when this GoControl is used as a editor. This GoControl becomes the value of ..

However, you can also use GoControls in s. When they are used as regular document objects, usually as part of a , a Control is created for each in which the GoControl can be seen. Please be aware of the restrictions that are imposed by Windows Controls. Because each Control, including , is responsible for completely painting itself and handling all events that it receives, it is not possible to interleave the painting done by and the painting done by Controls. All Controls that are parented by a must appear in front of the itself. Hence two s that each contain a and that overlap each other will produce the odd effect of not having one group properly appear in front of the other one, because the Controls managed by the nested s are in front of everything that the paints.

Besides having all Controls appear in front of all s, the use of has additional limitations and difficulties of use. You will need to handle the initialization of the Control, given information that is present on or accessible from the or its or . This is often done in the . setter, if you subclass the Control and implement the interface. Or you can do the initialization in a call from an override of .

Another limitation is that your application will need to deal with focus issues, scaling, and printing, and synchronization. Printing, in particular, is not naturally supported by Windows Forms controls. And at the current time, scaling Controls is not performed in a good manner. And if you have a GoControl visible in two s at the same time, you will need to deal with synchronization issues between the two Controls that are created for the single GoControl object.
For simplicity, does not call to make sure a Control exists in a . Instead it just paints a gray rectangle.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoObject.CopyObject(Northwoods.Go.GoCopyDictionary)
member.summary: Called during the first phase of the copy process to produce a copy of this object within the given copy dictionary.
member.param: The provides the context to be used for performing the copy.
member.returns: A newly allocated copy of this object, or null.

remarks.para: If you just need to make a copy of a , call ., or ., or if you have more than one object to copy.

You should override this method in your derived classes when it has some fields that have reference objects that need to be copied. Your override method should first call base.CopyObject(env) to get the newly copied object. The standard implementation of this method for is to do a shallow copy, by Object.MemberwiseClone(). The result should be the object you return, after performing any other deeper copying of referenced objects that you deem necessary, and after removing references that should not be shared (such as to cached data structures). If base.CopyObject(env) returns null, it's either already copied, or mapped to an existing object in this document, or shouldn't be copied at all.

The copied object does not belong to any layer or any group, nor does it have any observers; the ultimate caller (i.e. .) is responsible for adding it to the appropriate collection and is responsible for adding the appropriate observers.

You probably should not be calling this method for any reason but the initial base.CopyObject(env) call in an override of this method; normally only . is the caller. Within an override of this method, if you need to make a copy of another object, call . instead.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoObject.CopyObjectDelayed(Northwoods.Go.GoCopyDictionary,Northwoods.Go.GoObject)
member.summary: For objects that require a second pass to complete the copying, this method is called after the first pass of copying all of the objects in .

remarks.para: This method need only be overridden by objects that refer to other independent objects. The problem usually is that during the call to , some of the objects that this object refers to might not yet have been copied. So it's best to add this object to the collection in the call to , and then fix things up during the second pass in the call to this method.

For most objects, this method just adds the new observers that are copies of any old observers of this object. For s, however, it also makes sure both ports refer to the copied ports, and if the ports were not copied, it removes the link.
The base method should be called by any override that you define. You should not be calling this method from other code; normally only . is the caller.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoObject.Copy
member.summary: This convenience method just makes a copy of the object itself, using a generic .

remarks.para: The easiest way to add a copy of an object to a document is to call ..

If you want to copy many objects, it will be more efficient to allocate your own , call . on each object, and then finally call .. But if you are just going to be adding those copied objects into a , just call or the more general override of that method.

If you want to make many copies of one object, it will be more efficient to allocate your own , and then for each copy you want to make, call . on the object followed by a call to Clear() the dictionary. Clearing the copy dictionary will make sure each call does not share any references with any other copy.

another
a spot on the other object,

remarks.para: Use this method when you want a spot on this object to be exactly at a spot on another object, by moving this object.

Remember that this method just moves this object once. When other objects in a group resize or move, this object will not automatically follow. You will need to override to maintain whatever layout you want.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoObject.SetSizeKeepingLocation(System.Drawing.SizeF)
member.summary: Sets a new size for this object while maintaining the same location.
member.remarks: If the natural location of an object is not the top-left corner, changing the size of an object will also change its location. However, there are times when you wish to change the size without changing the location. This method is more efficient than remembering the Location, setting the Size, and then setting the Location again. By default this assumes the is really the spot of the object. If you override this method, you should also override the property.

member.summary: Notify this object's document or view that some part of this object's state is about to be changed.
member.remarks: Normally this method is only called for the benefit of the to record larger or more complex state before a change than can easily or efficiently be passed as the "old" or "previous" value in a call to . This method does nothing if is true. If you intend to turn on for a while, to reduce the overhead of repeated notifications, you probably should call this method first and make sure the and methods can remember all of the relevant state before the unrecorded changes occur.

remarks.para: Any override of this method and any methods that this calls should not further modify this object, either directly or indirectly.

Each of your property setters should call this method after actually changing the object's state. You should only call this method if the property's value actually changed. You should use the , , and/or parameters for passing the previous old property value. You should use the , , and/or parameters for passing the new property value. The old and new values can be used by . event handlers to update their state. A special case of such event handlers is the , which records the old and new values so that it can perform undo and redo operations.

If is true (it is normally false of course), this method does nothing. Your override of this method should check for before invoking any updating functionality. If this object is part of a layer, it calls
with a hint of .. If there are any observers watching changes to this object, this method calls on each of this object's observers.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoObject.OnLayerChanged(Northwoods.Go.GoLayer,Northwoods.Go.GoLayer,Northwoods.Go.GoObject)
member.summary: Called when this object's layer is changed.
member.param: This value is the old value of . The value will be null if the object did not belong to a layer but is being added to one.
This value is the new value of . The value will be null if the object is being removed from a layer.
This is the object that is being inserted or removed from a layer.
member.remarks: When this object is being removed from its layer, this method is called before the actual value of is set to null. Otherwise this method is called after the layer has been changed. Both and can be non-null when the object is being moved from one layer to another. Unlike . events, this method will be called even when this object is not part of a document, or when is true. However, this method is not called upon undo or redo of a change of layer. By default this method does nothing. Any implementation of this method should not cause a change in layers.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoObject.OnParentChanged(Northwoods.Go.GoGroup,Northwoods.Go.GoGroup)
member.summary: Called when this object's parent is changed.
member.param: This value is the old value of . The value will be null if the object did not belong to a group but is being added to one.
This value is the new value of . The value will be null if the object is being removed from a group.
member.remarks: When this object is being removed from its group, this method is called before the actual value of is set to null. Otherwise this method is called after the parent has been changed. When this object is being removed from its group, its will be set to null too. When this object is being added to a group, its property will be set to be the same as its new parent's layer. Unlike . events, this method will be called even when this object is not part of a document, or when is true. However, this method is not called upon undo or redo of a change of parent. By default this method does nothing. Any implementation of this method should not cause a change in parents or layers.

However, this method is not called when the bounds are changed due to a call to , nor upon an undo or a redo of a change in bounds.

member.remarks: calls this method on each of the observing objects that were registered with the observed object by a call to . If the observed's property is true, this method will not be called on its observers. Unlike . events, this method will be called even when the observed object is not part of a document. member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoObject.AddObserver(Northwoods.Go.GoObject)
member.summary: Register an object as an observer of changes to this object.

remarks.para: Adding an observer object means that that observer's method will be called whenever this object is changed. If the is already an observer for this object, this call does nothing. will not copy the list of observers for this object; the caller of is responsible for doing so, just as with adding the copied object to a layer and/or group to update the and properties.

Use of the observer mechanism is less efficient in both space and time than overriding the method of the observed object's class. However it can be useful when it is inconvenient to implement such an override.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoObject.RemoveObserver(Northwoods.Go.GoObject)
member.summary: Make sure an object is not an observer of changes to this object.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoObject.Paint(System.Drawing.Graphics,Northwoods.Go.GoView)
member.summary: Render this object to a Graphics object.
member.param: The Graphics object with which to draw.
The provides additional context for this painting operation.

remarks.para: This method may get called frequently and should not modify any object or view state.
The default implementation paints nothing. Each derived class should override this method.

The parameter is useful for customizing the drawing behavior based on the kind of view to which we are drawing. For example, the . property specifies the size of the drop shadow painted by objects whose property is true.
If you override this method, you may also need to override , and perhaps the other geometry methods, including , , , , and other methods such as and .

Furthermore, in the implementation of a property setter that causes the paint bounds to change, you will need to call before actually changing your object's state, so that views will get a chance to notice the paint bounds before it changes.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoObject.ExpandPaintBounds(System.Drawing.RectangleF,Northwoods.Go.GoView)
member.summary: Expand a bounding rectangle to better represent where this object is painted.
member.param: A RectangleF in document coordinates.
The view in which the object is being painted. This may be null, if the particular view is not known.
member.returns: A RectangleF in document coordinates that may be slightly larger than the argument, to account for where this object may be painted.

remarks.para: The property provides the abstract position and size of an object. However, the actual painted area is often somewhat larger, because of the thickness of a Pen or because of a shadow.
The default behavior of this method is just to return the value.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoObject.ContainsPoint(System.Drawing.PointF)
member.summary: Determine if a given point is inside and on this object.
member.param: A PointF in document coordinates.
member.returns: True if the argument is considered to be "in" this object.

remarks.para: This method tries to return true for points near a stroke or near or inside a possibly filled object such as an ellipse or a polygon. This method ignores any drop shadow, but normally includes the width of any Pen.

The default behavior of this method is to return true if the point is within this object's . If this object's or are zero, the given point has to be exactly on for this predicate to return true. However, some classes, such as that is inherently somewhat "one dimensional", may intentionally be more forgiving by supporting some margin nearby where a point can be considered to be "inside" the object.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoObject.ContainedByRectangle(System.Drawing.RectangleF)
member.summary: Determine if a given rectangle completely encloses this object.
member.param: a RectangleF in document coordinates.

member.remarks: The default behavior is to see if this object's are within the rectangle . A zero width and/or height for this object is acceptable; but if either r.Width or r.Height are zero or negative, this will return false.

remarks.para: By default this method does nothing but return false. This method is normally invoked by the tool and the tool, through the . method. Thus the event is not raised during a resize or a linking operation or the operation of other tools. This method is also not called directly on external drag-and-drop operations from other Controls. However, you may be able to get called in such situations if . is true, because then a drag enter causes a drop which adds objects to the document that are dragged around by the tool.
In GoDiagram Pocket, there are no mouse-over events, so this method is only called during dragging operations.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoObject.ChangeValue(Northwoods.Go.GoChangedEventArgs,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Perform an undo or redo, given a representing a change on this object.
member.param: The particular edit.
If true, restore the old value, otherwise restore the new value.

remarks.para: If you override this method, be sure to call the base method for all values that your override method does not handle.

Although properties should be designed so that setting one property does not modify other properties, this is sometimes not practical. Nevertheless it is important to avoid having side-effects when the value is changing due to an undo or redo. One way of doing this is to copy the needed code, but not the auxiliary side-effecting code, from the property setter to the override. Or you could define a method called from both the setter and the ChangeValue method, parameterized by whether the caller is the setter or not.

But a more convenient way to achieve this is to check the property that is set to true when the method is being called on this object. You should check this property before making "unrelated" side-effects.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoObject.Bounds
member.summary: Gets or sets the bounding rectangle for this object.
member.value: This RectangleF value describes the size and position of the object in document coordinates. The Width and Height must be non-negative.
member.remarks: When getting the bounds, if is true, we call to get the correct updated bounds. When setting the bounds, we call , . on the (if any), and with a subhint of ChangedBounds. You should override setting this property if you want to make sure this object never gets certain bounds, such as a size that's too small or large, or a position that is "out-of-bounds" for your application. However, if you only want to constrain how the user is allowed to move this object around with the mouse, you should override instead, or override if the constraint should be specific to a particular view or if something other than the should be set.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoObject.Location
member.summary: Gets or sets this object's natural position.
member.value: The PointF value is in document coordinates.
member.remarks: This property is normally the object's position. However, it is common for certain kinds of objects to assume that the assigned location actually refers to a different spot of the bounding rectangle. For example, for objects, the text's alignment property determines the Location. For groups, one of the child objects might be the natural thing to be positioned as the user would see it. For example, the icon of a node might provide the Location for the node as a whole. If you override this property, you should also override .

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoObject.Visible
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the user can see this object.
member.value: This defaults to true. You should normally call the method instead of getting this property. If you set this property to false, you probably also want to set the property to false.
member.remarks: A false value prevents the user from seeing this object by the normal painting mechanisms. Even when this property value is true, this object might not be seeable by the user because the object's layer is not visible. A user will not normally be able to select an invisible object or do other interactive operations with an invisible object. However, an invisible object can still be part of a layer and document or view, and can still take part in all programmatic operations such as manipulating its bounds.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoObject.Printable
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the view can print this object.
member.value: This defaults to true. You should normally call the method instead of getting this property. You may also want to set the property when setting this property.
member.remarks: A false value prevents the view from printing this object by the normal mechanisms. Even when this property value is true, this object might not be printable by the view because the object's layer is not printable.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoObject.Selectable
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the user can select this object.
member.value: This defaults to true. However, for some objects, such as , this defaults to false. You should normally call the method instead of getting this property.
member.remarks: A false value prevents the user from selecting this object by the normal mechanisms. Normally all the child objects of a group should have Selectable set to false. Even when this property value is true, this object might not be selectable by the user because its layer or document disallows it, or because the view disallows it. Your code can always select objects programmatically by calling aView.Selection.Select(obj) or aView.Selection.Add(obj). When this object's CanSelect is false, then if this object is part of a group, the normal selection mechanism will see if the group's CanSelect is true. If so, the group will be selected.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoObject.Movable
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the user can move this object.
member.value: This defaults to true. However, for some objects, such as , this defaults to false. You should normally call the method instead of getting this property.
member.remarks: A false value prevents the user from moving this object by the normal mechanisms. Even when this property value is true, this object might not be movable by the user because the layer or document disallows it, or because the view disallows it. Your code can always move objects programmatically by calling obj.Position = newPos. When this object is part of a group, the default drag behavior is to move just the object. However, the really determines what is actually moved. Note that some objects will not be able to move, or will not be able to move freely, because of constraints enforced in setting the or in the parent's . method.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoObject.Copyable
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the user can copy this object.
member.value: This defaults to true. You should normally call the method instead of getting this property.
member.remarks: A false value prevents the user from copying this object by the normal mechanisms. Even when this property value is true, this object might not be copyable by the user because the layer or document disallows it, or because the view disallows it. Your code can always copy objects programmatically by calling .. When this object is part of a group, the default drag behavior is to copy just the object. However, the really determines what is actually copied.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoObject.Resizable
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the user can resize this object.
member.value: This defaults to true. However, for some objects, such as and , this defaults to false. You should normally call the method instead of getting this property.
member.remarks: A false value prevents the user from resizing this object by the normal mechanisms. Even when this property value is true, this object might not be resizable by the user because the layer or document disallows it, or because the view disallows it. Your code can always resize objects programmatically by calling obj.Size = newSize or obj.Bounds = newRect. For an object to be resizable, its is really what should be resizable.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoObject.Reshapable
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the user can reshape this object.
member.value: This defaults to true. However, for some objects, such as this defaults to false, so that users cannot change the aspect ratio. You should normally call the method instead of getting this property.
member.remarks: A false value prevents the user from reshaping this object by the normal mechanisms. Even when this property value is true, this object might not be reshapable by the user because the layer or document disallows it, or because the view disallows it. Your code can always reshape objects programmatically by calling obj.Size = newSize or obj.Bounds = newRect or by making other changes to alter the shape of the object. For an object to be reshapable, its is really what should be reshapable--for a , this is often one of its child objects.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoObject.Deletable
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the user can delete this object.
member.value: This defaults to true. You should normally call the method instead of getting this property.
member.remarks: A false value prevents the user from deleting this object by the normal mechanisms (i.e., removing it from its layer). Even when this property value is true, this object might not be deletable by the user because the layer or document disallows it, or because the view disallows it. Your code can always delete objects programmatically by calling obj.Remove(). When this object is part of a group, the default edit delete behavior is to remove the object from the group.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoObject.Editable
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the user can edit this object.
member.value: This defaults to false. You should normally call the method instead of getting this property.
member.remarks: A false value prevents the user from editing this object by the normal mechanisms. Even when this property value is true, this object might not be editable by the user because the layer or document disallows it, or because the view disallows it. Your code can always edit objects programmatically by calling obj.DoBeginEdit(aView).

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoObject.AutoRescales
member.summary: Gets or sets whether this object automatically rescales its appearance when its size changes.
member.value: This defaults to true.
member.remarks: For most objects, particularly shapes, it is natural that when the size changes, the object adjusts its appearance appropriately smaller or larger, and accomodating any change in aspect ratio. Most classes ignore this property. However, there are certain circumstances where users do not expect this behavior, for example for instances that are part of a resizable group. Typically you will set this property false for text objects added to groups. . heeds this property.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoObject.ResizesRealtime
member.summary: Gets or sets whether this object continuously changes its size during a user resizing operation. [In Web Forms there is no continuous visual feedback of a resize.]
member.value: This defaults to false. However, for some objects, such as and , this defaults to true.
member.remarks: One advantage of a false value for this property is that only one undo record is generated for a user's resizing operation--namely the final one on mouse up.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoObject.Shadowed
member.summary: Gets or sets whether this object is painted with a drop shadow.
member.value: This defaults to false.
member.remarks: Normally the drop shadow is achieved by painting the shadow first, using or at the , and then doing the regular painting. The shadow affects the paint bounds, but not the object's bounds.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoObject.DragsNode
member.summary: Gets or sets whether this object, when selected and a child of a group, and when dragged, drags the parent node instead.
member.value: This defaults to false.
member.remarks: This is used by so that . or will move or copy the node instead of the child object.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoObject.SuspendsUpdates
member.summary: Gets or sets whether any document Changed event handlers are called upon a change to this object.
member.value: A value of true means that any document Changed event handlers and any UndoManager are not called. No observer objects are notified either. A value of false means that the notifications do take place. The default value is false.

remarks.para: Warning! You probably shouldn't be using this property.

When this property is true, no views of this document will be updated as this object is changed, and no undo/redo information is kept. When you set the property to false again, you will need to make sure all the views are correct (you may wish to call ). You should also be sure the user and the UndoManager will not be confused by the loss of any undo/redo information while this property was true. Setting this property does not raise any Changed events.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoObject.SkipsUndoManager
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the UndoManager is notified upon a change to this object.
member.value: A value of true means the 's method is not called. A value of false means that if there is an , it is notified so that it can record changes for undo and redo purposes. The default value is false.
member.remarks: You must be careful that any changes that occur while this property is true will not confuse the user when they perform Undo's and Redo's but the changes are not undone or redone. Setting this property does not raise any Changed events.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoObject.InvalidBounds
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the bounds are up to date.
member.remarks: This is typically set to true as some change is made to this object that requires recalculation of the bounds. This flag is automatically set to false and the method then actually does that calculation on demand. Setting this property does not raise any Changed events.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoObject.BeingRemoved
member.summary: Gets whether this object is in the process of being removed from its layer or group.
member.remarks: Sometimes when handling certain events you need to know whether the object is being removed from its group or layer, so that you can decide on alternative behaviors.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoObject.Initializing
member.summary: Gets or sets whether this object is in the process of being initialized.

remarks.para: This property is provided as a standard way to indicate that the object is not yet completely initialized, thereby allowing some methods to optimize their behavior.

Most of the simpler objects do not need to use this flag. More complicated objects such as s use this flag during construction and initialization to avoid repeated work in methods such as .. So if you temporarily set this property to true during the initialization of a complex or large node, be sure to call (null) after you set it back to false.
This property is temporarily set to true in some constructors or initialization methods, in . when calling , and during an undo or a redo when calling .

Property setters that have public side-effects (besides just changing the value of a field or other internal state) should not do those side-effects when this property is true. This can be important in avoiding unwanted side-effects during undo or redo.
Setting this property does not call or raise any events.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoObject.Observers
member.summary: Gets an enumerator over the list of observer objects of this object.
member.value: A that iterates over the s that are observers. Most objects do not have any observer objects. Their use does impose a performance penalty in both space and time.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoObject.SelectionObject
member.summary: Gets the object that gets selection handles when this object is selected.
member.remarks: Sometimes when an object gets selected, you want to make it look like another object is what really got selected. Normally this happens for groups, where you don't want to have selection handles on the whole group, but only on some particular child object. This property allows you to specify which object should get selection handles when this object gains selection. The default value is this object itself. The selection object's method will control if that object gets resize selection handles and if the user can actually resize that object. You should be careful to make sure the value of this property is not confusing to the user. Returning unrelated or varying objects may produce indeterminate behavior.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoObject.DraggingObject
member.summary: Gets the object that will be dragged instead of this selected object.
member.remarks: This property is used by . and .. If is true, this will return the node that this object is part of, which may be the or a grandparent. If this is a top-level object, the value will be this object itself. By default this will just return this object itself. You should be careful to make sure the value of this property is not confusing to the user. Returning unrelated or varying objects may produce indeterminate behavior.

member.name: T:Northwoods.Go.GoShape
member.summary: An abstract geometrical shape that uses an optional Pen to draw an outline and an optional Brush to fill the outline.

remarks.para: There are several very commonly used classes inheriting from GoShape: , , and . The following classes allow you to determine the shape: for straight and curved multi-segment lines, for closed figures using straight or curved sides, and most generally, . also supports many predefined shapes that you can specify with the enumeration. Other shape classes provide properties to easily specify particular characteristics, and they may provide specialized resizing behavior.

Although it is most common to use the predefined Brushes given by the System.Drawing.Brushes class, you can also set the property to any SolidBrush or HatchBrush, as well as many kinds of simple LinearGradientBrush or PathGradientBrush. Be sure to construct and completely initialize the Brush before assigning it to the property -- you may not modify a Brush after assigning it to a Brush property defined by GoDiagram.
It is also very common to assign the , , , , and properties.
For somewhat more complex effects, there are several Fill... methods defined on that set the property to commonly used LinearGradientBrushes or PathGradientBrushes.

As with brushes, you can set the property to any of the predefined System.Drawing.Pens, or you can construct your own Pen. Be sure to construct and completely initialize the Pen before assigning it to the property -- you may not modify a Pen after assigning it to a Pen property defined by GoDiagram.
It is also very common to assign the and properties.

member.param: the Color drawn inside the edges of the rectangular bounds
member.remarks: The is a PathGradientBrush using the rectangular bounds of this shape, clipped by the actual shape. Hence you may not see the very much, except where the shape is close to the bounds. This use of a PathGradientBrush does not suffer from the effects of GDI+ filling concave or multi-figure shapes. You can set the property to change where the center color is centered; the default is new PointF(0.5f, 0.5f), the middle of the shape. You can set the property to change the size of the center color area; the default is new SizeF(0, 0).

member.param: the Color drawn inside the edges of the rectangular bounds
the Color filling the center of the shape
member.remarks: The is a PathGradientBrush using the rectangular bounds of this shape, clipped by the actual shape. Hence you may not see the color very much, except where the shape is close to the bounds. This use of a PathGradientBrush does not suffer from the effects of GDI+ filling concave or multi-figure shapes. You can set the property to change where the center color is centered; the default is new PointF(0.5f, 0.5f), the middle of the shape. You can set the property to change the size of the center color area; the default is new SizeF(0, 0).

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoShape.Pen
member.summary: Gets or sets the pen used to draw the outline of this shape.
member.value: The Pen value may be null, in which case no outline is drawn. This value defaults to Pens.Black.
member.remarks: You must not modify the pen after you have assigned it. It is common to use the predefined brushes that are members of the Pens class. Currently serialization is limited to standard pens.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoShape.Brush
member.summary: Gets or sets the brush used to fill the outline of this shape.
member.value: The Brush value may be null, in which case no background is painted. This value defaults to null.

remarks.para: LinearGradientBrushes and TextureBrushes are drawn with their origin at the Position (top-left corner) of this shape.

You must not modify the brush after you have assigned it. It is common to use the predefined brushes that are members of the Brushes class. For the simplest linear gradient and path gradient effects, you can just set the , , , and properties. For common linear gradient and path gradient effects, more complicated than you get by setting those Brush... properties, we suggest that you use one of the Fill... methods. Finally, for the most sophisticated or complex kinds of gradient brushes, you may need to override this property to return the kind of value you need.

When a linear gradient brush or a path gradient brush is drawn very small, due to a combination of small size and small ., GoDiagram may substitute a solid brush or not draw anything at all, both for efficiency as well as to avoid GDI+ errors. When a path gradient brush is drawn very large, due to a combination of large size and large ., GoDiagram may substitute a solid brush, both for efficiency as well as to avoid GDI+ errors.
Currently serialization is limited to standard solid, hatch, and texture brushes and many kinds of simple linear gradient and path gradient brushes.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoShape.PenWidth
member.summary: Gets or sets the width of the pen.
member.value: The width of the , or 0 if there is no pen. The default value is zero.
member.remarks: If there is no , setting this property might have no effect. For GoDiagram Pocket, this property is only used for and its subclasses.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoShape.PenColor
member.summary: Gets or sets the color of the pen.
member.value: The Color of the , or Color.Empty if there is no pen. Setting the new value to Color.Empty will set the to null.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoShape.BrushColor
member.summary: Gets or sets the main or background color of the brush.
member.value: The Color of the , or Color.Empty if there is no brush. Setting the new value to a non-empty Color when is null will set the to a SolidBrush of that new color. Setting the new value to Color.Empty will set the to null if the old brush was a SolidBrush.
member.remarks: This refers to the color of a SolidBrush, the background color of a HatchBrush, the ending color of a LinearGradientBrush, or the center color of a PathGradientBrush.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoShape.BrushForeColor
member.summary: Gets or sets the foreground color of a brush. [Not in GoDiagram Pocket.]
member.value: Setting this value will have no effect for brushes that are not HatchBrush, LinearGradientBrush, or PathGradientBrush.
member.remarks: This refers to the foreground color of a HatchBrush, the starting color of a LinearGradientBrush, or the surrounding color of a PathGradientBrush.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoShape.BrushMidColor
member.summary: Gets or sets the middle color of a gradient brush. [Not in GoDiagram Pocket.]
member.value: For a LinearGradientBrush or PathGradientBrush, the value may be Color.Empty if no middle color is needed. This defaults to Color.Empty. Setting this value will have no effect for other kinds of brushes.
member.remarks: Due to a bug in GDI+ in .NET 1.1, this color is ignored. In .NET 2.0, this produces a brush with the correct appearance using all three colors when the is one that uses three colors.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoShape.BrushMidFraction
member.summary: Gets or sets the fractional distance between the end colors at which the middle color is drawn. [Not in GoDiagram Pocket]
member.remarks: This property is not meaningful unless the is a linear gradient or a path gradient that supports three colors. Changing the may also change the value of this property.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoShape.BrushStartPoint
member.summary: Gets or sets the start point for linear gradients, as normalized fractions of the size of the shape. [Not in GoDiagram Pocket]
member.value: A PointF whose X and Y values are normally between 0 and 1, and should be between -1 and 2. An X value of zero corresponds to the left side of the shape; an X value of 1 corresponds to the right side. A Y value of zero corresponds to the top side of the shape; a Y value of 1 corresponds to the bottom side. Negative values or values greater than 1 denote points that are outside of the shape.
member.remarks: This property is not meaningful unless the is a linear gradient. Changing the may also change the value of this property.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoShape.BrushPoint
member.summary: Gets or sets the end point for linear gradients or the focus point for path gradients, as normalized fractions of the size of the shape. [Not in GoDiagram Pocket]
member.value: A PointF whose X and Y values are normally between 0 and 1, and should be between -1 and 2. An X value of zero corresponds to the left side of the shape; an X value of 1 corresponds to the right side. A Y value of zero corresponds to the top side of the shape; a Y value of 1 corresponds to the bottom side. Negative values or values greater than 1 denote points that are outside of the shape.
member.remarks: This property is not meaningful unless the is a linear gradient or a path gradient. Changing the may also change the value of this property.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoShape.BrushFocusScales
member.summary: Gets or sets the size of the focus area for path gradients, as normalized fractions of the size of the shape. [Not in GoDiagram Pocket]
member.value: A SizeF whose Width and Height values must be between 0 and 1.
member.remarks: This property is not meaningful unless the is a path gradient. Changing the may also change the value of this property.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoShape.BrushStyle
member.summary: Gets or sets the kind of brush used by this shape. [Not in GoDiagram Pocket]
member.value: A . The default value depends on the shape type. However, for most shapes the default is because is null.

remarks.para: Changing this property to a new that is a gradient will also reset some of the brush properties to default values established by the corresponding Fill... methods. In particular, the value of , , , and/or may change. However, setting this property will not change the , or properties, although some or all of those properties might not be used by certain brush styles. You will normally want to set this property first, before setting other Brush... properties.

When a linear gradient brush or a path gradient brush is drawn very small, due to a combination of small size and small ., GoDiagram may substitute a solid brush or not draw anything at all, both for efficiency as well as to avoid GDI+ errors. When a path gradient brush is drawn very large, due to a combination of large size and large ., GoDiagram may substitute a solid brush, both for efficiency as well as to avoid GDI+ errors.
Caution: using gradient brush styles, particularly path gradients, can be computationally expensive to paint. This is especially true for large shapes.

member.name: T:Northwoods.Go.GoDrawing
member.summary: This shape holds both closed and open figures consisting of segments that are either straight lines or Bezier curves. [Not in GoDiagram Pocket]

remarks.para: This shape class, the most capable of the s, is a generalization of the and classes. You can also rotate or flip a drawing, extract figures as drawings, or insert other shapes as figures. The enumeration specifies a number of predefined drawings.

The term "figure" is used in two different but related ways here. Inside a GoDrawing there can be more than one figure, where each figure is a closed or open series of straight or curved segments. Although most enumerations specify s consisting of a single figure, some of the more complicated s specify s that contain multiple figures.

The most common usage is to just use the constructor, followed by setting the , , or other properties. Remember that an instance of a GoDrawing is a single , with a single and a single covering the whole shape.

If you call and also set to FillMode.Alternate, the inner area between the two curves will be open. No brush will be painted there, and at any point in there will return false, although will return true where the brush is painted.

You can rotate a drawing by setting the property. Or you can rotate about any point by calling , which will also set the . Please note that changing the angle may very well change the , including the . You can get the bounds of this drawing as if the angle were zero by using the property. Just setting the property will rotate the drawing about the -- the center of the .
You can also flip a drawing about either a horizontal axis or a vertical one.
When a drawing is and , and when is true, the user will be able to drag any of the points of the drawing.

For figures that are have their first point and their last point at the same PointF location, moving either shape might produce undesirable results unless the other point is moved too. Set the property to true to have (called by ) keep both end points of figures together.

Adjacent curved segments may meet at an angle. Sometimes you would like to make sure that curves remain smooth between two curved segments, even when the user reshapes the points. You can set , or call . But note that curved segments will still form angles with an adjacent straight line segments.

There are also methods for modifying individual points, for inserting segments into an existing figure, for opening or closing existing figures, for inserting whole shapes as figures into a drawing, and for extracting figures from a drawing into a new GoDrawing.
The basic points and segment style and figure information is stored in a , accessible via the property. This information is used to construct a GraphicsPath in the method.
The property returns the number of points in the whole drawing. The property returns the number of figures in the whole drawing.
Since it is hard for a user to pick a figure when they have to precisely target pixels where the line is drawn, the predicate allows for a certain amount of leeway. This is governed by the property.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoDrawing.IsClosedFigure(System.Int32)
member.summary: This predicate determines if the figure containing the given index is closed.
member.param: An index contained in the figure to be determined closed or not. If less than zero, it will be set to zero. If beyond the end of the array, it will be set to the last index.
member.returns: true if the figure containing the index is closed. false if the figure containing the index is open, or if there are no points.
member.remarks: A closed figure will be filled with a brush if one is set, and will have a line drawn from its end point to its start point, if they are not already at the same point. To close or open figures, use and .

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoDrawing.OpenFigure(System.Int32)
member.summary: Opens the figure containing the given index.
member.param: Any index in the figure
member.remarks: A closed figure will be filled with a brush if one is set, and will have a line drawn from its end point to its start point, if they are not already at the same point.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoDrawing.CloseFigure(System.Int32)
member.summary: Closes the figure containing the given index.
member.param: Any index in the figure

remarks.para: A closed figure will be filled with a brush if one is set, and will have a line drawn from its end point to its start point, if they are not already at the same point.
This method is different from because this results in the figure being filled with a brush, whereas causes the figure to be left unfilled when painted.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoDrawing.CloseFigure
member.summary: Close the current (last) figure.
member.remarks: This just calls passing it the last index. You may find it convenient to call this after constructing the last segment of a figure that you want to be filled with the brush.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoDrawing.OpenAllFigures
member.summary: Opens all figures in the shape.
member.remarks: This just calls with the end index of each figure.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoDrawing.CloseAllFigures
member.summary: Closes all figures in the shape.
member.remarks: This just calls with the end index of each figure. You may find it convenient to call this after constructing some figures a segment at a time, when you intend all of the figures to be filled with the brush.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoDrawing.HasClosedFigures
member.summary: Determines if the GoDrawing has closed figures
member.returns: true if at least one figure is closed, false otherwise
member.remarks: When this is true, will fill the closed figures of this shape with the .

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoDrawing.CompleteFigure(System.Int32)
member.summary: Completes a figure by adding a line segment from the last point to the start point of the figure, if needed.
member.param: an index in the figure
member.remarks: This method is different from because, if needed, it inserts a point that is the same as the first point of the segment without causing the figure to be filled with a brush. results in the figure being filled when painted.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoDrawing.CompleteFigure
member.summary: Complete the current (last) figure.
member.remarks: This just calls passing it the last index. You may find it convenient to call this after constructing the last segment of a figure that you want to complete by having it return straight to the first point of the segment.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoDrawing.CompleteAllFigures
member.summary: Completes all figures by adding a line segment from the last point to the start point of each figure, if needed.
member.remarks: This just calls with each figure index.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoDrawing.RemoveSegment(System.Int32)
member.summary: Remove the action at the given index.
member.param: a valid insertion index greater than zero
member.remarks: This will remove the action and point for the index . If the action is a (open or closed), this will remove the three points of this Bezier curve segment. This method does not simply remove a StartAt action, causing two figures to be combined--call to do that.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoDrawing.JoinFigure(System.Int32)
member.summary: Remove the action that begins the figure at point , causing the figure to become part of the previous figure.
member.param: the zero-based index of a point
member.remarks: This method does nothing if the figure is the first one in this shape. This method will iterate idx backward until it reaches a StartAt.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoDrawing.FiguresCount
member.summary: Returns the number of figures currently in this shape.
member.remarks: The number of figures is the same as the number of points in the shape.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoDrawing.SameEndPoints
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the first and last point of each figure are at the same point.
member.value: The default value is false.
member.remarks: For polycurves setting this property to true will cause the loss of the straight line connecting the last and first points. (But note that if the whole figure consists of just the four points of a Bezier curve, having the first and last points the same may result in a degenerate Bezier curve: a straight line.) Even when this property is true, the first and last point of each figure might not be at the same position if they are modified by calling .

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoDrawing.SmoothCurves
member.summary: Gets or sets whether all points joining any two adjacent Bezier segments form a smooth curve.
member.value: The default value is false. A value of true means that there are no corners between Bezier curves, although there still may be corners between straight line segments and between a Bezier segment and a straight segment.
member.remarks: Even when this property is true, the rendered path might not be smooth if the points are modified by calling .

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoDrawing.FillMode
member.summary: Gets or sets how and operate on closed figures.
member.value: The default value is FillMode.Winding.
member.remarks: Consider also calling before combining two shapes.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoDrawing.PickMargin
member.summary: Gets or sets the approximate width of the region on either side of an open shape's line that is still considered "inside" the shape when picking.
member.value: The default value is 3.

member.remarks: This value is considered by whether or not this shape is Resizable.

member.name: T:Northwoods.Go.GoHandle
member.summary: This class is used to show that a document object is selected by decorating the object with handles that are added to a view layer.
member.remarks: Instances of this class are assumed only to be used in layers, not as part of a . Thus they do not participate in undo/redo nor can they be selected.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoHandle.GetCursorName(Northwoods.Go.GoView)
member.summary: Return the appropriate resize cursor name for the handle ID's corresponding to the standard spots, but return null if the object cannot be resized.
member.returns: null if is false or if .CanResize and .CanReshape are both false; otherwise the value of if it is non-null; finally a cursor name depending on the , such as "se-resize" for .BottomRight or "hand" for , or "move" for most other handles, or finally null if the is .NoHandle.

member.summary: Draw this handle according to the handle's style.

member.summary: Produce a GraphicsPath representing this shape.
member.returns: a newly allocated GraphicsPath

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoHandle.ContainsPoint(System.Drawing.PointF)
member.summary: Determines if the given point is inside this handle's bounds.
member.param: A PointF value in document coordinates.
member.returns: True if the point is considered "on" the handle.
member.remarks: This assumes that handles are actually hollow when the is .NoHandle-- that is, a point well inside the handle's bounds is not considered "on" the handle if the handle's ID is .NoHandle. This is useful for letting bounding handles be ignored by mouse over behavior. Note that this method does not take the into account--it assumes the handle is rectangular.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoHandle.Style

member.value: The default style is

member.name: T:Northwoods.Go.GoGrid
member.summary: An object that draws a set of dots, crosses, or lines in a rectangular pattern, and that can affect how objects are moved, copied, and resized.
member.remarks: A GoGrid is not a table containing cells of objects. This class just draws lines in a regular manner within the bounds of this object according to a frequency specified by the . The appearance of the lines is governed by the and and . You can also specify a regular pattern of colors by specifying . Furthermore a grid can have a semi-infinite or infinite extent by setting . This class also implements the interface, which affects how various view methods and tools move, copy, and resize objects.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoGrid.CanSnapPoint(System.Drawing.PointF,Northwoods.Go.GoObject,Northwoods.Go.GoView)
member.summary: This predicate is called by . to decide whether this grid should take part.
member.param: a PointF in document coordinates
the object being moved or resized (may be null/nothing)
the in which the snapping is occuring; may be null/nothing
member.returns: true if . should call .
member.remarks: This considers the property (or the property if resizing). If is not null and the current is either or , this method checks whether the point is within the grid; if the view is null or another type of tool is currently in use, it checks whether the given point is within the grid. This predicate is false if returns false, but this predicate is not affected by the value of or any other properties that control this grid's appearance. To avoid confusion in some common cases, this predicate is also false if the is this grid itself, or if this grid the , or if this grid is part of the view's .

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoGrid.MajorLineFrequency
member.summary: Gets or sets how often grid lines should be drawn as major lines.
member.value: The Width indicates how often vertical lines should be drawn using and if not Pocket, MajorLineWidth and MajorLineDashStyle. The Height indicates the same thing for horizontal lines. A value of zero means never; one means always; two means every other one, etc. The initial value is 0x0, so major lines are never drawn.
member.remarks: Typically this will have the same values as the bounds of the array, or integral multiples of each other, if both are in use.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoGrid.CellColors
member.summary: Gets or sets an array of colors to be used in drawing grid cell backgrounds.
member.value: A two-dimensional array of Colors. You must not modify the array that is returned by this property. To change any cell colors you must set this property, either by allocating a new array or by cloning the current value, modifying the copy, and then setting this property. When set the grid will keep a copy of the array. Initially the array has zero-by-zero bounds, so there is no cell color.
member.remarks: This array is used by . Typically this array's bounds will have the same values as , or integral multiples of each other, if both are in use.

member.name: T:Northwoods.Go.GoGroup
member.summary: Groups are a way of treating a collection of instances as a single object.

member.name: T:Northwoods.Go.IGoCollection
member.summary: This interface specifies a collection of .
member.remarks: Classes implementing IGoCollection need not maintain an indexing of its objects--in other words, they need not implement IList. But at any one time each collection implementing this interface should maintain an ordering of all of its items, so that the enumerator will iterate "forwards" over the list, and so that the enumerable's enumerator will iterate "backwards" over that list. This ordering should be guaranteed to remain stable as long as the collection is unchanged. However, a call to or may cause the ordering of the items to be altered.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoGroup.CopyChildren(Northwoods.Go.GoGroup,Northwoods.Go.GoCopyDictionary)
member.summary: Copy this group's children.
member.remarks: This method is responsible for copying and adding this group's child objects to the . By default, this simply calls newgroup.Add(env.Copy(obj)) for each child obj. However, your group subclass may want to keep track of some or all of the children for its own purposes. To that end you can override this method to do the copying manually, thereby correctly maintaining your subclass's internal pointers to children. You probably should not be calling 's , but 's or indexed lookup instead.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoGroup.Add(Northwoods.Go.GoObject)
member.summary: Add an object to this group.
member.remarks: The must not already belong to another group or to a layer. If the object already belongs to this group, nothing happens. Otherwise, afterwards, the 's will be this group and its . will be the same as this group's layer. When you add an object to a group, you will normally make that child object not .. If the child is supposed to be selectable, you need to consider whether users can move or copy the child on its own, or whether this parent group should be moved or copied instead. For the latter case you should set the . property to true for each such child, so that . will return the child's parent node. If instead you want to allow selected children to be able to move on their own, you should make sure does not control the positioning of these child objects.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoGroup.InsertBefore(Northwoods.Go.GoObject,Northwoods.Go.GoObject)
member.summary: Add or move an object to be before an existing child.
member.remarks: The children of a group are ordered with respect to each other. This method makes the be in the group at the position before the , so that the will be painted immediately before the . If the already belonged to this group, only its position in the list is changed. The must not already be part of a different group or be a top-level object in some layer. The existing must be either null or a member of this group (but not be the same as ). If the is null, the is added at the beginning of the list, behind all other objects in this group.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoGroup.InsertAfter(Northwoods.Go.GoObject,Northwoods.Go.GoObject)
member.summary: Add or move an object to be after an existing child.
member.remarks: The children of a group are ordered with respect to each other. This method makes the be in the group at the position after the , so that the will be painted immediately after the . If the already belonged to this group, only its position in the list is changed. The must not already be part of a different group or be a top-level object in some layer. The existing must be either null or a member of this group (but not be the same as ). If the is null, the is added at the end of the list, in front of all other objects in this group.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoGroup.Remove(Northwoods.Go.GoObject)
member.summary: Remove an object from this group.
member.remarks: The must not belong to a different group. This method does nothing if the has already been removed from this group. Afterwards, the 's will be null and its . will also be null, because it will be removed from the layer if the group and it belonged to a layer.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoGroup.AddCollection(Northwoods.Go.IGoCollection,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Move some objects into this group, as immediate children of this group, even if they are part of other groups in this same layer.
member.param: a collection of s
whether to make sure all connected links belong to the proper subgraph or layer; if true, this will call .

remarks.para: This method tries to preserve the links connecting any ports of the objects being moved into this group. Of course, none of the objects to be added to this group may be the group itself nor a parent of this group.

Just as with the method, you may find that you will want to set the . property to false for each of the objects being added to this group. The need for this depends on the behavior you want in your application.

This method is normally called on instances of . If calling this method on a group that is not a subgraph, you will probably want to specify the value of to be false, since otherwise any links that you think you are adding to the group will be taken right out again to be added to the enclosing subgraph or to be a top-level object.

member.summary: Provides default behavior, assuming all children are already correctly placed and sized, and only need to be moved and/or scaled to fit the new bounds of this GoGroup.
member.remarks: The default behavior, if the size did not change, is just to call . If the size did change, we call to rescale and proportionally reposition all of the children, and then we call to give the node a chance to do special positioning of any of the children.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoGroup.LayoutChildren(Northwoods.Go.GoObject)
member.summary: Reposition this group's children to achieve a particular appearance.

remarks.para: By default this method does nothing. However, this method is frequently overridden.

Implementations of this method probably should not refer, directly or indirectly, to this group's . property. Instead, you should just position and size the children based on the bounds of the children (not this group's bounds), and let this group's bounds be determined by the union of the bounds of the children.

For groups that may have many children, overrides will often check the . flag. If true, this method usually does nothing; later when all the changes have been performed is that flag set to false and this method is called explicitly with a null argument.

member.summary: Gets a Hashtable of name/child mappings.

remarks.para: The hash table should contain mappings in both directions-- from String name to child GoObject, and the reverse, from object to name. In order to save space, overrides of and will handle common child names rather than using a hash table data structure. For example, provides the name "Label" for its part that is the value of its property.
To modify this hash table, call , , or . If you modify this hash table directly, such changes are not recorded by the undo manager.

member.name: T:Northwoods.Go.GoGroupEnumerator
member.summary: Iterate over the immediate child objects of this group, either forwards or backwards.
member.remarks:
Although this structure is public, it is rarely used explicitly. Instead you should use the foreach (or For Each) construct to iterate through the children of a group. In C#:
foreach (GoObject obj in aGroup) { . . . }
In VB.NET:
Dim obj As GoObject For Each obj in aGroup . . . Next
Also, since implements the IList interface, you can refer to the items of the group by a zero-based index.
Remember that you must not modify the group collection, by adding, removing, or re-ordering the child objects, while you are iterating over the children. This structure type does not support comparison for equality.

member.value: This defaults to GoHexagonResizeBehavior.FreeForm.
member.remarks: Note, however, that the actual resize behavior is constrained by the and properties.

members.member:
Gets or sets whether to maintain the lengthwise distances at one half the crosswise bounds size member. (eg. Orientation == Orientation.Horizontal; DistanceTop = Bounds.Height/2; DistanceBottom = Bounds.Height/2)
Gets or sets whether to maintain symmetry in respect to the lengthwise axis.
This defaults to true.

Gets or sets whether to maintain the crosswise distances equal to each other and the crosswise distances equal to each other. (eg. Orientation == Orientation.Horizontal; DistanceTop = Bounds.Height/2; DistanceBottom = Bounds.Height/2)
Gets or sets whether to maintain symmetry in respect to the crosswise axis.
This defaults to true.

member.name: T:Northwoods.Go.GoImage
member.summary: An object that displays a image such as a bitmap or JPEG file.

remarks.para: This is responsible for painting an Image. The , , , and properties are used by in order to procure the actual Image that is painted. If you change any of these properties, will be called again to find a new image.

When you set any of those properties, if is true (which is the default value), will be called immediately to determine whether the new Image has a new Size, in order to resize this GoImage object to the Image's natural size. However, when is false, will only get called when the property is needed by a call to . Hence if you have a large diagram with many different Images to be shown, it is advantageous to have GoDiagram only load images on demand due to painting. You can achieve this effect by setting to false and by setting the explicitly to the size that you want, before setting the or properties.
If is non-negative, this tries to display the corresponding Image in the . If is null, this uses the value of instead.

If is non-null and non-empty, this tries to display the correspondingly named Image in the . If is null, this uses the value of instead. If no Image is found in any ResourceManager for the given name, the is treated as a URI to be gotten via a WebClient if is true, or as a file pathname for an image file stored on disk if is false.
Finally, even if is null, this object will still be able to paint an image if is non-negative and if it can find an image in the 's ImageList.

Images loaded by from a ResourceManager or ImageList or from a file on disk or from the web are cached in a static/shared hash table. Future calls to with the same source and name/index will just share the same Image. You can clear the whole cache by calling , or you can clear individual cache entries by calling one of the ClearCachedImage overloaded methods. Call to cause an individual to call again the next time it needs to show an Image.

A newly constructed will get its initial value for from and for from . These properties are not serialized and deserialized, although and are. To make sure copy-and-paste works successfully, you should either set or , or fix up the value of or in a event handler or override.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoImage.UnloadImage
member.summary: Clear the reference that this object maintains, so that the next use of that property (for example, in ) will result in a call to .
member.remarks: This is different from setting the property to null, because that change would actually modify the state of this , a change that could be undone and redone.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoImage.LoadImage
member.summary: This method is responsible for getting an Image.
member.returns: An Image.

remarks.para: The normal behavior is to try to use the value, if non-negative, to find an Image in the . If there is no ImageList, we try using the .
If the index value is negative, we use the to get an Image object from the . If there is no ResourceManager, we try using the , and if that fails, we try treating the name as a filename.
The resulting Image is normally cached by this object as the property. If it loads the image from a file, the file may remain locked until the image is garbage collected.

If an exception occurs trying to load an image, the message is sent to trace listeners. Also, if is true, the catch handler will rethrow the exception. If the is out-of-bounds for the , or if the is not found in the , this will fail silently--no exception is thrown.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoImage.ClearCachedImages
member.summary: Clear out GoDiagram's internal cache of loaded Images.
member.remarks: Calling this method does not modify any existing , so no Images will be "lost". However, future calls to will have to re-load all named images from ResourceManagers or from disk, or (in Windows Forms) re-load all indexed images from ImageLists.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoImage.ClearCachedImage(System.Resources.ResourceManager,System.String,System.Globalization.CultureInfo)
member.summary: Remove any cached image identified by a ResourceManager and a name in a particular culture.
member.param: a ResourceManager
a CultureInfo
member.remarks: Calling this method does not modify any existing , so no Images will be "lost". However, future calls to will have to re-load any image with the given name from the given ResourceManager.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoImage.ClearCachedImage(System.String)
member.summary: Remove any cached image identified by a pathname on disk.
member.param: a filename
member.remarks: Calling this method does not modify any existing , so no Images will be "lost". However, future calls to will have to re-load from disk any image with the given file pathname.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoImage.ClearCachedImage(System.Windows.Forms.ImageList,System.Int32)
member.summary: Remove any cached image identified by an ImageList and an index.
member.param: an ImageList
member.remarks: Calling this method does not modify any existing , so no Images will be "lost". However, future calls to will have to re-load from the given ImageList an image at the given index.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoImage.Image
member.summary: The Image displayed by this GoImage.
member.value: If set to null, the next get will call .

remarks.para: will draw the Image that is the value of this property. When an Image is not yet available, it calls and remembers that returned Image as this property's value. The cached Image value is not serialized.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoImage.ResourceManager
member.summary: Gets or sets the ResourceManager used to look up and load images by Name.
member.value: When this value is changed, any cached Image is forgotten so that it can be reloaded from the new ResourceManager by .
member.remarks: The ResourceManager is not serialized; after deserialization, you will need to reset this property.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoImage.ImageList
member.summary: Gets or sets the ImageList used to hold images from which one is chosen by index.
member.value: When this value is changed, any cached Image is forgotten so that it can be redrawn from the new ImageList by .
member.remarks: The ImageList is not serialized; after deserialization, you will need to reset this property. If you modify the ImageList's collection of Images to replace an Image that a GoImage has already loaded, you will need to reset this property by setting it to null.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoImage.Index
member.summary: Gets or sets the index of the image in an ImageList.
member.value: This zero-based value is an index into an ImageList. The default value is -1, indicating no image in any ImageList.
member.remarks: If this value is non-negative, the image will come from the value, assuming it is within the bounds of the ImageList's collection of Images. If this value is non-negative but is null, this object will try to draw using the view's ImageList, , if any.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoImage.Name
member.summary: Gets or sets the resource name or filename for loading images.
member.value: A null value causes to avoid looking for an image in a ResourceManager or as a file.
member.remarks: When this value is changed, any cached Image is forgotten so that it can be reloaded from the ResourceManager, if any, or from the file system.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoImage.NameIsUri
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the property is a URI instead of a disk file path. [Not in GoDiagram Pocket]
member.value: The default is false.
member.remarks: You might want to set this property to true before setting the property, so that doesn't waste time trying to look up the as if it were a pathname for a disk file.

member.summary: The natural location depends on this object's Alignment.

member.summary: Gets or sets the alignment for the image, which governs its .
member.value: The default value is .

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoImage.AutoResizes
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the bounds are recalculated when the image changes.
member.value: The default value is true.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoImage.ThrowsExceptions
member.summary: Gets or sets whether to (re-)throw an exception that may occur while trying to load an Image.
member.value: The default value is false.

remarks.para: You may want to set this to true to help debug why an image does not appear. will first send the exception's message to trace listeners. Then if this property is true, the catch handler will rethrow the exception.

This flag may help you debug any image loading exceptions, but there can be other reasons for an image not to appear. Perhaps the most common problem is that information, such as the , is not present for to be able to find the image data. This will occur, for example, if you set the property alone and then serialize/deserialize this GoImage, because Image data and ResourceManagers are not serialized.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoPie.StartAngle
member.summary: Gets or sets the initial angle of the section of the ellipse to be drawn.
member.value: This value is in degrees, measured clockwise from zero along the positive X axis. The value should range from zero to just below 360. Values outside this range are adjusted to equivalent angles that fall in this range.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoPie.SweepAngle
member.summary: Gets or sets the angle of the width of the section of the ellipse to be drawn.
member.value: This value is in degrees, measured clockwise from the . Absolute values equal to or greater than 360 degrees are adjusted to the equivalent angles less than 360 degrees. The default value is 60.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoPie.ResizableStartAngle
member.summary: Gets or sets whether to add the resizing handle controlling the start angle.
member.value: This defaults to true.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoPie.ResizableEndAngle
member.summary: Gets or sets whether to add the resizing handle controlling the end angle.
member.value: This defaults to true.

member.name: T:Northwoods.Go.GoPolygonStyle
member.summary: Specifies the kind of curve drawn between the points of the polygon.

member.name: F:Northwoods.Go.GoPolygonStyle.Line
member.summary: A straight line is drawn between each two consecutive points in the , and between the last and first points to close the curve.

member.name: F:Northwoods.Go.GoPolygonStyle.Bezier
member.summary: A Bezier curve is drawn using four points: a start point, two control points, and an end point. Additional sets of three points specify additional Bezier curves, where the new start point is the old end point.
member.remarks: If the first point and the last point are not at exactly the same position, there is a straight line drawn between the two to complete the closed shape.

member.summary: Changing the bounds of a polygon may change all of its points.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoPolygon.ComputeBounds
member.summary: The bounding rectangle of a polygon is computed as the smallest rectangle that includes all of its points.
member.remarks: If there are only zero or one points, the size will be zero. The computed bounds for Bezier-sided polygons are not necessarily the closest fitting.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoPolygon.ContainsPoint(System.Drawing.PointF)
member.summary: A point is in a polygon only if it is inside its fill area, even if it has no Brush.
member.remarks: This currently does not take pen width into account.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoPolygon.GetSegmentNearPoint(System.Drawing.PointF,System.Single)
member.summary: Return the index of the first point of a segment of this polygon that is close to a given point.
member.param: A PointF in document coordinates
the approximate distance from each line segment that is allowed, in addition to the width of the Pen; assumed to be non-negative
member.returns: The zero-based index of the first point of a segment, or -1 if no segment is near .
member.remarks: This ignores the filled area and only considers the boundary defined by the polygon points that is drawn by the Pen (or if there is no Pen, what would be drawn if there were a Pen). For Bezier style polygons, this returns the index of the first of each set of points, e.g. 0, 3, 7, ....

member.remarks: This currently does not always take into account any Pen width.
