member.name: T:Northwoods.Go.GoRoundedRectangle
member.summary: An object in the shape of a rectangle or square, whose corners are quarter ellipses at the corners of the bounding rectangle.
member.remarks: Although by default all four corners are rounded by the value of , you can control which ones are rounded by setting . For example, if you just want the top corners to be rounded-off, but you want to keep the bottom corners squared-off: r.RoundedCornerSpots = GoObject.TopLeft | GoObject.TopRight;

member.name: T:Northwoods.Go.GoBrushStyle
member.summary: An enumeration of all of the kinds of simple brushes that supports.

remarks.para: This is used by the property, in coordination with the , , and properties.
Note that diagonal linear gradients always go from one corner spot to the opposite corner spot, following the aspect ratio of the shape, not at 45 or 135 degree angles.

When a linear gradient brush or a path gradient brush is drawn very small, due to a combination of small size and small ., GoDiagram may substitute a solid brush or not draw anything at all, both for efficiency as well as to avoid GDI+ errors. When a path gradient brush is drawn very large, due to a combination of large size and large ., GoDiagram may substitute a solid brush, both for efficiency as well as to avoid GDI+ errors.
This enum, along with the , , and properties, are not used in GoDiagram Pocket, but exist for source-code compatibility. Only the and enum values are defined in GoDiagram Pocket.

member.name: F:Northwoods.Go.GoBrushStyle.None
member.summary: Nothing is painted. If you do not want to fill the region inside a shape, it is most efficient to set . to null or Nothing.

member.name: F:Northwoods.Go.GoBrushStyle.Solid
member.summary: The default brush style, a uniform color using a SolidBrush; the color that is drawn may be partially or totally transparent. You can specify the color by setting .. Alternatively, you can set the . to an instance of a System.Drawing.SolidBrush.

member.name: F:Northwoods.Go.GoBrushStyle.SimpleGradientVertical
member.summary: A simple two color linear gradient, with the . at the top and with the . at the bottom.

member.name: F:Northwoods.Go.GoBrushStyle.SimpleGradientHorizontal
member.summary: A simple two color linear gradient, with the . at the left and with the . at the right.

member.name: F:Northwoods.Go.GoBrushStyle.SimpleGradientForwardDiagonal
member.summary: A simple two color linear gradient, with the . at the top-left and with the . at the bottom-right.

member.name: F:Northwoods.Go.GoBrushStyle.SimpleGradientBackwardDiagonal
member.summary: A simple two color linear gradient, with the . at the top-right and with the . at the bottom-left.

member.name: F:Northwoods.Go.GoBrushStyle.MiddleGradientVertical
member.summary: A three color linear gradient, with the . at the top, with the . at the middle, and with the . at the bottom. If the is Color.Empty, it uses the at the middle. Due to a bug in GDI+ in .NET 1.1, the middle gradient color is ignored. All three colors are shown in .NET 2.0.

member.name: F:Northwoods.Go.GoBrushStyle.MiddleGradientHorizontal
member.summary: A three color linear gradient, with the . at the left, with the . at the middle, and with the . at the right. If the is Color.Empty, it uses the at the middle. Due to a bug in GDI+ in .NET 1.1, the middle gradient color is ignored. All three colors are shown in .NET 2.0.

member.name: F:Northwoods.Go.GoBrushStyle.MiddleGradientForwardDiagonal
member.summary: A three color linear gradient, with the . at the top-left, with the . at the middle, and with the . at the bottom-right. If the is Color.Empty, it uses the at the middle. Due to a bug in GDI+ in .NET 1.1, the middle gradient color is ignored. All three colors are shown in .NET 2.0.

member.name: F:Northwoods.Go.GoBrushStyle.MiddleGradientBackwardDiagonal
member.summary: A three color linear gradient, with the . at the top-right, with the . at the middle, and with the . at the bottom-left. If the is Color.Empty, it uses the at the middle. Due to a bug in GDI+ in .NET 1.1, the middle gradient color is ignored. All three colors are shown in .NET 2.0.

member.name: F:Northwoods.Go.GoBrushStyle.SingleEdgeGradientTop
member.summary: A three color linear gradient, with the . along the top, with the . in the middle, and with the . at the bottom. If the is Color.Empty, it uses the at the middle. Due to a bug in GDI+ in .NET 1.1, the middle gradient color is ignored. All three colors are shown in .NET 2.0.

member.name: F:Northwoods.Go.GoBrushStyle.SingleEdgeGradientLeft
member.summary: A three color linear gradient, with the . along the left, with the . in the middle, and with the . at the right. If the is Color.Empty, it uses the at the middle. Due to a bug in GDI+ in .NET 1.1, the middle gradient color is ignored. All three colors are shown in .NET 2.0.

member.name: F:Northwoods.Go.GoBrushStyle.SingleEdgeGradientRight
member.summary: A three color linear gradient, with the . along the right, with the . in the middle, and with the . at the left. If the is Color.Empty, it uses the at the middle. Due to a bug in GDI+ in .NET 1.1, the middle gradient color is ignored. All three colors are shown in .NET 2.0.

member.name: F:Northwoods.Go.GoBrushStyle.SingleEdgeGradientBottom
member.summary: A three color linear gradient, with the . along the bottom, with the . in the middle, and with the . at the top. If the is Color.Empty, it uses the at the middle. Due to a bug in GDI+ in .NET 1.1, the middle gradient color is ignored. All three colors are shown in .NET 2.0.

member.name: F:Northwoods.Go.GoBrushStyle.DoubleEdgeGradientVertical
member.summary: A three color linear gradient, with the . along the top and the bottom, with the . at the center, and with the . in between. If the is Color.Empty, it uses the at the middle. Due to a bug in GDI+ in .NET 1.1, the middle gradient color is ignored. All three colors are shown in .NET 2.0.

member.name: F:Northwoods.Go.GoBrushStyle.DoubleEdgeGradientHorizontal
member.summary: A three color linear gradient, with the . along the left and the right sides, with the . at the center, and with the . in between. If the is Color.Empty, it uses the at the middle. Due to a bug in GDI+ in .NET 1.1, the middle gradient color is ignored. All three colors are shown in .NET 2.0.

member.name: F:Northwoods.Go.GoBrushStyle.DoubleEdgeGradientForwardDiagonal
member.summary: A three color linear gradient, with the . at the top-left and bottom-right corners, with the . at the center, and with the . in between. If the is Color.Empty, it uses the at the middle. Due to a bug in GDI+ in .NET 1.1, the middle gradient color is ignored. All three colors are shown in .NET 2.0.

member.name: F:Northwoods.Go.GoBrushStyle.DoubleEdgeGradientBackwardDiagonal
member.summary: A three color linear gradient, with the . at the top-right and bottom-left corners, with the . at the center, and with the . in between. If the is Color.Empty, it uses the at the middle. Due to a bug in GDI+ in .NET 1.1, the middle gradient color is ignored. All three colors are shown in .NET 2.0.

member.name: F:Northwoods.Go.GoBrushStyle.ShapeSimpleGradient
member.summary: A two color path gradient, with the . along the edges of the shape, gradually turning into the . at the very middle. This gradient works best with convex shapes. This should not be used for very large shapes; in some cases the system will automatically use a simple solid brush instead.

member.name: F:Northwoods.Go.GoBrushStyle.ShapeFringeGradient
member.summary: A three color path gradient, with the . along the edges of the shape, and with the . and . in most of the middle. If the is Color.Empty, it uses the at the middle. This gradient works best with convex shapes. This should not be used for very large shapes; in some cases the system will automatically use a simple solid brush instead.

member.name: F:Northwoods.Go.GoBrushStyle.ShapeHighlightGradient
member.summary: A two color path gradient, with the . in most of the shape, but with the . near the top-left corner. This gradient works best with convex shapes. This should not be used for very large shapes; in some cases the system will automatically use a simple solid brush instead.

member.name: F:Northwoods.Go.GoBrushStyle.RectangleGradient
member.summary: A three color path gradient, with the . along the edges of a rectangle whose Bounds are the same as the shape, gradually turning into the . at the very middle. If the is Color.Empty, it uses the at the middle. This has the same effect as when the shape is a rectangle, but when the shape is not a rectangle, the brush continues to paint a rectangular gradient. This should not be used for very large shapes; in some cases the system will automatically use a simple solid brush instead.

member.name: F:Northwoods.Go.GoBrushStyle.EllipseGradient
member.summary: A three color path gradient, with the . along the edges of an ellipse whose Bounds are the same as the shape, gradually turning into the . at the very middle. If the is Color.Empty, it uses the at the middle. This has the same effect as when the shape is an ellipse, but when the shape is not an ellipse, the brush continues to paint an elliptical gradient. This should not be used for very large shapes; in some cases the system will automatically use a simple solid brush instead.

member.name: F:Northwoods.Go.GoBrushStyle.Texture
member.summary: A pattern of tiled images, using a TextureBrush. You can set the . to an instance of a System.Drawing.TextureBrush.

member.name: F:Northwoods.Go.GoBrushStyle.CustomLinearGradient
member.summary: A LinearGradientBrush not constructed by setting the various .Brush... properties or calling the various .Fill... methods. Such a brush is not likely to be serializable, and will need to be reconstructed dynamically.

member.name: F:Northwoods.Go.GoBrushStyle.CustomPathGradient
member.summary: A PathGradientBrush not constructed by setting the various .Brush... properties or calling the various .Fill... methods. Such a brush is not likely to be serializable, and will need to be reconstructed dynamically.

member.name: T:Northwoods.Go.GoStrokeStyle
member.summary: Specifies the kind of curve drawn between the points of the stroke.

member.name: F:Northwoods.Go.GoStrokeStyle.Line
member.summary: A straight line is drawn between each two consecutive points in the .

member.name: F:Northwoods.Go.GoStrokeStyle.RoundedLine
member.summary: Rounded line is like but with curves at each point where the lines intersect. Currently this is only implemented for adjacent segments that intersect at right angles.

member.name: F:Northwoods.Go.GoStrokeStyle.Bezier
member.summary: A Bezier curve is drawn using four points: a start point, two control points, and an end point. Additional sets of three points specify additional Bezier curves, where the new start point is the old end point.

member.name: F:Northwoods.Go.GoStrokeStyle.RoundedLineWithJumpOvers
member.summary: Like but the path also "jumps" or "hops" over intersections with other strokes that have this style.

member.name: T:Northwoods.Go.GoStrokeArrowheadStyle
member.summary: Specifies the general shape of an arrowhead.

member.name: F:Northwoods.Go.GoStrokeArrowheadStyle.Polygon
member.summary: The arrow head is drawn as a polygon.
member.remarks: The number of sides for the polygon is determined by .

member.name: F:Northwoods.Go.GoStrokeArrowheadStyle.Circle
member.summary: The arrowhead is drawn as a circle.
member.remarks: The circle's diameter is specified by the stroke's arrow shaft length, or .

member.name: F:Northwoods.Go.GoStrokeArrowheadStyle.Cross
member.summary: The arrowhead is a line crossing perpendicularly to the shaft.
member.remarks: The arrow length determines the distance of the line from the end point, or . The arrow width determines the length of the line, or . The arrow shaft length should normally be zero, or . If the maximum of the arrow length and the arrow shaft length exceed the end line segment length, the whole arrowhead is scaled down to fit.

member.name: F:Northwoods.Go.GoStrokeArrowheadStyle.Slash
member.summary: The arrowhead is a line crossing at an angle across the shaft.
member.remarks: The arrow length determines the distance of the line from the end point, or . The arrow width determines the length of the line, or . The arrow shaft length should normally be zero, or . If the maximum of the arrow length and the arrow shaft length exceed the end line segment length, the whole arrowhead is scaled down to fit.

member.name: F:Northwoods.Go.GoStrokeArrowheadStyle.BackSlash
member.summary: The arrowhead is a line crossing at an angle across the shaft.
member.remarks: The arrow length determines the distance of the line from the end point, or . The arrow width determines the length of the line, or . The arrow shaft length should normally be zero, or . If the maximum of the arrow length and the arrow shaft length exceed the end line segment length, the whole arrowhead is scaled down to fit.

member.summary: Display the appropriate selected appearance, normally resize selection handles at each point of the stroke.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoStroke.OnBoundsChanged(System.Drawing.RectangleF)
member.summary: Changing the bounds of a stroke may change all of the stroke's points.
member.param: the earlier bounds, a RectangleF in document coordinates
member.remarks: All of the points are modified to reflect the translation and scaling of the new bounding rectangle from the old one.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoStroke.ComputeBounds
member.summary: The bounding rectangle of a stroke is computed as the smallest rectangle that includes all of the stroke's points.
member.remarks: If there are only zero or one points, the size will be zero. The computed bounds for Bezier strokes are not necessarily the closest fitting, and do not include any arrowheads.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoStroke.ExpandPaintBounds(System.Drawing.RectangleF,Northwoods.Go.GoView)
member.summary: Consider Pen width, miter limit, drop shadow and highlight in computing the paint bounds.

member.summary: A point is in a stroke only if it is near one of its segments.

member.param: A PointF in document coordinates
member.returns: The zero-based index of the first point of a segment, or -1 if no segment is near .

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoStroke.GetArrowheadPointsCount(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets the number of points to be used in the polygon representing an arrowhead.
member.param: true for the "To" end, false for the "From" end
member.returns: By default this returns 4. The value must be at least 3.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoStroke.CalculateArrowhead(System.Drawing.PointF,System.Drawing.PointF,System.Boolean,System.Drawing.PointF[])
member.summary: Modify an array of points to hold the four points of a polygon outlining an arrowhead
member.param: The arrowhead anchor position, giving the spot the arrow is coming from
The arrowhead end point
true if for the "To" end, false if for the "From" end
An array of PointF of at least length four to hold the results

remarks.para:
By default the four points are as follows:
[0] the inner point on the shaft, arrow shaft length from the end point
[1] and [3] the barbs of the arrowhead, arrow width apart
[2] the tip of the arrowhead, at the end point
If necessary, the length of the arrowhead is actually scaled down to fit in the distance between the and the .

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoStroke.DrawArrowhead(System.Drawing.Graphics,Northwoods.Go.GoView,System.Drawing.Pen,System.Drawing.Brush,System.Boolean,System.Single,System.Single,System.Drawing.PointF[])
member.summary: This method is called by to actually draw an arrowhead.
member.param: true if for the "To" end, false if for the "From" end
the offset is normally used for drawing a shadow
the offset is normally used for drawing a shadow
The result of a call to
member.remarks: By default this will be called with a thin, solid pen derived from and this stroke's . When the arrowhead style is , the polygon's [0] and [2] points are used to position the circle. When the arrowhead style is one of the "crossed" styles, the polygon's [1] and [3] points are used as the points for the crossing line.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoStroke.Paint(System.Drawing.Graphics,Northwoods.Go.GoView)
member.summary: A stroke is drawn as a sequence of straight line segments or Bezier curves, with optional arrows at the ends.
member.remarks: The kind of stroke is specified by , and the parameters of the stroke's segments are specified by the stroke's points. Each segment uses the points it needs until there are not enough more for an additional segment. If is true, the stroke is drawn with the at a offset given by . If is non-null, that pen is used to drawn the stroke first. Finally is used to draw the stroke. If or are true, the corresponding arrowheads are drawn according to the values of the ArrowAnchorPoint, ArrowLength, ArrowShaftLength, ArrowWidth, and ArrowFilled.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoStroke.MakePath
member.summary: Returns a GraphicsPath representation of what will be drawn.
member.remarks: The path will not include the arrowheads.

Gets the number of points in this stroke.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoStroke.FirstPickIndex
member.summary: Gets the index of the first point that should get a selection handle.
member.remarks: This normally returns 0.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoStroke.LastPickIndex
member.summary: Gets the index of the last point that should get a selection handle.
member.remarks: This normally returns PointsCount-1.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoStroke.PickMargin
member.summary: Gets the approximate width of the region across the stroke, in addition to the pen width, that is still considered "inside" the stroke when picking.
member.value: This value defaults to 3, and should be non-negative.
member.remarks: This allows users to pick thin links more easily. You can override this property in order to have it return a different value.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoStroke.ToArrow
member.summary: Gets or sets whether an arrow is drawn at the end of this stroke.
member.value: The default value is false.
member.remarks: The arrow will be located near the last point of the stroke. By default this will be an arrowhead drawn pointing out with a thin pen and filled with the stroke's , which defaults to Brushes.Black.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoStroke.ToArrowStyle
member.summary: Gets or sets the general shape of an arrowhead at the end of this stroke.
member.value: The default value is .

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoStroke.ToArrowEndPoint
member.summary: Gets the point at the tip of the arrowhead at the end of this stroke.
member.value: The default value is the last point of this stroke.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoStroke.ToArrowAnchorPoint
member.summary: Gets a point which specifies the direction the arrow is coming from.
member.value: The default value is the next-to-last point of this stroke.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoStroke.ToArrowLength
member.summary: Gets or sets the length of the arrowhead at the end of this stroke.
member.value: The default value is 10. A negative value will produce an arrowhead that points inward instead of outward.
member.remarks: The length is the distance measured along the shaft of the two "barbs" of the arrowhead from the end point.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoStroke.ToArrowShaftLength
member.summary: Gets or sets the length of the shaft of the arrowhead at the end of this stroke.
member.value: The default value is 8. A negative value, along with a negative value for the arrow length, will produce an arrowhead that points inward instead of outward.
member.remarks: The shaft length is the length of the arrowhead on the shaft. You can make the arrowhead diamond shaped by having the shaft length twice the arrow length. A shaft length of zero will result in an arrowhead with no interior to fill with the .

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoStroke.ToArrowWidth
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum width of the arrowhead at the end of this stroke.
member.value: The value is measured in document coordinates and must be non-negative. The default value is 8.
member.remarks: Smaller values make the arrowhead sharper.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoStroke.ToArrowFilled
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the arrowhead at the end of this stroke is filled with the brush.
member.value: The default value is true.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoStroke.FromArrow
member.summary: Gets or sets whether an arrow is drawn at the start of this stroke.
member.value: The default value is false.
member.remarks: The arrow will be located near the first point of the stroke. By default this will be an arrowhead drawn pointing out with a thin pen and filled with the stroke's , which defaults to Brushes.Black.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoStroke.FromArrowStyle
member.summary: Gets or sets the general shape of an arrowhead at the start of this stroke.
member.value: The default value is .

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoStroke.FromArrowEndPoint
member.summary: Gets the point at the tip of the arrowhead at the start of this stroke.
member.value: The default value is the last point of this stroke.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoStroke.FromArrowAnchorPoint
member.summary: Gets a point which specifies the direction the arrow is coming from.
member.value: The default value is the second point of this stroke.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoStroke.FromArrowLength
member.summary: Gets or sets the length of the arrowhead at the start of this stroke.
member.value: The default value is 10. A negative value will produce an arrowhead that points inward instead of outward.
member.remarks: The length is the distance measured along the shaft of the two "barbs" of the arrowhead from the end point.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoStroke.FromArrowShaftLength
member.summary: Gets or sets the length of the shaft of the arrowhead at the start of this stroke.
member.value: The default value is 8. A negative value, along with a negative value for the arrow length, will produce an arrowhead that points inward instead of outward.
member.remarks: The shaft length is the length of the arrowhead on the shaft. You can make the arrowhead diamond shaped by having the shaft length twice the arrow length. A shaft length of zero will result in an arrowhead with no interior to fill with the .

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoStroke.FromArrowWidth
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum width of the arrowhead at the start of this stroke.
member.value: The value is measured in document coordinates and must be non-negative. The default value is 8.
member.remarks: Smaller values make the arrowhead sharper.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoStroke.FromArrowFilled
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the arrowhead at the start of this stroke is filled with the brush.
member.value: The default value is true.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoStroke.HighlightPenWidth
member.summary: Gets or sets the width of the line drawn as the highlight for the stroke.
member.value: The value must be non-negative. The default value is 0, meaning a one-pixel wide line at any scale. Values other than zero cause slower drawing, particularly in GoDiagram Pocket.
member.remarks: If there is no , setting this property might have no effect.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoStroke.HighlightPenColor
member.summary: Gets or sets the color of the .
member.value: The Color of the , or Color.Empty if there is no pen. Setting the new value to Color.Empty will set the to null.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoStroke.Curviness
member.summary: Gets how rounded the corners are for adjacent line segments when the stroke style is .
member.value: This describes the maximum radius of rounded corners, in document coordinates. This also is used to determine the offset distance for the control points of a style link when connecting two ports whose spots are both . This defaults to 10.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoStroke.Highlight
member.summary: Gets or sets whether this stroke displays a highlight along its path.
member.value: This defaults to false.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoStroke.HighlightPen
member.summary: Gets or sets the pen used to draw a highlight for this stroke.
member.value: This property defaults to null.
member.remarks: You must not modify the pen after you have assigned it. Setting to true will not result in a visible markup until you specify a Pen for this property.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoStroke.HighlightWhenSelected
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the highlight is shown when this stroke becomes selected.
member.value: This defaults to false.
member.remarks: When this property is true and this stroke is selected, we set the property to true. Assuming there is a value for , the stroke will appear highlit. When the stroke is no longer selected, the property is set to false. Under these circumstances the change to the property is not recorded by the undo manager (if any). This feature should only be used when there is only one view on the document, or if it is OK for all views on the document to display the highlight when the stroke is selected in just one of the views.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoText.#ctor
member.summary: The constructor produces an object that is not resizable by the user and does not automatically rescale the font size when the size is changed. However, it does automatically change the size to fit the text when the text is changed.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoText.CopyObject(Northwoods.Go.GoCopyDictionary)
member.summary: This makes a copy of this text object.
member.returns: The copied object.
member.remarks: The list of , if any, is not copied--it is shared with the original text object.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoText.PaintGreek(System.Drawing.Graphics,Northwoods.Go.GoView)
member.summary: This method is responsible for alternative painting when the scale is small.
member.returns: True if this method handled the Paint request; false if it did not and the regular painting should take place.
member.remarks: This paints nothing if the 's is less than the . It just draws a line if the scale is less than the .

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoText.Paint(System.Drawing.Graphics,Northwoods.Go.GoView)
member.summary: Draw a text string according to the attributes specified by this object's properties.
member.remarks: If is false, we fill the bounds with the , and we paint a rectangular drop shadow if . If is true, we draw the text (offset) using the shadow pen if is true. Then we draw the text using the . The value of and either or GoView.RightToLeft determine the actual alignment of the text.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoText.SetSizeKeepingLocation(System.Drawing.SizeF)
member.summary: This method can be called to change the size of this object without changing its location.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoText.ExpandPaintBounds(System.Drawing.RectangleF,Northwoods.Go.GoView)
member.summary: Consider any shadow when calculating the paint bounds.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoText.AddSelectionHandles(Northwoods.Go.GoSelection,Northwoods.Go.GoObject)
member.summary: Implement a custom selection indicator if BackgroundOpaqueWhenSelected is true.
member.remarks: When is true, selecting this object will cause the background to be shown; unselecting will make the background transparent again. This produces the effect of highlighting the text when selected, if the text normally has a transparent background and the is a suitable highlight color. Changes to the property are not recorded by the .

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoText.RemoveSelectionHandles(Northwoods.Go.GoSelection)
member.summary: Implement a custom selection indicator if BackgroundOpaqueWhenSelected is true.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoText.OnBoundsChanged(System.Drawing.RectangleF)
member.summary: Handle any change in size.
member.remarks: If is true, we rescale the font size so that the text fits in this object's bounds.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoText.OnLayerChanged(Northwoods.Go.GoLayer,Northwoods.Go.GoLayer,Northwoods.Go.GoObject)
member.summary: Handle any change in layers.
member.remarks: If the layer changes, make sure we are no longer editing the text.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoText.OnSingleClick(Northwoods.Go.GoInputEventArgs,Northwoods.Go.GoView)
member.summary: Start editing this text object on a single click if this object is editable.
member.returns: True if it started editing; false if it could not.
member.remarks: To be able to call , both and the 's property must both be true.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoText.DoBeginEdit(Northwoods.Go.GoView)
member.summary: Bring up a TextBox or other Control to allow the user to edit the text string in-place.

remarks.para: This is responsible for calling . ( is responsible for finishing the transaction.) This basically sets both and . to the result from calling . However, this method does nothing if an edit is already in progress, when is not null.

However, many Controls require more sophisticated behavior, which is best implemented by inheriting from that particular Control class, implementing , and handling the desired events. Normally that is done by overriding instead of overriding this method.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoText.CreateEditor(Northwoods.Go.GoView)
member.summary: This creates a that will create a TextBox, a ComboBox, or a NumericUpDown when the is painted in a .

remarks.para: This is responsible for creating a with the appropriate and bounds. This method is called by . If you want to set some properties on the Control created by the for a , it is probably easiest to override the method.

Your subclass of Control, MyCustomControl, which should implement the interface, should be responsible for initializing itself correctly for this GoText object. That initialization is normally done when is set. It will of course want to examine this object being edited; you can get that with the following expression:
this.GoControl.EditedObject as GoText

Your Control should terminate by calling:
this.GoControl.DoEndEdit(this.GoView)
in its event handlers that cause it to finish.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoText.DoEndEdit(Northwoods.Go.GoView)
member.summary: Stop editing this text object.

remarks.para: This sets to null and removes the from the view by setting . to null. This is also responsible for calling and . However, this method does nothing if no edit is in progress, when is already null.
If you override this method, it might be easiest to first do whatever cleanup you need before calling the base method.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoText.DoEdit(Northwoods.Go.GoView,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Called when a user tries to commit a text edit.
member.returns: true to call to stop editing; false to continue editing. The default value is true.

remarks.para: This is normally called from the control that is setting a new string for this text object as a result of the user having finished editing the text. By default it just sets this object's property to the result of a call to : Text = ComputeEdit(oldtext, newtext). You can override this method to prevent the text value from being set, or you can override to constrain the new text value. If you intend to bring up a message box or other focus-taking activity, call . first, to make sure no tool is started if the user had clicked elsewhere in the view.

Call to programmatically have the user start editing this text object; call to stop any editing that the user might be doing. However, you should not be calling either of those methods from an override of this method.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoText.ComputeEdit(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Calculate a new string value for this object as a result of an edit.
member.returns: Normally, this just returns .
member.remarks: This is normally called from , and can be used for normalizing or canonicalizing the new string value, even when not interactively editing (i.e. no is not available). One typical usage is to make sure the new value is a unique string within some context such as the document.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoText.ChangeValue(Northwoods.Go.GoChangedEventArgs,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Performs changes for undo and redo.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoText.Text
member.summary: Gets or sets the string that this text object displays.
member.value: This defaults to the empty string. Setting this property to a null/nothing value will result in using an empty string instead. If is true, setting this property will resize this object to fit the text; otherwise if is true, setting this property will change the font size so that the text fits the bounds.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoText.FamilyName
member.summary: Gets or sets the font family face name.
member.value: Initially this is the value of . Setting this value to null will result in the use of that default. If is true, setting this property will resize this object to fit the text; otherwise if is true, setting this property will change the font size so that the text fits the bounds.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoText.FontSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the font size.
member.value: This value is in units of text points. Initially this is the value of .
member.remarks: Setting this property when is true will cause this object's bounds to be updated to fit the text.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoText.Alignment
member.summary: Gets or sets how the text is aligned.
member.value: This defaults to ; you can use any of the predefined spot values.
member.remarks: This property governs how each line of text is positioned in the bounding rectangle. In addition this property specifies the for this object. The value of this property is not changed by the value of or Control.RightToLeft for any . However, the GoView.RightToLeft or property does affect where the text is drawn for that view. When GoView.RightToLeft property value is RightToLeft.Yes, or when is false and is true, then text whose is on the left (such as ) will actually be drawn right-aligned.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoText.TextColor
member.summary: Gets or sets the color of the text.
member.value: This defaults to Color.Black.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoText.BackgroundColor
member.summary: Gets or sets the background color for this text object, shown when is false.
member.value: This defaults to Color.White.
member.remarks: The background is not painted if is true.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoText.TransparentBackground
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the background color is painted.
member.value: This defaults to true--the background color is not painted, and only the characters are displayed.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoText.Bold
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the font style is bold.
member.value: This defaults to false.
member.remarks: If is true, setting this property will resize this object to fit the text; otherwise if is true, setting this property will change the font size so that the text fits the bounds.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoText.Italic
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the font style is italic.
member.value: This defaults to false.
member.remarks: If is true, setting this property will resize this object to fit the text; otherwise if is true, setting this property will change the font size so that the text fits the bounds.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoText.Underline
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the font style includes underline.
member.value: This defaults to false.
member.remarks: If is true, setting this property will resize this object to fit the text; otherwise if is true, setting this property will change the font size so that the text fits the bounds.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoText.StrikeThrough
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the font style includes strike-through.
member.value: This defaults to false.
member.remarks: If is true, setting this property will resize this object to fit the text; otherwise if is true, setting this property will change the font size so that the text fits the bounds.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoText.Bordered
member.summary: Gets or sets whether a simple border is drawn around the text.
member.value: the default value is false, indicating no border
member.remarks: The line drawn around the text is drawn using a solid Pen whose color is . If you need more complex borders, wider margins around the text, or other visual effects, you will need to override or compose different objects using a . Note that the of this object are not changed by setting this property. However, this property does affect the result of , just as the property also affects that method.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoText.GdiCharSet
member.summary: Gets or sets the GDI character set used for the text.
member.value: The default value is 1, the default character set.
member.remarks: If is true, setting this property will resize this object to fit the text; otherwise if is true, setting this property will change the font size so that the text fits the bounds.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoText.RightToLeft
member.summary: Gets or sets whether this text should be drawn from right to left, when the property is false.
member.value: The default value is false.
member.remarks: This property is ignored when is true.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoText.RightToLeftFromView
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the view's RightToLeft property governs how the string is drawn, or whether this text object's property takes precedence.
member.value: This defaults to true, which means the 's RightToLeft property will affect the appearance of the text. However, for GoDiagram Web and GoDiagram Pocket, since the ASP.NET Web Forms and .NET Compact Framework Controls don't support a RightToLeft property, this property is ignored and the value is assumed to be false.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoText.Multiline
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the text is displayed in multiple lines, according to any NewLine character sequences in the text string.
member.value: This defaults to false.
member.remarks: If this is false, any text after the first NewLine is ignored. If is true, setting this property will resize this object to fit the text; otherwise if is true, setting this property will change the font size so that the text fits the bounds.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoText.BackgroundOpaqueWhenSelected
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the text background is displayed when selected.
member.value: This defaults to false.
member.remarks: When this property is true and this text object is selected, we set the property to false. Assuming there is a suitable , the text will appear highlit. When the text object is no longer selected, the property is set to true. Under these circumstances the change to the property is not recorded by the undo manager (if any). Note that setting this property to true will prevent the normal selection handles from appearing, so that when is true there won't be any resize handles for the user to manipulate. This feature should only be used when there is only one view on the document, or if it is OK for all views on the document to display the text highlight when the text object is selected in just one of the views.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoText.Clipping
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the text drawing is clipped by this object's bounds.
member.value: This defaults to false.
member.remarks:
This is not supported in GoDiagram Pocket.
You should turn on clipping when is false, unless you can be sure the text will always fit within the bounds of this object. You may also wish to set the StringTrimming property, for additional control over how the text is truncated or elided.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoText.AutoResizes
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the bounds are recalculated when the text changes.
member.value: This defaults to true.
member.remarks: If both this property and are false, and you change either the string or the , you must be careful not to make either the text too big or the bounds too small. It is then wise to turn on the property.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoText.StringTrimming
member.summary: Gets or sets how characters are removed when is false. [Not in GoDiagram Pocket]
member.value: The default value is StringTrimming.None.
member.remarks: If you set this property to a value other than StringTrimming.None, you should set to false and to true. Clipping may be needed even if this value is different than StringTrimming.None. If is true, this applies to each virtual line, as separated by NewLine character sequences.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoText.Wrapping
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the text is wrapped when the text reaches the wrapping width.
member.value: This defaults to false.
member.remarks: If is true, setting this property will resize this object to fit the text; otherwise if is true, setting this property will change the font size so that the text fits the bounds.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoText.WrappingWidth
member.summary: Gets or sets the width at which text is wrapped.
member.value: This distance is in document coordinates. This defaults to 150. The new value must be positive and at least as wide as any single character.
member.remarks: Text is wrapped to the next line when the property is true and the text gets wider than this value. If is true, a NewLine character sequence (Carriage Return/ LineFeed) forces a line break. If is true, setting this property will resize this object to fit the text; otherwise if is true, setting this property will change the font size so that the text fits the bounds.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoText.EditorStyle
member.summary: The kind of editor Control used when the user edits the text string in-place.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoText.Minimum
member.summary: When the is , this specifies the minimum value.
member.value: This defaults to zero.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoText.Maximum
member.summary: When the is , this specifies the maximum value.
member.value: This defaults to 100.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoText.DropDownList
member.summary: When the is , this controls whether the user must choose from the list of , or whether the user can type in an arbitrary string.
member.value: This defaults to false.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoText.Choices
member.summary: When the is , this holds the list of choices that are presented in the drop down list.
member.value: This defaults to an empty list. The value may be shared by more than one GoText object.
member.remarks: Modifying the items in the list is not controlled. Any such changes are not recorded by the undo manager. Only replacing the list is recorded for undo/redo, and even then, it is only the reference to an ArrayList that is remembered and restored.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoText.Font

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoText.LineCount

member.value: the number of physical lines of text that are drawn, including line breaks caused by newlines and by wrapping, if any

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoText.Location

member.remarks: The value of this property is not changed by the value of or Control.RightToLeft for any .

member.remarks: This property only affects the behavior of , and is only effective when is also true.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoText.DefaultFontSize

member.name: T:Northwoods.Go.GoBalloon
member.summary: A GoBalloon is a kind of that is associated with another object.

remarks.para: The object is implemented as a . It is shaped to "point" at the object. The actual PointF point is calculated by . When there is no , it uses to determine a point near the .

When is true, an additional selection handle is placed at the "point", to allow users to interactively choose another object. You can override to determine which objects may be chosen as new anchors for this balloon comment. By default it allows any selectable document object, but you could just have it return objects of a certain type, depending on the state of your application.

member.name: T:Northwoods.Go.GoComment
member.summary: A simple group displaying text with a shadowed background.

remarks.para:
The is normally a , but could be any kind of . Hence you can easily customize that rectangle's appearance by setting properties on the , such as:
comment.Shape.BrushColor = Color.LightSkyBlue comment.Shape.PenColor = Color.DeepSkyBlue
Or you could replace the with a different .
sizes the to fit around the , using the and the to leave space between the and the bounds of the shape. If you use other shapes, you may need to increase these margins.

Because this class has a , it implements the interface, even though this class is not a "node". It also implements , to make it easier to keep track of the different comments that might be in your diagram, if you have set to true in your .

member.summary: Gets or sets the unique ID of this part in its document, a non-negative integer.
member.value: This value is invalid unless this is part of a whose property is true. This property should not be set when this object is part of a document. The initial value should be -1, which instructs the document, when the object is added to the document, to find a unique ID and assign it to this object.
member.remarks: When is false, you may set and get this PartIDproperty. However, you will need to manage any uniqueness of values, and (if desired) you will need to manage a hashtable to make finding parts fast. will not set any PartID unless is true or unless you call .

member.name: T:Northwoods.Go.GoBasicNode
member.summary: A simple node with a , a single and an optional text .

remarks.para: By default the is a . You can easily replace that shape with a or other . If you call the constructor, the shape will be a initialized to have that .

The position and size of the relative to the is determined by the property. When the spot is , the shape is automatically resized to fit the label's text (if is true) plus the , and the port is hidden and resized to be the same size as the shape itself.
When is false, the is sized to fit inside the bounds of the , minus the margins. The label (a ) is automatically wrapped and clipped.

Since the default value for is GoObject.MiddleTop, you will need to explicitly set the to GoObject.Middle to get this appearance and behavior. Otherwise the default appearance is to have the be positioned outside of the , with the small and positioned in the middle of the .
Unless you set the or the property, there will be no . However, the constructor does create a , in addition to having the label be in the middle of the shape.
When the is an instance of , you can get and set the property, if you want to dynamically change the appearance of the node. More generally, you can modify that or replace the with another kind of .
Setting the , , and properties actually set the same properties on the node's , which is the .

member.name: T:Northwoods.Go.GoBoxPort
member.summary: A rectangular port that is smart about where each of its links is connected, centered or distributed on each side, meeting the edge of the port orthogonally.

remarks.para: Although this class is normally used as part of a to act as a port that surrounds another object, you can use GoBoxPort as part of other nodes, such as .
Normally links can connect at any of the four sides. If you want to permit links at only particular sides, you can set the and/or properties.

member.name: T:Northwoods.Go.GoPort
member.summary: This class provides the standard implementation of as a .

remarks.para: A port is an object to which one or more links may be connected. Ports are normally part of a , although they may also be part of a . A node will only need more than one port when you want to make sure there is a logical distinction between the links or when you want to position the links connections at one physical location. Both reasons apply, for example, when wanting to represent an electronic logic gate or arithmetic or database operator: you don't want to confuse where each input is getting its value from.

Since GoPort inherits from , it is easy to customize the appearance of a port by setting the and/or the properties. The property controls the shape of the port within the port's bounds. The default style is . When the style is , nothing is painted for the port, but it continues to behave normally.

A less common approach to providing a port appearance is to specify a style that is . For this case you will need to set the property to refer to a that is not part of any group or layer. This may be shared by many ports. When there is a port object, the appearance comes totally from that object -- the port's brush and pen are ignored. You'll need to make sure that that object can be resized to the same size as the port. If you use a as a port object, be sure to either set true, or resize the port to be able to show all of the text.

The links that are attached to a port are conceptually divided into two categories: ones that come into the port, and ones that go out from the port. But often you won't care about the direction, so some of the properties and methods apply to all links. The property allows you to enumerate the links that are coming into a port -- e.g. the links whose is this port. The property allows you to enumerate the links that are going out of a port -- e.g. the links whose is this port. The property allows you to enumerate all links connected at this port. The , , and properties give you the size of each of those three collections. The User Guide provides examples for how to traverse a graph.

GoPort provides a fair bit of control for where and how each link will appear to connect to it. The most common case is that links connect at a particular spot on the port, usually the middle of some side. You can get this behavior by setting the and properties. For example, setting to GoObject.MiddleRight will cause all destination links to come out of the port at the middle of the right side. Similarly, you can set the to be the same spot, or perhaps a different spot, say GoObject.MiddleLeft if you want links to go into the port from the left side. When the spot(s) are set in this manner, each link will have a short end segment at the port.

More generally, you can override the and/or methods to control the exact end point for the link, for source links and for destination links, respectively. Similarly, you can override the and/or methods to control what direction each link's end segment should travel. controls how long each end segment should be, assuming there is one at all. If the port spot is GoObject.NoSpot, there usually won't be an end segment in the link at that port.

Many applications do not want to permit the user to draw links between any two ports. There are semantic rules that may make linking particular pairs of ports invalid. Or there may be some ports for which only one direction link may be connected. You can easily specify the most common restrictions by setting one or more of the following properties: , , , , and .
For the most general or dynamic cases, you can override the method, either here on , or on the and tools associated with your . Also consider setting the property.

You may wish to override this method if you want to customize dynamically the direction of the link at the link point.

member.summary: Gets or sets whether this port can be a valid value for some link's .

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoPort.IsValidSelfNode
member.summary: Gets or sets whether a valid link can be made between two ports belonging to the same node.
member.value: This defaults to false.
member.remarks: uses this property in the following manner: If this property is true, and the other port's IsValidSelfNode property is also true, then the proposed link may be valid. Otherwise, if is true, it will not be a valid link.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoPort.IsValidDuplicateLinks
member.summary: Gets or sets whether a valid link can be made between two ports already connected by a link in the same direction.
member.value: This defaults to false.
member.remarks: uses this property in the following manner: If this property is true, and the other port's IsValidDuplicateLinks property is also true, then the proposed link may be valid. Otherwise, if is true, it will not be a valid link.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoPort.IsValidSingleLink
member.summary: Gets or sets whether and return false when there is already a link connected at this port.
member.value: This defaults to false -- an unlimited number of links can be valid.
member.remarks: If you want to provide different or more general limitations on how many links can be connected to this port, you may need to override and . For the most general way to control whether links might be valid, you may need to override . But first consider all of the other properties governing link validity.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoPort.Style
member.summary: Gets or sets the appearance style for this port.
member.value: This defaults to .
member.remarks: If the value changes, the setter will also call to notify all connected links about the change.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoPort.PortObject
member.summary: Gets or sets the that may stand in for this port.
member.value: The initial value is null.
member.remarks: When painting this port, if the is , then the painting is delegated to the value of this property, which should be an object not owned by any layer or group. delegates to the value of this property when the is not and the port object does belong to a layer. The value must not be set to another port. If the value changes, the setter will also call to notify all connected links about the change.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoPort.FromSpot
member.summary: Gets or sets the spot at which to connect links coming out from this port.
member.value: The default value is GoObject.MiddleRight.
member.remarks: This property is used for the common case where we know where and in which direction we expect to attach links to ports. The default assumes a left-to-right flow for the graph. If the value changes, the setter will also call to notify all connected links about the change.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoPort.ToSpot
member.summary: Gets or sets the spot at which to connect links going into this port.
member.value: The default value is GoObject.MiddleLeft.
member.remarks: This property is used for the common case where we know where and in which direction we expect to attach links to ports. The default assumes a left-to-right flow for the graph. If the value changes, the setter will also call to notify all connected links about the change.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoPort.EndSegmentLength
member.summary: Gets or sets the length of the link segment closest to this port.
member.value: This float value is in document coordinates. By default this value is 10.
member.remarks: Basically this tells how long a line segment to draw straight out from the port before turning, assuming a well-defined (non-NoSpot) link spot for this port. If the value changes, the setter will also call to notify all connected links about the change.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoPort.ClearsLinksWhenRemoved
member.summary: Gets or sets whether this port calls when it is removed from a (i.e., from a document, normally).
member.value: This defaults to true.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoPort.PartID
member.summary: Gets or sets the unique ID of this part within its document.
member.value: The value is invalid unless this object is part of a whose property is true. Setting this property is normally done only by when this object is added to the document, or by code deserializing a document, before this object is part of the document. The default value is -1, to indicate to the document that it needs to find and assign a unique PartID for this object when it is added to the document.

member.name: T:Northwoods.Go.IGoActionObject
member.summary: This interface specifies ways for the tool to invoke actions on objects.
member.remarks: Tools () are ways to easily specify behavior in response to mouse events for a whole . To have a specify mouse-event behavior, have your object subclass implement this interface, and make sure the 's list starts with an instance of , as it does by default. The will handle mouse events and set the properties and invoke the methods of the object implementing this interface. Typically this will be some object where a click (and perhaps a drag) should execute some code. One such class is .

member.name: T:Northwoods.Go.GoGeneralNode
member.summary: A more complicated node that has an icon, optional labels at the top and bottom, and variable numbers of labeled ports on either side.

remarks.para: Be sure to call the Initialize method to create all of the standard parts by calling the various Create... methods. You can override those methods to customize the appearance or behavior of those parts.

The positions of the s relative to the icon are determined by the and methods. If you want to customize how the ports are laid out, you can override these methods. For simple customization, you can set the and properties to specify whether the port should go outside, straddle, or go inside of the icon's edge.
The positions of the s relative to the port are determined by the . method. However, you can set the , , , and properties on the node to customize the default layout for all port labels.
If you don't want the ports to have labels at all, override to return null/Nothing.

If you want ports at the top and at the bottom of the icon, with optional labels at either left or right sides, set the to Orientation.Vertical. "Left" ports will go on top; "right" ports will go underneath the icon.
You can add ports at any time by calling and then calling either or or . You can remove ports at any time by calling .
The is normally a , but can be any kind of . Setting the , , and properties actually sets the same properties on the , which is the .

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoGeneralNode.LayoutChildren(Northwoods.Go.GoObject)
member.summary: Position the parts of this node.
member.remarks: The icon is the primary part--the node labels are placed just above and below the icon. The ports go on their respective sides of the icon, positioned contiguously and centered vertically. The ports are always next to the icon, and their respective labels are expected to be outside, as determined by . If there are too many ports to fit alongside the , the is stretched, unless the icon's property is false. Of course when is Orientation.Vertical, all of the left/right and up/down directions are exchanged. When is true, this method does nothing.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoGeneralNode.OnOrientationChanged(System.Windows.Forms.Orientation)
member.summary: Determine how to change the whole node when the changes.
member.param: the former value
member.remarks: By default, changing the property will reposition all of the ports appropriately and change the ports' and properties. When is Orientation.Horizontal, "left" ports are in fact on the left side, "right" ports are on the right side, source links come into the left ports on the left side, and destination links go out of the right ports from the right side. When is Orientation.Vertical, "left" ports are on top of the node, "right" ports are on the bottom, and links come in from the top and go out from the bottom.

member.name: T:Northwoods.Go.GoIconicNode
member.summary: A node with an image for an icon, a label, and a single port centered on the image.

remarks.para: Call the Initialize method to construct the standard parts of this kind of node.

The is normally a , but could be any kind of . When it is a , the property gives you convenient access to the icon's image properties. The image will normally be sized to match the natural size of the Image being drawn. You may want to set the Icon.Size property to make sure the icon isn't too big or too small.
When then first two arguments to are null, the node is initialized to use a instead of a . After initialization you can set the property if you want to display one of the standard s.

You can also set the to be any kind of , including other kinds of s. The property provides convenient access to the icon when it is a , to allow you to initialize its brush and/or pen. If your icon is a , it might be convenient to override and perhaps to refer to the appropriate shape or drawing in the group.
The is normally centered below the . You can set the property to position it elsewhere relative to the . Furthermore, you can set the property to allow the user to move it around.

member.name: T:Northwoods.Go.GoLabeledLink
member.summary: This class provides a standard implementation of as a with several other decoration objects.

remarks.para: The property is the actual that this group uses to implement the link. If you want to specify any arrow or highlighting or stroke point information, you should do so on the rather than on this class. However, for your convenience, many of the properties are available here, delegated to the .

The labels, , , and , are normally either null or instances of . However, they can be other objects, including ports or groups of objects. Nevertheless, GoLabeledLink does not support link labels that are links. Nor may this link's ports be or be part of any of its own labels.

member.name: T:Northwoods.Go.GoLinkAdjustingStyle
member.summary: Specifies how . should determine the points of the link's stroke.

member.name: F:Northwoods.Go.GoLinkAdjustingStyle.Calculate
member.summary: Clear all of the existing points and add points for the standard kinds of strokes.
member.remarks:
has a number of standard appearances:
When both ports have link spots that are GoObject.NoSpot, draw a straight line if the is or draw a Bezier curve if the stroke style is .
When only one port has a link spot, draw a two segment straight line.
When both ports have link spots, draw either a three-segment line or a Bezier curve, depending on the value of .
If is true, draw a five-segment line (either straight segments or with rounded corners) or a Bezier curve.
If is true, draw either a Bezier curve or a five-segment line if is true.

member.name: F:Northwoods.Go.GoLinkAdjustingStyle.Scale
member.summary: When there are more than the standard number of points in the stroke, scale and rotate the intermediate points so that the link's shape stays approximately the same.
member.remarks: This style, implemented by , does not maintain the horizontal and vertical line segments of an orthogonal link. Orthogonal links with this adjusting style will instead recalculate the standard stroke path, as if the adjusting style were .

member.name: F:Northwoods.Go.GoLinkAdjustingStyle.Stretch
member.summary: When there are more than the standard number of points in the stroke, linearly interpolate the intermediate points along the X and Y dimensions between the ports.
member.remarks: This style, implemented by , does not maintain the horizontal and vertical line segments of an orthogonal link. Orthogonal links with this adjusting style will instead only modify the end points of the existing path, as if the adjusting style were .

member.name: F:Northwoods.Go.GoLinkAdjustingStyle.End
member.summary: When there are more than the standard number of points in the stroke, or if the stroke is orthogonal, just modify the end points, while leaving the intermediate points unchanged.
member.remarks: This style maintains orthogonality for orthogonal links.

member.name: T:Northwoods.Go.GoLink
member.summary: This class provides a standard implementation of as a .
member.remarks:
A GoLink is a that connects two s. Make a link by constructing a link, setting both the and the , setting any other properties you want on the link, and adding the link to your . Setting the two port properties will automatically add the link to each port's collection of links. Remove a link by calling . That will automatically disconnect the link from both of its ports.
A link does not own either port to which it is connected -- ports are normally owned by nodes. Ports hold references to the links that are connected to them -- they do not own the links.
The appearance of a link is determined by the stroke , by the , as well as by various link properties. Any filled arrowheads are painted by the . Many examples are presented in the User Guide.
The path of a link is determined by the points in its stroke, as plotted by . For links of , it takes the into account to automatically give the link a curve.
When the link is , it is common to set the style to . Then the property controls the size of the corners in the link.
Whenever either port is moved (normally because the port's parent node moved), is called again. By default this will calculate all of the stroke points again. However, if you set the property, will take the old path into account in calculating the new path.

member.summary: Handle resizing in the same manner as , but when is true, we move both points of the middle segment in order to maintain orthogonality.
member.param: the whose is calling this method

the PointF, in document coordinates, to which the resize handle is being dragged

The . of the handle being dragged. Possible values include:
GoObject.MiddleTop movement of this handle near the FromPort is constrained to be in the vertical direction because this link is
GoObject.MiddleLeft movement of this handle near the FromPort is constrained to be in the horizontal direction because this link is
GoObject.MiddleBottom movement of this handle near the ToPort is constrained to be in the vertical direction because this link is
GoObject.MiddleRight movement of this handle near the ToPort is constrained to be in the horizontal direction because this link is
GoObject.LastHandle + 1000000, or more move both ends of the segment starting with the point whose index is the value minus GoObject.LastHandle minus 1000000, because and are both true
GoObject.LastHandle or more set the point whose index is the value minus GoObject.LastHandle
GoLink.RelinkableFromHandle this case is normally handled by rather than by this method
GoLink.RelinkableToHandle this case is normally handled by rather than by this method
GoObject.NoHandle this case usually means that the should not be dragged

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoLink.AddSelectionHandles(Northwoods.Go.GoSelection,Northwoods.Go.GoObject)
member.summary: Unlike a normal the end handles are in the shape of diamonds if is true.

remarks.para: The first and last resize handles depend on whether this link is . If it is, the handles have a style with a that is either or . If it is not, the handles are hollow and have a handle ID of GoObject.NoHandle, and the user cannot drag them.

The second and next-to-last resize handles, if they exist apart from first and last resize handles and if this link is , will have special s to constrain the movement of those handles in order to maintain orthogonality. These special handles are GoObject.MiddleTop, GoObject.MiddleRight, GoObject.MiddleBottom, and GoObject.MiddleLeft.

The for the rest of the resize handles, if they exist in the middle parts of the link, is just the corresponding point index plus GoObject.LastHandle. These allow for unconstrained movement while resizing, even if the link is .

Furthermore, if and are both true, this adds additional hidden handles ( is ) along the middle segments to allow those segments to be dragged in a direction perpendicular to the segment. These handles have a equal to the index of the point beginning the segment plus GoObject.LastHandle plus 1000000.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoLink.CalculateStroke
member.summary: This method is responsible for determining the points in the stroke, given the positions of the ports.

remarks.para: The standard stroke path is determined by properties of this link and of the two ports it is connected to. If both ports are s, by default this method considers the 's and the 's . If both spots are GoObject.NoSpot, this link's stroke will consist of two points determined by calling and . (There are four points if the is --the points are plotted according to the value of .) If both spots have "spots" (i.e. not GoObject.NoSpot), there will be four points in the stroke, resulting in three straight line segments, unless is true, in which case there are six points (five horizontal or vertical line segments).

However, if there are already more than the standard number of points in this link, the method is called to give the link a chance to decide how it wants to modify its path. The behavior of depends on the value of . If returns false, this method plots the standard stroke as described above.
If either port is not a , this stroke is just a single straight line segment between the centers of the objects. If either port is not a , this method does nothing.

member.summary: Get the object acting as the .
member.value: Initially this value will be this itself. Any new value must not be null.
member.remarks: This property allows a GoLink to be used in the implementation of an IGoLink without being the IGoLink. This is important to avoid confusion in classes such as . When the link is copied or removed, it is actually the abstract link that is copied or removed, not just this GoLink object.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoLink.Orthogonal
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the segments of the link are always horizontal or vertical.
member.remarks: This property primarily controls the behavior of , to position the points of the stroke so that straight line segments will be horizontal or vertical. You can have a link drawn with only horizontal and vertical segments if the link's stroke style is or . If the stroke style is , some of the orthogonally positioned points act as control points to help form the curve. The orthogonal algorithm adds two segments to the normal three segments so that it is possible to connect two ports using only orthogonal lines. Changing this value will call to notify both ports that this property changed. Setting this property to true will clear any existing points and then call , which will eventually call .

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoLink.Relinkable
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the user may reconnect this link to another port.
member.value: This defaults to true.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoLink.DraggableOrthogonalSegments
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the user may drag a resizable segment of an Orthogonal link.
member.value: This defaults to false.
member.remarks: When this is true, a selected link that is will have unseen resize handles in addition to the standard resize handles at the points of this stroke. This will allow the user to drag the segment horizontally for a vertical segment, or vertically for a horizontal segment.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoLink.AvoidsNodes
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the link's path tries to avoid other nodes.
member.value: This defaults to false.
member.remarks: This property is only applicable when the property is true. A Bezier for this link is not recommended. When this property is true you will incur a noticeable overhead in each call to . Changing this value will call to notify both ports that this property changed. Setting this property to true will clear any existing points and then call , which will eventually call .

member.name: T:Northwoods.Go.GoListGroup
member.summary: This group arranges its children vertically or horizontally, aligned within the rectangular bounds, optionally spaced with lines drawn between the objects, bordered, and with a background.
member.remarks: As with any other group, adding a child to this group does not change its selectability. You will need to decide whether the user can select individual items in the list of objects. If an item is selectable, it should have its DragsNode property set to true and it probably should not be resizable.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoListGroup.ComputeBounds
member.summary: The width of this group is just the maximum width of all of the children, and the height is the sum of the heights of the items, incremented by the property between the items.
member.returns: a RectangleF describing the actual size and position of the whole group in document coordinates

remarks.para: Of course, if is Horizontal, the width of this group is the sum of the widths of the items, incremented by the property between the items, and the height is just the maximum height of all of the children. This ignores child objects that are not .

When is non-negative, this group supports "scrolling". The Bounds is not determined by the size of the child objects, but can be set, possibly resulting in some objects at the start and at the end of the list being made not Visible.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoListGroup.LayoutChildren(Northwoods.Go.GoObject)
member.summary: Position each child starting at the top, according to the alignment, leaving space according to the spacing and drawn lines.
member.param: the child object that was moved or resized
member.remarks: The first child is drawn at the top (smallest Y coordinate); the last one is at the bottom (largest Y coordinate). The actual amount of space between items is the larger of the value and the width of the . The actual positioning of each child item is performed by a call to . When is true, this method does nothing. When is Horizontal instead of Vertical, the items are positioned from the left towards the right instead of top-down. This ignores child objects that are not .

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoListGroup.Bounds
member.summary: Whenever the size and/or position is changed, we need to recalculate the corners.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoListGroup.TopIndex
member.summary: The index of the first visible child, or -1 to specify no scrolling.
member.value: The default value is -1. A value greater or equal to the count of items in this list will cause no items to be painted.

remarks.para: This property can be incremented or decremented to cause the list to "scroll". When this value is zero, the first item is positioned and drawn at the top (or at the left, if is Orientation.Horizontal). Following items are positioned after, until either there are no more or until the next item will not fit within the current Bounds.
When the value is greater than zero, the items whose index is less than this value are positioned at the top-left corner of the group and are made not Visible and not Printable.
When the value is -1, all items are assumed to be Visible and Printable, and the result of will be the size of the group including all of its items, laid out in a column or row.

Although this property is very useful in supporting scrolling, this group does not provide any scroll buttons or a scroll bar or any other "controls" to allow the user to "scroll". Such objects (such as GoButtons) can be added to a group or node that includes this GoListGroup.
