member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoListGroup.Brush
member.summary: Gets or sets the brush used to fill this group as a background.
member.value: The Brush value may be null, in which case no background is drawn. This value defaults to null.

remarks.para: LinearGradientBrushes are drawn with their origin at the Position of this group.

You must not modify the brush after you have assigned it. It is common to use the predefined brushes that are members of the Brushes class. For the simple linear gradient and path gradient effects, you can just set the , , , and properties. Finally, for the most sophisticated or complex kinds of gradient brushes, you may need to override this property to return the kind of value you need.

When a linear gradient brush or a path gradient brush is drawn very small, due to a combination of small size and small ., GoDiagram may substitute a solid brush or not draw anything at all, both for efficiency as well as to avoid GDI+ errors. When a path gradient brush is drawn very large, due to a combination of large size and large ., GoDiagram may substitute a solid brush, both for efficiency as well as to avoid GDI+ errors.
Currently serialization is limited to standard solid, hatch, and texture brushes and many kinds of simple linear gradient and path gradient brushes.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoListGroup.BrushColor
member.summary: Gets or sets the main or background color of the brush.
member.value: The Color of the , or Color.Empty if there is no brush. Setting the new value to a non-empty Color when is null will set the to a SolidBrush of that new color. Setting the new value to Color.Empty will set the to null if the old brush was a SolidBrush.
member.remarks: This refers to the color of a SolidBrush, the background color of a HatchBrush, the ending color of a LinearGradientBrush, or the center color of a PathGradientBrush.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoListGroup.BrushForeColor
member.summary: Gets or sets the foreground color of a brush. [Not in GoDiagram Pocket.]
member.value: Setting this value will have no effect for brushes that are not HatchBrush, LinearGradientBrush, or PathGradientBrush.
member.remarks: This refers to the foreground color of a HatchBrush, the starting color of a LinearGradientBrush, or the surrounding color of a PathGradientBrush.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoListGroup.BrushMidColor
member.summary: Gets or sets the middle color of a gradient brush. [Not in GoDiagram Pocket.]
member.value: For a LinearGradientBrush or PathGradientBrush, the value may be Color.Empty if no middle color is needed. This defaults to Color.Empty. Setting this value will have no effect for other kinds of brushes.
member.remarks: Due to a bug in GDI+ in .NET 1.1, this color is ignored. In .NET 2.0, this produces a brush with the correct appearance using all three colors when the is one that uses three colors.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoListGroup.BrushMidFraction
member.summary: Gets or sets the fractional distance between the end colors at which the middle color is drawn. [Not in GoDiagram Pocket]
member.remarks: This property is not meaningful unless the is a linear gradient or a path gradient that supports three colors. Changing the may also change the value of this property.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoListGroup.BrushStartPoint
member.summary: Gets or sets the start point for linear gradients, as normalized fractions of the size of the shape. [Not in GoDiagram Pocket]
member.value: A PointF whose X and Y values are normally between 0 and 1, and should be between -1 and 2. An X value of zero corresponds to the left side of the shape; an X value of 1 corresponds to the right side. A Y value of zero corresponds to the top side of the shape; a Y value of 1 corresponds to the bottom side. Negative values or values greater than 1 denote points that are outside of the shape.
member.remarks: This property is not meaningful unless the is a linear gradient. Changing the may also change the value of this property.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoListGroup.BrushPoint
member.summary: Gets or sets the end point for linear gradients or the focus point for path gradients, as normalized fractions of the size of the shape. [Not in GoDiagram Pocket]
member.value: A PointF whose X and Y values are normally between 0 and 1, and should be between -1 and 2. An X value of zero corresponds to the left side of the shape; an X value of 1 corresponds to the right side. A Y value of zero corresponds to the top side of the shape; a Y value of 1 corresponds to the bottom side. Negative values or values greater than 1 denote points that are outside of the shape.
member.remarks: This property is not meaningful unless the is a linear gradient or a path gradient. Changing the may also change the value of this property.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoListGroup.BrushFocusScales
member.summary: Gets or sets the size of the focus area for path gradients, as normalized fractions of the size of the shape. [Not in GoDiagram Pocket]
member.value: A SizeF whose Width and Height values must be between 0 and 1.
member.remarks: This property is not meaningful unless the is a path gradient. Changing the may also change the value of this property.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoListGroup.BrushStyle
member.summary: Gets or sets the kind of brush used by this shape. [Not in GoDiagram Pocket]
member.value: A . The default value depends on the shape type. However, for most shapes the default is because is null.

remarks.para: Changing this property to a new that is a gradient will also reset some of the brush properties to default values established by the corresponding Fill... methods. In particular, the value of , , , and/or may change. However, setting this property will not change the , or properties, although some or all of those properties might not be used by certain brush styles. You will normally want to set this property first, before setting other Brush... properties.

When a linear gradient brush or a path gradient brush is drawn very small, due to a combination of small size and small ., GoDiagram may substitute a solid brush or not draw anything at all, both for efficiency as well as to avoid GDI+ errors. When a path gradient brush is drawn very large, due to a combination of large size and large ., GoDiagram may substitute a solid brush, both for efficiency as well as to avoid GDI+ errors.
Caution: using gradient brush styles, particularly path gradients, can be computationally expensive to paint. This is especially true for large shapes.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoListGroup.Corner
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum radial width and height of each corner.
member.value: The default value is 0x0. Both the width and the height must be non-negative; only when both are positive will there be arcs at each corner.

member.summary: Gets or sets the space between the top and left sides of the text label with the top and left sides of the border.
member.value: The width and height must not be negative.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoListGroup.BottomRightMargin
member.summary: Gets or sets the space between the bottom and right sides of the text label with the bottom and right sides of the border.
member.value: The width and height must not be negative.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoListGroup.Clipping
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the items should be clipped to paint within the rounded corners of the border. [Not in GoDiagram Pocket]
member.value: The default value is false
member.remarks: Setting this property to true is useful when the and/or are small enough relative to the to cause the rounded corners of the border to be drawn across the top item(s) or bottom item(s).

member.name: T:Northwoods.Go.GoMultiTextNode
member.remarks: Although this group typically displays strings by holding objects, you can actually insert any . This object is not meant to be resizable, so is false. If you want to change the width of all of the items in the , you can set the property. The initial value of , -1, does not cause any of the items' to be set -- they will keep their natural width. If you really want the user to be able to change the width of this node interactively, one way to do so is to override to reset the to an appropriate value, accounting for any and and any ports.

member.name: T:Northwoods.Go.GoNodeLinkEnumerator
member.summary: Iterate over the links (or a subset of the links) connected to this node.
member.remarks:
Although this structure is public, it is rarely used explicitly. Instead you should use the foreach (or For Each) construct to iterate through the links connected to a port of a node. In C#:
foreach (IGoLink link in aNode.DestinationLinks) { . . . }
In VB.NET:
Dim link As IGoLink For Each link in aNode.DestinationLinks . . . Next
Remember that you must not modify the graph structure of ports and links and nodes connected to this node, by adding or removing any ports, links, or nodes, while you are iterating over them. This structure type does not support comparison for equality.

member.summary: Iterate over a subset of the links connected to this port, those either coming into this port or those leaving this port.
member.remarks:
Although this structure is public, it is rarely used explicitly. Instead you should use the foreach (or For Each) construct to iterate through the links of a port. In C#:
foreach (IGoLink link in aPort.DestinationLinks) { . . . }
In VB.NET:
Dim link As IGoLink For Each link in aPort.DestinationLinks . . . Next
Remember that you must not modify the graph structure of links and nodes connected to this port, by adding or removing any links or nodes, while you are iterating over them. This structure type does not support comparison for equality.

member.name: T:Northwoods.Go.GoSheet
member.summary: This class is an object that represents a sheet of paper, normally only used as a background in a .

remarks.para: A sheet also supports a and an optional that you can set. It also can paint the margins to let the user know where the margins are.

For WinForms, you will need to set the margins appropriately, given the current page settings for your application. Given a PageSettings object you can call UpdateBounds to adjust the sizes of the and the margins.

member.name: T:Northwoods.Go.GoSimpleNode
member.summary: A node with a resizable icon, a label, and a port on each side.

remarks.para: Call the Initialize method to construct the standard parts of this kind of node. The ports are normally on the left side and on the right side of the icon, and the is on the bottom. If you set to Orientation.Vertical, the will be on top and the will be on the bottom, and the will be on the right side. In order to remove either port you can set either or to null, or you can call on the port.
The is normally a , but could be any kind of . When it is a , the property gives you convenient access to the icon's image properties. The image will normally be sized at .
When then first two arguments to are null, the node is initialized to use a instead of a . After initialization you can set the property if you want to display one of the standard s.

You can also set the to be any kind of , including other kinds of s. The property provides convenient access to the icon when it is a , to allow you to initialize its brush and/or pen. If your icon is a , it might be convenient to override and perhaps to refer to the appropriate shape or drawing in the group.
Remember that also inherits from , so you can easily set the brush and/or pen, as well as setting the port's .
Setting the , , and properties actually set the same properties on the , which is the .

member.name: T:Northwoods.Go.GoSubGraphBase
member.summary: Node classes that expect to hold nodes and links should inherit from this class.
member.remarks: This base class for does nothing but support graph traversal and the reparenting of links. Unlike , it does not support collapse/expand (), a Label, a Port, or a drawn border with margins. Instead, if you want to implement your own kinds of subgraphs, this may provide a handy base class without the constraints and assumptions that was designed for.

member.summary: Determine the area occupied by the subgraph's child nodes, excluding any margins.
member.param: a child object to ignore, in addition to children skipped because returned true
member.returns: the region that is the inside of the subgraph, excluding the margins and any objects skipped by

remarks.para: If all child objects are skipped, as when there are no nodes in the subgraph, this will try to provide a reasonable value for the area inside the margins, by using the if any. Otherwise the return value may well have a Width and Height of zero.

This is called by with a null argument. calls this method passing the , and calls this method passing the , so that those layout methods can determine the area without the collapsed-object and label, respectively, affecting the calculations.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoSubGraph.ComputeInsideMarginsSkip(Northwoods.Go.GoObject)
member.summary: This method is called by to see if a given child of this group should be ignored.
member.returns: true for special objects whose position depends on the bounds of all the other children or for those objects that should not affect the size of the subgraph.

remarks.para: Child objects such as the , , an invisible or and invisible links or internal links connected to this subgraph's should not be included in the computation of the method, because they may be outside of the inside area where the child nodes are. Any override of this method to return true for additional objects may also override one of the Layout... methods to make sure those objects are positioned in the desired manner.

Originally this method was called from , but we no longer tie the Bounds with the bordered area. The latter is now governed by , which calls , which calls this method to decide which objects are really part of the subgraph and thus should be inside the border.

member.remarks: The resize handles are placed around the rectangle returned by . The predicate is ignored at the present time--it is assumed to be true. If this subgraph is not resizable, a bounding handle will go around the whole subgraph, not just the bordered area.

If there is a the label is positioned relative to that collapsed object; otherwise it is positioned relative to the result of .

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoSubGraph.ComputeCollapsedSize(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Determine the size that this subgraph should be when collapsed, excluding any collapsed margin.
member.param: true when the size of any should be considered
member.returns: the size of , if it is not null/nothing and is true, and the union of the sizes of all the children, including the collapsed sizes of subgraphs

remarks.para: Unlike , this method is used to calculate the expected size of this node when collapsed, so that can call and with the intended collapsed bounds. The size of each child (that is not skipped by ) is given by the ., except for nested subgraphs, where is called recursively. This method does not augment the size to include the or .

Note that the standard behavior of this method makes sure the resulting size is wide enough to hold each child node and tall enough to hold each child node--it is not just the size of any . The reason is that the standard behavior wants to insure that all links connected to child nodes will end at or in the collapsed subgraph, not potentially far away from the subgraph.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoSubGraph.Collapse
member.summary: Reposition all of the children so that this node takes a minimum amount of space.
member.remarks: This method will first set the to . It then calls , which collapses any nested subgraphs. It will call to determine the reference position for the collapsed subgraph. Then it will call to determine the desired size of the collapsed subgraph, will call to remember the expanded size and relative position of each child, will call to actually move and perhaps resize each child, and then will call . It then sets the state to . Afterwards, will be false, and this method calls LayoutChildren(null) to give , , and a chance. This method does nothing if this node is already collapsed or if is false.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoSubGraph.PrepareCollapse
member.summary: Do any work before collapsing this subgraph.
member.remarks: By default this does nothing.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoSubGraph.SaveChildBounds(Northwoods.Go.GoObject,System.Drawing.RectangleF)
member.summary: Save the original size and relative position for all non-links and the paths of all links.
member.param: the expected bounds of the collapsed subgraph, without the collapsed margin
member.remarks: This saves the points of link strokes, relative to the 's position, in the hash table. For other objects, besides the , , , or , this saves the current size and position relative to the in the hash table.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoSubGraph.CollapseChild(Northwoods.Go.GoObject,System.Drawing.RectangleF)
member.summary: Center all the objects that aren't links and make everything invisible (besides Label and Handle and Port and CollapsedObject).
member.param: the expected bounds of the collapsed subgraph, without the collapsed margin

remarks.para: Child subgraphs are collapsed first, of course, and if they had been expanded, their property is set to true. If the child object has a , that is centered; otherwise the whole child is centered.

You may want to override this method in order to customize the sizing of child objects when the subgraph is collapsed. If you do this, you will also want to override to restore the original size, as saved in the hash table.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoSubGraph.FinishCollapse(System.Drawing.RectangleF)
member.summary: This method is called towards the end of the process of a call.
member.param: the expected bounds of the collapsed subgraph, without the collapsed margin
member.remarks: By default this method makes any visible and makes the whole subgraph not resizable.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoSubGraph.Expand
member.summary: Restore the position of all of the children so that this subgraph completely visible again.
member.remarks: The call saved the original bounds of all of the non-link children. These saved relative positions are used to move all of the children back again, and making them all visible too. This method will first set the to , and then call for any preparatory work. It will call to determine the reference position for the expanded subgraph. It calls on each child to move them back to their original positions, and will call for any clean-up work. It then sets the state to . This method does nothing if this node is already expanded or if is false. This method also calls LayoutChildren(null) afterwards, mostly to make sure the and are positioned correctly again, especially if the objects changed while the node was collapsed.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoSubGraph.PrepareExpand
member.summary: Do any work before expanding the children.
member.remarks: By default this does nothing.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoSubGraph.ExpandChild(Northwoods.Go.GoObject,System.Drawing.PointF)
member.summary: Restore a child to its original position.
member.param: the reference point for restoring the new position
member.remarks: This uses for getting the saved relative position of a child, and this uses for getting the relative points of link strokes. Nested subgraphs that are (i.e. were collapsed by ) are expanded. This method also makes sure each child is made again.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoSubGraph.FinishExpand(System.Drawing.PointF)
member.summary: This method is called at the end of the process of an call.
member.param: the reference point for restoring the new position
member.remarks: By default this just clears all saved information in the and hash tables, it makes any not visible, and it restores whether the expanded subgraph is resizable.

member.name: T:Northwoods.Go.GoTextNode
member.summary: A node displaying a string with a background and four ports, one at the middle of each side.

remarks.para: If you don't need all four ports, you can remove ones you don't want by setting the corresponding property to null.

You can change the background from a light-gray rectangle by setting the property to be some other object. In order for the text to fit nicely within the shape, you may need to set the and properties to larger values. This is particularly true if the new shape is a or a polygon that has a small rectangular area in it.
When is false, the is sized to fit inside the bounds of the , minus the margins. The label (a ) is automatically wrapped and clipped.

To make it easier to initialize or modify the shape's brush and/or pen, the property casts the to a . If you make the background a group of various kind of objects, you may want to override the property to return the particular shape inside the group that you consider to be the most prominent.
The text string is normally multiline and not editable, but you can change those and other properties by setting the 's properties.
Setting the property for this node actually sets that property on the object. Although the object is normally a , it could be any kind of .

member.name: T:Northwoods.Go.GoTool
member.summary: This abstract class provides the base for all of the predefined tools.

member.name: T:Northwoods.Go.IGoTool
member.summary: This interface specifies the methods the view uses to control this tool and the methods used to handle the canonicalized input events processed through the view.
member.remarks: All existing tools are actually subclasses of the abstract class .

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.IGoTool.CanStart
member.summary: This predicate is used by the view to decide if this tool can be started.
member.returns: true if the view can make this tool the current one and call the method

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.IGoTool.Start
member.summary: This method is called by the view when this tool becomes the currently active tool.
member.remarks: Tool implementations should perform their per-use initialization here, such as starting a document transaction and setting up internal data structures.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.IGoTool.Stop
member.summary: This method is called by the view when this tool stops being the current tool.
member.remarks: Tool implementations should perform their per-use cleanup here, such as finishing a document transaction.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.IGoTool.DoMouseDown

member.summary: The view will call this method upon a mouse up event.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.IGoTool.DoMouseHover

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoTool.CanStart
member.summary: This predicate should be true if this tool can be activated to be the view's current tool.
member.remarks: By default, this returns true. This is normally only called by the to decide whether this tool should be started as a mode-less mouse tool.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoTool.Start
member.summary: This method is called when this tool becomes the view's current tool.
member.remarks: Typically you will want to put initialization code here for each time the tool is started. By default, this does nothing. You should not normally be calling this method directly--only the view should.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoTool.Stop
member.summary: This method is called when this tool is about to be replaced as the view's current tool.
member.remarks: Typically you will want to put termination code here for each time the tool is stopped. By default, this does nothing. You should not normally be calling this method directly--only the view should. If you want to cause this tool to stop, call instead, which will eventually call this method.

member.remarks: By default, this does nothing.

member.summary: The view calls this method upon a mouse move event; all of the event information is provided by the property.
member.remarks: By default, this does nothing.

member.summary: The view calls this method upon a mouse up event; all of the event information is provided by the property.
member.remarks: By default, this just calls .

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoTool.DoMouseWheel
member.summary: The view calls this method as the mouse wheel rotates; all of the event information is provided by the property.
member.remarks: By default this does nothing.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoTool.DoMouseHover

member.summary: The view calls this method when the user cancels the gesture with the mouse; all of the event information is provided by the property.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoTool.DoKeyDown
member.summary: The view calls this method when the user presses a key on the keyboard; all of the event information is provided by the property.
member.remarks: By default, this just calls if the user pressed the Escape key.

This method also sets the to null, so that a call to will abort the transaction rather than finishing it normally, unless has been set to something. Not all tools involve changes to the view's document, and thus not all tools need to start and stop transactions.

member.name: T:Northwoods.Go.GoToolAction
member.summary: This modeless tool is used to handle objects like buttons or knobs that implement the interface.

remarks.para: An instance of this tool is the first tool in the default 's list.
A mouse down activates the under that mouse point. The object can use the setting of the property to true to render differently. For example, a will appear "pressed".

A mouse move will invoke . The object can use this notificaton to track the user's mouse in adjusting the state of the object. For example, a knob's direction and value can follow the mouse over a range of values.
A mouse up will invoke . The object can use this notification to perform some action. A button can actually do some work; a knob could actually set the new value in the document.

member.summary: The "mode-less" tool used to handle the user's mouse click to invoke a context menu.
member.remarks: An instance of this tool is one of the first tools in the default 's list. By default this will make the object at the mouse point be the only selected object. Set if you want to let users operate a context menu on more than one selected object.

member.summary: The standard tool constructor.

member.returns: true if is true for the

member.summary: When there is a selectable document object under the last input event point, select it if it isn't already in the selection and call .

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoToolContext.DoSelect(Northwoods.Go.GoInputEventArgs)
member.summary: When is false, the user's context-click on a selected object does not modify the selection, thereby allowing the context-click action to apply to a multiple selection.
member.remarks: If the user holds down the Control and/or Shift keys, or when is true, the standard behavior occurs. When the user context-clicks over an object that is not selected, it becomes the single selection. When the user context-clicks over no object, the selection is cleared.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoToolContext.Start
member.summary: If the view has a context menu, remember it and set it to null if there is an object at the last input event point.
member.remarks: This disables the default context menu behavior for Controls when there is a selectable document object under the mouse. The object is free to bring up its own context menu as part of the method. When there is no object under the mouse, the view's context menu pops up normally. We recommend not using the view's Control.ContextMenu property, but bringing up a context menu explicitly when handling the event.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoToolContext.Stop
member.summary: Restore the original context menu for the view, if any.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoToolContext.SingleSelection
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the becomes the one and only selected object even if there are other already-selected objects.
member.value: The default value is true.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoToolContext.BackgroundContextMenu
member.summary: Gets the view's original ContextMenu, before being temporarily reset by this tool.
member.remarks: This is set by and is restored by . The view's ContextMenu property has to be set to null temporarily to avoid being invoked as well as an object specific context menu. We recommend not using the view's Control.ContextMenu property, but bringing up a context menu explicitly when handling the event.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoToolContext.BackgroundContextMenuStrip
member.summary: Gets the view's original ContextMenuStrip, before being temporarily reset by this tool.
member.remarks: This is set by and is restored by . The view's ContextMenuStrip property has to be set to null temporarily to avoid being invoked as well as an object specific context menu. We recommend not using the view's Control.ContextMenuStrip property, but bringing up a context menu explicitly when handling the event.

member.summary: The tool used to implement dragging behavior, for moving and copying objects.
member.remarks: This tool is expected to be invoked upon a mouse move.

member.summary: The standard tool constructor.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoToolDragging.CanStart
member.summary: The dragging tool is applicable when the user can move or copy one or more objects.
member.returns:
This predicate returns true when:
the user has started moving the mouse with a mouse button down
the view allows objects to be moved or copied or dragged out of the window
the mouse button is not the context menu button
there is a selectable object under the mouse
and that object can be moved or copied

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoToolDragging.Start
member.summary: Start a drag-and-drop operation.

remarks.para: This first remembers the between the 's position and the mouse point (the first input event point). It removes any selection handles, so those do not need to be dragged along. It also starts a transaction. If the view's property is true, we call Control.DoDragDrop to start the standard modal drag-and-drop process.
This depends on the cooperation of , , and to call , , and appropriately when the drop target is the same view as the drag source. If the view's property is false, the normal calls to , , and occur.
If is false, this method does not modify the current selection and does not set or .

member.summary: Call Control.DoDragDrop
member.param: a collection of objects being dragged, normally the view's
this is passed as the second argument to Control.DoDragDrop
member.remarks: This is in a separate method for easy overriding, so that you can substitute other serializable objects or IDataObjects to be dragged out to other windows.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoToolDragging.Stop
member.summary: Clean up after any drag.
member.remarks: This restores any hidden selection handles, removes any drag selection objects, and stops the current transaction.

member.summary: Gets or sets whether should include links that have both ports in (or part of) the selection being dragged.
member.value: The default value is true.
member.remarks: When this is true, links that connect dragged nodes will be moved along with the nodes. In such cases links will normally not be rerouted and thus will maintain the shape that they had originally connecting the nodes. When this property is false, will not include such links in the effective selection -- after the nodes are dragged, the links will need to recalculate their strokes, thereby potentially losing any special path that they may have had between the nodes.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoToolDragging.HidesSelectionHandles

member.value: The default value is true.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoToolLinking.IsValidLink(Northwoods.Go.IGoPort,Northwoods.Go.IGoPort)
member.summary: This predicate is called during the process of finding the nearest port that the user can link to.
member.returns: Basically this is implemented as fromPort.IsValidLink(toPort)

remarks.para: If both and are null, this returns false. If only one of the parameters is null, then this returns the value of fromPort.CanLinkFrom() or toPort.CanLinkTo(), on the non-null port parameter. This predicate also disallows interactive linking of a link to a port that is part of the link--e.g. linking to a port that is a label on a . The results of these calls are stored in the hash table. The ports are associated with or values depending on whether this predicate returned true or false. Note that to check for links from a port to itself, this predicate may be called with the same value for both arguments.

has more options for link validity checking; see for more details. If you override this method, you may well need to do so for both and , and then replace both of the standard linking tools in your by calling .

member.summary: Find the valid document port nearest to a given point.
member.param: a PointF in document coordinates
member.remarks: A nearby port (as determined by the distance between and the result of ) must be within the distance for it to qualify, and it must be in a that is visible. This uses the predicate, passing it the along with each port to be considered. The results of are cached in , for the cases where determining valid links is computationally expensive. This cache is valid only for the duration of this linking tool as the current tool; it is cleared each time this tool is stopped.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoToolManager.DoKeyDown
member.summary: Provide default behavior, when not running some other tool.
member.remarks:
By default this handles:
Delete: the Delete key deletes the current selection
Select All: Ctrl-A selects all selectable document objects
Copy, Cut, Paste: The Ctrl-C, Ctrl-Insert, Ctrl-X, Shift-Delete, Ctrl-V, and Shift-Insert keys do the standard clipboard operations
Edit: the F2 key starts in-place editing of the current node's text label
PageDown, PageUp: The PageDown and PageUp keys scroll vertically; Shift-PageDown and Shift-PageUp scroll horizontally
Home, End: the Home and End keys scroll to the left side and right sides of the document; Ctrl-Home and Ctrl-End scroll to the top-left and bottom-right corners of the document, respectively
Undo, Redo: Ctrl-Z and Ctrl-Y (or Ctrl-Shift-Z) perform undo and redo
Arrow keys: moves the selection in the given direction, or else scrolls the view that way; the Ctrl modifier causes the movement or scrolling to just be one pixel at a time. This uses the and properties to control how far the selection is moved.
Escape: the Escape key may clear the selection and then cancels the current input operation
letters and digits: selects the next node whose text starts with that character
However, the value of . can disable each of these behaviors.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoToolManager.Started
member.summary: Gets or sets whether we have performed a mouse down as part of a mouse down-move-up gesture.
member.remarks: This property is initially false. It is set to true after all of the have had return false. This property helps avoid any tool behavior where the mouse down actually occurred in a different window.

member.summary: This tool supports both automatic and manual panning in a view.

member.summary: The standard tool constructor.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoToolPanning.CanStart
member.summary: This tool can start when the middle mouse button is pressed, unless is false (for manual panning), in which case the left mouse button is used.
member.remarks: However, for manual panning on WebForms, the left mouse button is expected only when is true. When used modelessly, the middle button must be used, since the whole operation will consist of a background-mouse-down and a mouse-up, and that gesture will not be confused with a background rubber-band selection.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoToolPanning.Start
member.summary: Initialize this tool.

member.summary: Stop any auto-panning in the view and remove the original panning point marker.

member.summary: When manually panning (i.e. is false), a mouse down causes future mouse moves to change the view's to move along with the mouse.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoToolPanning.DoMouseMove
member.summary: Call to pan the view according to the current mouse point relative to the .
member.remarks: When autopanning, until the panning point is set, this method does nothing. When manually panning, this changes the view's along with changes of the mouse position in the view, thereby panning the view. However, when is false and is true, mouse moves have no effect unless a drag is in progress--i.e. after a mouse down.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoToolPanning.DoMouseUp
member.summary: On the first mouse up, set the point and display the panning origin marker; on the second second mouse up, stop this tool.

remarks.para: For WinForms, when autopanning, if the has already been set, a mouse up just stops this tool. When manually panning, a mouse up just stops this tool, unless is true, in which case this tool waits for a mouse down again to start panning during mouse moves.

For WebForms, the behavior is different. When autopanning, this method always sets the to the FirstInput.ViewPoint, scrolls the view according to , and then stops this tool. When manually panning, this changes the according to the difference between the mouse down and the mouse up points. Again, the value of determines whether this tool then stops, or if it waits for another mouse down/up.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoToolPanning.DoMouseWheel
member.summary: Stop panning whenever the mouse wheel turns.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoToolPanning.DoKeyDown

member.value: This is a point in view coordinates. It is set on the first mouse up. Once this value is set, mouse moves cause
member.remarks: This is only relevant when is true.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoToolPanning.AutoPan
member.summary: Gets or sets whether this tool is used to implement autopanning or manual panning.
member.value: the initial value is true for WinForms, false for WebForms
member.remarks: When this value is true, this tool implements the standard auto-scrolling panning, initiated by a middle-mouse button click and terminated by a second click or a key press. When this value is false, this tool implements the standard manual-scrolling panning, initiated by a left-mouse drag in the background and terminated by a mouse up (when is false).

member.name: T:Northwoods.Go.GoCollectionEnumerator
member.summary: Iterate over all of the GoObjects in this collection, either forwards or backwards.
member.remarks:
Although this structure is public, it is rarely used explicitly. Instead you should use the foreach (or For Each) construct to iterate through the objects that are part of a collection. In C#:
foreach (GoObject obj in aGoCollection) { . . . }
In VB.NET:
Dim obj As GoObject For Each obj in aGoCollection . . . Next
Remember that you must not modify the collection, by adding or removing any child objects, while you are iterating over the children. If you do, you may get an InvalidOperationException. This structure type does not support comparison for equality.

member.summary: This class is used to remember the mapping of original objects to copied objects in .

member.summary: Create an empty mapping of objects to copied objects.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoCopyDictionary.Copy(Northwoods.Go.GoObject)
member.summary: Return a copied object for an object (first pass only).

remarks.para: First this method looks up in its mapping table--if it finds an object, it returns it, because presumably it has already been copied. Otherwise it calls . in order to make a copy of . If is null, this returns null.

The primary use of this method is to be called by 's GoDocument.CopyFromCollection(IGoCollection, bool, bool, SizeF, GoCopyDictionary) method. This is also typically called within a override method to make a copy of a referenced object that is not a child of the copied object.

If you don't call this in the context of a GoDocument.CopyFromCollection(IGoCollection, bool, bool, SizeF, GoCopyDictionary) method, be sure to call afterwards to perform the second copying pass, which resolves references and can do other copying work as implemented by ..

The easiest way to make a full copy of an object in a document is to call ., which calls CopyFromCollection. However, if you want to create a copy of an object without adding it to a document, you can call , which performs both copying passes.

member.name: T:Northwoods.Go.GoDocument
member.summary: This class represents a model for a , holding s to be displayed, organized into s.

remarks.para: Please note that a GoDocument does not require the existence of any s. A document may have zero, one, or many views displaying it simultaneously. A document and all of its s must not have any references to any or to any other Controls.
All documents and all of their objects must be serializable. Please read more about this topic in the User Guide. To help debug serialization issues, call the method.
GoDocument implements , so you can call methods such as , , , , and , use properties such as , and enumerate both forwards and .

A GoDocument organizes all of the s that it contains into s. The layers are held in the collection. Initially a document will only have one layer, the . If you want to keep nodes in one layer and links in a different layer, it is conventional to put the nodes in the and the link in the . You will need to create a new layer and assign it to that property. If you want have all links appear behind all nodes, you can do:
doc.LinksLayer = doc.Layers.CreateNewLayerBefore(doc.Layers.Default)
Since the layers are painted in the order in which they appear in the collection, the above code will ensure that all links are painted before any nodes or other objects that are in the .

The of each object are in document coordinates. This means that the coordinates are single precision floating point values; the position is a PointF, the size is a SizeF, and the bounds is a RectangleF. Each can look at some or all of the s in a rectangular area determined by the view. The size of the view, the view's , and the view's all together form the view's . If a 's is outside of a view's , it won't be seen in that view.

Independent of any view, a GoDocument has a and a position. Together they form the document's . Normally the document's bounds is large enough to include the bounds of all of its objects. As objects are added or moved or resized, extends the position and the if needed. (However, if is true, does nothing.) The document's bounds affect whether or not a particular view's scroll bars are needed and how far a user might be able to scroll. But note that each view has additional properties for governing scrolling extents.

The document's bounds do not automatically shrink as objects are removed or are moved away from the edges of the bounds. To iterate over all of the objects and compute the actual area that they currently occupy, call . You can also call the static method to determine the extent of any collection of objects. That method takes an optional argument to allow consideration of how much area each object actually takes when painted or printed in that view, since for each object the result of may be larger than then the object's .
There are a number of different possibilities for finding an object in a document: by location, by name, or by identifier.

To find the front-most object at a given point, call the method. If you might want to find all of the objects at a particular point, including those hidden behind/underneath, call the method. If you want to find all of the objects that are either completely or partially surrounded by a rectangular area, call .
To find a node by name, call one of the FindNode methods. FindNode actually will find any , not just nodes. is the property that provides the text string.

To find a node or port or link by integer identifier, you'll first need to set to true. Then you'll be able to call to find any within the document, at any level of nesting. is the property that provides the integer identifier.

There are many properties that control whether a user can perform certain operations. These properties (and corresponding predicates) are defined by the interface . Those include: select, move, copy, resize, reshape, delete, insert, link, and edit. Setting one of these Allow... properties will affect all s displaying this document. (Setting the same properties on a view will only affect that view; setting the same properties on a layer will only affect all objects in that layer.) Call the method for a convenient way to set all of the properties that allow modification of the document.
The property indicates whether the document has been modified. Read its documentation to learn more about how the affects its state, for both getting and setting.

Whenever a change to the document occurs, the event is raised. Each time one sets a property or adds or removes an object, is called, which in turn calls to call all registered event handlers. is also responsible for maintaining the state, for calling , and for maintaining s.

If you add a property in a class inheriting from GoDocument, be sure to call if and only if the value has changed. You will also need to override to perform the recorded change for that particular property. Similarly, if you add a property to a class inheriting from , be sure to call if and only if the value has changed. You will also need to override in that class to perform the recorded change for that particular property.

To record undo/redo information, assign the property. This will automatically enable undo/redo functionality in all views displaying this document. If you want to make some transient changes to objects and do not want those changes to be recorded in the , temporarily set to true.

Any code that makes changes to a document or to a document object should be preceded with a call to and followed by a call to or . This groups together all of the changes so that an undo or a redo will perform them all at once. Transactions can be nested.

When you want to (programmatically) make copies of objects and add them to a document, call for a single object or call for multiple objects. Calling the latter method (or its overloaded variant, for more options) is needed if you want to maintain relationships between the objects being copied, for example, the links between nodes.
GoDocument also provides some options for controlling the kinds of links that users may draw: the property.

For document persistence, you will need to implement code to read/write to your desired medium. If you are reading/writing XML, you may find GoXML useful. In particular, GoXmlBindingTransformer may be very convenient to use. We also offer a sample, DataSetDemo, demonstrating persistence to and from a DataSet.
Read the User Guide and FAQ for more details.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoDocument.TestSerialization
member.summary: Test serializing and deserializing this document, to help discover unserializable objects by getting SerializationExceptions when debugging serialization errors such as during a copy-and-paste. [Not in GoDiagram Pocket]
member.returns: a copy of this document, including all of its contents and any referenced objects

remarks.para: Serialization of a and its s is important for copy-and-paste and drag-and-drop (in Windows Forms) and for session state (in ASP.NET Web Forms). Sometimes copy-and-paste will result in missing objects, due to unserializable objects or serialization errors.

You can call this method to help debug serialization problems. This method serializes this document into a MemoryStream and then immediately deserializes it back into a newly copied document. If there is a problem, you are likely to get a SerializationException, which should give you a clue as to which class needs to be attributed Serializable or which fields need to be attributed NonSerialized.
Because this may consume significant time and space without actually changing anything, do not call this method in a production environment except when investigating a serialization problem.

member.summary: Call this method to invoke the method before any change occurs.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoDocument.AddCopy(Northwoods.Go.GoObject,System.Drawing.PointF)
member.summary: Add a copy of an object into this document at the given point.
member.returns: The newly inserted object.

remarks.para:
This creates a singleton collection and calls
with the appropriate offset. This method is different from in that the latter method causes the document to own the object; i.e., the object's property is modified to be this document's default layer. But this method does not modify the and may add the copy to a different layer, if belongs to a layer and CopyFromCollection can find a matching layer in this document.
If you want to make a copy of a but do not want to add it to a document, you can call . or ..

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoDocument.CopyFromCollection(Northwoods.Go.IGoCollection)
member.summary: Make copies of a collection of objects in this document.
member.returns: A describing the results of the copy.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoDocument.CopyFromCollection(Northwoods.Go.IGoCollection,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Drawing.SizeF,Northwoods.Go.GoCopyDictionary)
member.summary: Add a copy of the objects in the given collection into this document, with locations offset from their existing locations.
member.param: the of s
whether to heed the property for each object that might be copied, and whether to heed the predicate for the corresponding destination layer
whether to copy the instead of the object itself
the SizeF offset in document coordinates
the copy dictionary which can control and record the results of the copy; if null it calls to get one
member.returns: the holding the results of the copy
member.remarks: This is a two-pass process. In the first pass, this method copies everything, by calling on each object and then adding the object to the appropriate layer in this document. The layer is chosen to be one that matches the layer of the original object, by calling . If no such layer is found, it adds the new object to the default layer. The second pass checks for any objects that were delayed during the copy. Any such objects have their method called to fix up whatever is needed.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoDocument.MergeLayersFrom(Northwoods.Go.GoDocument)
member.summary: Make sure this document has all of the identified layers of another document.
member.remarks: Only non-null s of the layers of the document are checked for presence in this document. No s are inserted or removed from any layer. No pre-existing layers are removed or reordered. The property is changed to match that of the other document too, if its has an identifier. The is also updated to match that of the other document, if that layer has an identifier. The principal use of this method is to initialize a clipboard document-- .

member.summary: This method is called by in order to perform the Undo or Redo or a particular document change.
member.param: this value's property identifies the kind of document change
true if this method should restore the older/previous state from before the change event; false if this method should restore the newer/next state from after the change event

remarks.para: This handles changes to the document, such as ; to the collection of document layers, such as ; and to any document layer, such as . For a event hint, this just calls on the , to handle all the changes for objects such as . This method will raise an ArgumentException if the argument 's value is not recognized.

If you add a property to a class inheriting from , you may want to override this method in order to handle undo/redo. Be sure to call the base method for all values that your override does not handle.

Although properties should be designed so that setting one property does not modify other properties, this is sometimes not practical. Nevertheless it is important to avoid having side-effects when the value is changing due to an undo or redo. One way of doing this is to copy the needed code, but not the auxiliary side-effecting code, from the property setter to the override. Or similarly, you could define a method called from both the setter and the ChangeValue method, parameterized by whether the caller is the setter or not.

But a more convenient way to achieve this is to check the property that is set to true when the method is being called on this document. You should check this property before making "unrelated" side-effects.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoDocument.MakesDirectedCycleFast(Northwoods.Go.IGoNode,Northwoods.Go.IGoNode)
member.summary: This method returns true if adding a link from to would result in a cycle of directed links going through the node .
member.param: the node to start from
the node that the proposed link would connect to
member.remarks: This method ignores any reflexive links--i.e. links whose ports are both part of the same node. This assumes that there are no directed cycles already present in the graph. If there are any such cycles, this recursive method may cause stack overflows or infinite recursion. However, this method is faster than . Set to when you can be sure there are never any cycles in the graph; otherwise set it to , which is slower but can handle existing cycles in the graph.

member.remarks: This method ignores any reflexive links--i.e. links whose ports are both part of the same node.

the node that the proposed link would connect to

member.summary: Make sure every in this document has a unique .
member.remarks: Although this is called automatically when setting to true, you may need to call this method explicitly after adding some objects to this document while is true. You may also want to call this method explicitly after loading a document from persistent storage if there is a possibility of any inconsistencies. This method will also make sure that the value of is at least as large as any of any in this document. If you set any to a non-negative integer before adding the object to the document, you are responsible for making sure that the value is in fact unique within the document.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoDocument.Layers
member.summary: Gets the collection of layers belonging to this document.
member.remarks: This value is the list of this document's layers. Use methods for creating new document layers, removing them, or operating on particular layers, such as the one.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoDocument.DefaultLayer
member.summary: Gets or sets the layer that is considered the default layer for document operations that do not specify a layer.
member.value: The value must not be null and must already belong to this document.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoDocument.LinksLayer
member.summary: Gets or sets the layer that is normally used for holding links.
member.value: The value must not be null and must already belong to this document. By default the links layer is the same as the default layer, because the document only has a single layer.
member.remarks: It is common to want to display all links behind all nodes, or all links in front of all nodes. Either policy can be implemented easily by creating a new document layer and assigning it to this property.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoDocument.Name
member.summary: Gets or sets a name for this document.
member.value: The name may be any string. The default value is an empty string. A new value must not be null.
member.remarks: Normally this property is used to hold a user-visible name for a document. Additional properties are then used to hold information about how to load and store the information in the document.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoDocument.Size
member.summary: Gets or sets the size of this document.
member.value: The SizeF value is in document coordinates and should have non-negative width and height.
member.remarks: The default behavior is that this property automatically expands to include all of the objects in the document. This policy is implemented in . Set to avoid this default policy, or override to implement your own policy. This property automatically affects what a view can show and where the user can scroll to.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoDocument.TopLeft
member.summary: Gets or sets the top-left corner position of this document.
member.value: The PointF value is in document coordinates. Initially this value is (0, 0).
member.remarks: The default behavior is that this property automatically moves toward negative coordinates to include all of the objects in the document. This policy is implemented in . Set to avoid this default policy, or override to implement your own policy. This property automatically affects what a view can show and where the user can scroll to. Note that the property has no effect on any document. That property constrains what the user can see, even if the document includes objects at negative positions.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoDocument.Bounds
member.summary: This property is just a combination of and as a RectangleF.
member.remarks: To limit the scrolling extent of views where objects in the document have been deleted or gathered together, you may want to do: doc.Bounds = doc.ComputeBounds()

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoDocument.FixedSize
member.summary: Gets or sets whether should update the and properties as objects are added or moved.
member.value: The default value is false.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoDocument.WorldScale
member.summary: Gets or sets a horizontal and vertical scaling factor for converting document coordinates in other units to and from pixel units.
member.value: The default value is 1.0f--document units have the same size as pixels (when the view's is 1.0f).

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoDocument.PaperColor
member.summary: Gets or sets the color for this document's background.
member.value: The default value is Color.Empty.
member.remarks: Documents can have their own background, independent of any background color provided by a view. The normal behavior is that a view will use the document's PaperColor property when that color is not Color.Empty, but will otherwise use the view's BackColor property. However, there may be times when both or neither color is used in a rendering of the document.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoDocument.AllowSelect
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the user can select objects in this document.
member.remarks: A false value prevents the user from selecting objects in this document by the normal mechanisms. Even when this property value is true, some objects might not be selectable by the user because the object or its layer disallows it, or because the view disallows it, or because the object is not visible. Your code can always select objects programmatically by calling aView.Selection.Select(obj) or aView.Selection.Add(obj).

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoDocument.AllowMove
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the user can move selected objects in this document.
member.remarks: A false value prevents the user from moving objects in this document by the normal mechanisms. Even when this property value is true, some objects might not be movable by the user because the object or its layer disallows it, or because the view disallows it. Your code can always move objects programmatically by calling obj.Position = newPos.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoDocument.AllowCopy
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the user can copy selected objects in this document.
member.remarks: A false value prevents the user from copying objects in this document by the normal mechanisms. Even when this property value is true, some objects might not be copyable by the user because the object or its layer disallows it, or because the view disallows it. Your code can always copy objects programmatically by calling .

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoDocument.AllowResize
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the user can resize selected objects in this document.
member.remarks: A false value prevents the user from resizing objects in this document by the normal mechanisms. Even when this property value is true, some objects might not be resizable by the user because the object or its layer disallows it, or because the view disallows it. Your code can always resize objects programmatically by calling obj.Size = newSize or obj.Bounds = newRect.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoDocument.AllowReshape
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the user can reshape resizable objects in this document.
member.remarks: A false value prevents the user from reshaping objects in this document by the normal mechanisms. Even when this property value is true, some objects might not be reshapable by the user because the object or its layer disallows it, or because the view disallows it. Your code can always reshape objects programmatically by calling obj.Size = newSize or obj.Bounds = newRect.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoDocument.AllowDelete
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the user can delete selected objects in this document.
member.remarks: A false value prevents the user from deleting objects in this document by the normal mechanisms. Even when this property value is true, some objects might not be deletable by the user because the object or its layer disallows it, or because the view disallows it. Your code can always delete objects programmatically by calling obj.Remove().

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoDocument.AllowInsert
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the user can insert objects in this document.
member.remarks: A false value prevents the user from inserting objects in this document by the normal mechanisms. Even when this property value is true, some objects might not be insertable by the user because the layer or view disallows it. Your code can always insert objects programmatically by calling Add(obj).

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoDocument.AllowLink
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the user can link objects in this document.
member.remarks: A false value prevents the user from linking objects in this document by the normal mechanisms. Even when this property value is true, some objects might not be linkable by the user because the ports disallow it, or because the view disallows it. Your code can always link objects programmatically by calling LinksLayers.Add(newLink), where newLink is a newly created instance of a class like or whose and properties have been set to ports in the same document.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoDocument.AllowEdit
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the user can edit objects in this document.
member.remarks: A false value prevents the user from editing objects in this document by the normal mechanisms. Even when this property value is true, some objects might not be editable by the user because the object or its layer disallows it, or because the view disallows it. Your code can always edit objects programmatically by calling obj.DoBeginEdit(aView).

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoDocument.IsModified
member.summary: Gets or sets whether this document is considered changed from an earlier state.
member.value: true if this document has been marked as having been modified, if the has recorded any changes, or if an undo has been performed without a corresponding redo.

remarks.para: This property is set to true in . Setting this property to a new value calls , but does not raise a Changed event.

Although you can set this property at any time, the value of GoDocument.IsModified will continue to be true as long as there have been changes made to the document and you are using an . Any modifications to a GoDocument or one of its parts will result in setting GoDocument.IsModified to true and in adding a to the . list, which holds all of the changes for undo/redo.

When using an UndoManager, you should be making all changes within a transaction. After finishing or aborting a transaction, you can set GoDocument.IsModified to false, and then it will remain false until another change is made to the document.
When there is no , this property is implemented as only a simple boolean state variable.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoDocument.SuspendsUpdates
member.summary: Gets or sets whether any Changed event handlers are called upon a document or document object change.
member.value: A value of true means that any Changed event handlers and any UndoManager are not called. A value of false means that the notifications do take place. The default value is false.

remarks.para: Warning! You probably shouldn't be using this property.

When this property is true, no views of this document will be updated as the document is changed, and no undo/redo information is kept. When you set the property to false again, you will need to make sure all the views are correct (you may wish to call ) and that the (if any) is in a satisfactory state (you may wish to call , so that it cannot be confused by the loss of any undo/redo information while this property was true). You may also need to update the document's bounds ( and ) and perhaps call . No Changed event is raised when this property is set.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoDocument.SkipsUndoManager
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the is notified upon a document or document object change.
member.value: A value of true means the 's method is not called. A value of false means that if there is an , it is notified so that it can record changes for undo and redo purposes. The default value is false.
member.remarks: You must be careful that any changes that occur while this property is true will not confuse the user when they perform Undo's and Redo's but the changes are not undone or redone. No Changed event is raised when this property is set.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoDocument.Initializing
member.summary: Gets or sets whether this document is in the process of being initialized.
member.remarks: This property is provided as a standard way to indicate that the document is not yet completely initialized, thereby allowing some methods to optimize their behavior. During an undo or a redo, this property will be set to true. See the documentation for . Setting this property does not call .

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoDocument.SerializesUndoManager
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the is serialized when the document is.
member.value: The default value is false for Windows Forms but is true for Web Forms.
member.remarks: If you set this to true, you will need to make sure that all that are remembered as changes by the undo manager are themselves serializable. This might be a problem if you are tracking a field that has a non-serializable value, since those values are naturally remembered by the . No Changed event is raised when this property is set.

member.name: E:Northwoods.Go.GoDocument.Changed
member.summary: The Changed event is raised whenever a document or a part of a document is modified.
member.remarks: Any Changed event handlers should not modify this document or any part of this document.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoDocument.DataFormat
member.summary: Gets or sets this document's data format name for the clipboard.
member.value: Normally this String will be the fully qualified name of this document Type. This value must not be null.
member.remarks: The default value for this property ensures that the user will not be able to copy the selection from one kind of document and paste it into another kind of document, but that they can do so when the document classes are the same. If you want to be able to copy and paste between views where the documents are of different classes, you will have to assign the same values for this property for both documents.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoDocument.UndoManager
member.summary: Gets or sets the UndoManager for this document.
member.value: This value may be null, when there is no . By default this value is null.
member.remarks: Of course, when there is no UndoManager, the user cannot perform an Undo or a Redo. No Changed event is raised when this property is set.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoDocument.UserFlags
member.summary: Gets or sets an integer value associated with this document.
member.value: The initial value is zero.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoDocument.UserObject
member.summary: Gets or sets an object associated with this document.
member.value: The initial value is null. The value should be serializable.
member.remarks: In some cases you may be able to avoid creating a subclass of by using this property to hold your application specific state. However, in general it would be best to derive a subclass holding your custom fields, because you will be able to control access to your document state more clearly, and because you will be able to override various methods to customize behavior more cleanly.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoDocument.ValidCycle
member.summary: Gets or sets whether a valid link can be made between two ports that may produce a directed or undirected cycle in this document.
member.value: This defaults to , resulting in no checks for a new link possibly producing any kind of cycle or loop.
member.remarks:
uses this property in the following manners:
produces no checking for cycles.
checks for possible cycle consisting of directed links. This check is slower and consumes more memory than the "Fast" version, but will not fail even if there are cycles or loops in the graph.
checks for possible cycle consisting of directed links, without concern for any existing directed cycles elsewhere in the graph. Thus using this mode may result in infinite recursion and stack overflows if there happen to be any directed cycles accessible from either port in a call to .
checks for possible cycle consisting of links in either direction.
checks for possible links that would cause the graph no longer to be a tree, with each node having at most one source link.
checks for possible links that would cause the graph no longer to be a tree, with each node having at most one destination link.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoDocument.SuspendsRouting
member.summary: Gets or sets whether s should have their . method called immediately, or later when this property is set back to false.
member.value: The default value of this property is false. It is temporarily set to true in methods such as , where the moving of multiple objects might cause repeated routing calls for the same objects.
member.remarks: You probably shouldn't be using this property. No Changed event is raised when this property is set. If you set this property to false, you are also responsible for calling in order to properly deal with any objects that have been added to the collection.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoDocument.DelayedRoutings
member.summary: A collection of s that implement the interface and whose needs to be called.
member.remarks: Modifications of this collection do not produce any events, nor are they recorded by the . Normally the only modifications to this collection are implemented by the class; in particular by the and methods.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoDocument.RoutingTime
member.summary: Gets or sets when objects should have their routes recalculated.
member.value: The default value is , so that routable objects have their routes recalculated by , such as at the end of the implementations of , , and (in full Windows Forms) GoView.DoExternalDrop.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoDocument.MaintainsPartID
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the document should make sure each has a unique .

remarks.para: Setting this property to true will call . When this property is false, any 's are invalid. When this property is true, adding any object to this document will cause every whose is -1 to be assigned a unique part ID, a non-negative integer.

If you add any with a non-negative integer to a document, all parts (including parts nested inside groups) must have unique s already. Since PartIDs are integers, the number of unique part IDs for the lifetime of a document is limited to the number of positive integers.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoDocument.LastPartID
member.summary: Gets or sets the last PartID value that this document assigned to an when is true.
member.value: Initially the value is -1.
member.remarks: You should not set this property except when loading/deserializing an existing document. Setting this property at other times may cause inconsistent results, just as setting the . at other times can cause problems.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoLayer.Add(Northwoods.Go.GoObject)
member.summary: Add an object to this layer.
member.remarks: The must not already belong to a different document or view, nor to a group. If the object already belongs to this layer, nothing happens. The object's property will be changed to be this layer. If the object already belonged to a different layer in this same document or view, the Changed hint will be , otherwise it will be .

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoLayer.Remove(Northwoods.Go.GoObject)
member.summary: Make sure this layer no longer holds an object.
member.remarks: It is an error if the object currently belongs to a different layer. If the object already is not in this layer, this method does nothing. Just before changing the object's property to null, the object's document or view will be notified with a Changed hint of . During that notification the object's property will be true. For convenience, if the object belongs to a , this method will remove the object from the group.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoLayer.MoveBefore(Northwoods.Go.GoObject,Northwoods.Go.GoObject)
member.summary: Change the Z-order of an object in this layer by moving it to be before (i.e. behind) another object.
member.param: the object in this layer that will be placed before; if null, will be painted as the first (i.e. rear-most) object in this layer.
the top-level object in this layer whose Z-order will be changed
member.remarks: This method signals an exception if is not a top-level object in this layer, if is not null and is not in this layer, or if you are trying to move an object before (i.e. behind) itself.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoLayer.MoveAfter(Northwoods.Go.GoObject,Northwoods.Go.GoObject)
member.summary: Change the Z-order of an object in this layer by moving it to be after (i.e. in front of) another object.
member.param: the object in this layer that will be placed after; if null, will be painted as the last (i.e. front-most) object in this layer.
the top-level object in this layer whose Z-order will be changed
member.remarks: This method signals an exception if is not a top-level object in this layer, if is not null and is not in this layer, or if you are trying to move an object after (i.e. in front of) itself.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoLayer.NextObject(Northwoods.Go.GoObject,System.Int32)
member.summary: Return the next object in the Z-order, given an object in this layer.
member.param: a that is in this layer
a value of 1 returns the next object (just in front of ); a value of -1 returns the previous object (just behind )
member.returns: null if is null or does not belong to this layer or if there is no object at the Z-order position indicated by .

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoLayer.AddCollection(Northwoods.Go.IGoCollection,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Re-parent some objects to be top-level objects, even if they are part of groups in this same layer.
member.param: whether to make sure all connected links belong to the proper subgraph or layer
member.returns: a collection of the objects that were added to this layer
member.remarks: This method tries to preserve the links connecting any ports of the objects being added to this layer. Just as with the method, you may find that you will want to set the property to true for each of the objects being added to this layer. The need for this depends on the behavior you want in your application.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoLayer.Paint(System.Drawing.Graphics,Northwoods.Go.GoView,System.Drawing.RectangleF)
member.summary: Render all of the visible objects in this layer within a rectangle to a Graphics.
member.remarks: This method calls on each object in this layer whose property is true and whose paint bounds, calculated by calling , intersects with . If is true, it calls on each object instead of calling . If is false, or if is true and is false, this method does nothing.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoLayer.PickObject(System.Drawing.PointF,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Find a visible object in this layer at a given point.
member.param: the point in document coordinates
this is passed on to calls to
member.returns: the result of ; null if no object contains the point
member.remarks: This method calls on each object in this layer until a call returns an object, which is returned by this method. The objects are tested in reverse order in which they are painted, so as to get the "top-most" object at the given point . If is false, this method does nothing. If is true but is false, this method returns null. Please note that if an object is found, it might not be a top-level object. In fact, when is false, it is very likely that if any object is found at the given point, it will be a child of some group.

If true, only consider objects for which is true.
An that is modified by adding results and then returned. If this value is null, a is allocated and returned.
A limit on the number of objects to be found and added to the result collection.
member.returns: The argument, or a newly allocated one if that was null.
member.remarks: See the remarks about .

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoLayer.PickObjectsInRectangle(System.Drawing.RectangleF,Northwoods.Go.GoPickInRectangleStyle,Northwoods.Go.IGoCollection,System.Int32)
member.summary: Return a collection of objects that are surrounded by a given rectangle.
member.param: A RectangleF in document coordinates.
If or , only consider objects for which is true.
An that is modified by adding results and then returned. If this value is null, a is allocated and returned.
A limit on the number of objects to be found and added to the result collection.
member.returns: The argument, or a newly allocated one if that was null.
member.remarks: This heeds this 's and the 's predicates. If is GoPickInRectangleStyle.SelectableOnlyContained, this method also heeds the and predicates. This actually checks to see if the whole is within the bounds. Such a policy allows a to be selected even though only one part of the group is in the rectangle, the object's that appears to the user to be selected. This will consider the children of s. Once it finds a selectable object within the rectangle, it does not recurse further into that object. This method is called by .
