member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoLayer.AllowView
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the user can see objects in this layer.
member.remarks: A false value prevents the user from seeing objects in this layer by the normal mechanisms. Even when this property value is true, some objects might not be seeable by the user because the object is not visible.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoLayer.AllowPrint
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the objects in this layer will be printed.
member.remarks: A false value prevents the view from printing objects in this layer.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoLayer.AllowSelect
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the user can select objects in this layer.
member.remarks: A false value prevents the user from selecting objects in this layer by the normal mechanisms. Even when this property value is true, some objects might not be selectable by the user because the object or its document disallows it, or because the view disallows it, or because the object is not visible. Your code can always select objects programmatically by calling aView.Selection.Select(obj) or aView.Selection.Add(obj).

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoLayer.AllowMove
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the user can move selected objects in this layer.
member.remarks: A false value prevents the user from moving objects in this layer by the normal mechanisms. Even when this property value is true, some objects might not be movable by the user because the object or its document disallows it, or because the view disallows it. Your code can always move objects programmatically by calling obj.Position = newPos.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoLayer.AllowCopy
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the user can copy selected objects in this layer.
member.remarks: A false value prevents the user from copying objects in this layer by the normal mechanisms. Even when this property value is true, some objects might not be copyable by the user because the object or its document disallows it, or because the view disallows it. Your code can always copy objects programmatically by calling .

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoLayer.AllowResize
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the user can resize selected objects in this layer.
member.remarks: A false value prevents the user from resizing objects in this layer by the normal mechanisms. Even when this property value is true, some objects might not be resizable by the user because the object or its document disallows it, or because the view disallows it. Your code can always resize objects programmatically by calling obj.Size = newSize or obj.Bounds = newRect.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoLayer.AllowReshape
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the user can reshape resizable objects in this layer.
member.remarks: A false value prevents the user from reshaping objects in this layer by the normal mechanisms. Even when this property value is true, some objects might not be reshapable by the user because the object or its document disallows it, or because the view disallows it. Your code can always reshape objects programmatically by calling obj.Size = newSize or obj.Bounds = newRect.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoLayer.AllowDelete
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the user can delete selected objects in this layer.
member.remarks: A false value prevents the user from deleting objects in this layer by the normal mechanisms. Even when this property value is true, some objects might not be deletable by the user because the object or its document disallows it, or because the view disallows it. Your code can always delete objects programmatically by calling obj.Remove().

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoLayer.AllowInsert
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the user can insert objects in this layer.
member.remarks: A false value prevents the user from inserting objects in this layer by the normal mechanisms. Even when this property value is true, some objects might not be insertable by the user because the document or view disallows it. Your code can always insert objects programmatically by calling Add(obj).

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoLayer.AllowLink
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the user can link objects in this layer.
member.remarks: A false value prevents the user from linking objects in this layer by the normal mechanisms. Even when this property value is true, some objects might not be linkable by the user because the document or the ports disallow it, or because the view disallows it. Your code can always link objects programmatically by calling Document.LinksLayers.Add(newLink), where newLink is a newly created instance of a class like or whose and properties have been set to ports in the same document.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoLayer.AllowEdit
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the user can edit objects in this layer.
member.remarks: A false value prevents the user from editing objects in this layer by the normal mechanisms. Even when this property value is true, some objects might not be editable by the user because the document or the object disallows it, or because the view disallows it. Your code can always edit objects programmatically by calling obj.DoBeginEdit(aView).

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoLayer.Identifier
member.summary: Gets or sets an identifier for this layer.
member.value: The default value is null. However, the initial, default layer for each has as a default identifier an instance of Integer 0.
member.remarks: Typically identifiers will be Strings, but could be other more complex serializable objects.

member.name: T:Northwoods.Go.GoLayerEnumerator
member.summary: Iterate over the GoObjects that are in this layer.
member.remarks:
Although this structure is public, it is rarely used explicitly. Instead you should use the foreach (or For Each) construct to iterate through the objects that are part of a layer. In C#:
foreach (GoObject obj in aLayer) { . . . }
In VB.NET:
Dim obj As GoObject For Each obj in aLayer . . . Next
Remember that you must not modify the layer collection, by adding, removing, or re-ordering its objects, while you are iterating over them. This structure type does not support comparison for equality.

member.summary: Advance the enumerator to the next GoObject.
member.returns: True if there is a next GoObject; false if it has finished iterating over the collection.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoLayerEnumerator.Reset
member.summary: Reset the enumerator to its original position.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoLayerCollection.InsertDocumentLayerAfter(Northwoods.Go.GoLayer,Northwoods.Go.GoLayer)
member.summary: Add a reference to a document layer into this view's collection of layers.
member.param: A layer already in this view's collection of layers.
A layer owned by this view's document.
member.remarks: By allowing a view's collection of layers to include both view layers owned by the view and document layers owned by the view's document, we permit each view on a document to display a different set of document layers, perhaps in different orders. This functionality is called by . It is an error if this collection does not belong to a , or if does not belong to this view's . The document layer continues to be owned by the document; the view just acquires a shared reference to that layer. The call gets a hint.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoLayerCollection.SortByZOrder(Northwoods.Go.GoObject[])
member.summary: Sort an Array of s by their Z-order position in these layers.
member.param: an array of s in layers of this layer collection; this array is modified

remarks.para: This method does not modify the order of any objects in any layer--it simply modifies the argument array by sorting the objects by their current Z-order in these layers. For example, if you have a few selected objects, you can use this method to find the selected object which is in front of the other selected objects. That would be the last object in the array after calling this method.

If one or more elements of the argument array are not s that belong to one of these layers, the resulting sort order is indeterminate. In many circumstances you can easily create an array of GoObjects by calling ..

member.name: T:Northwoods.Go.GoOverview
member.summary: Provide a reduced-scale view of a document, showing the size and position of another view's viewport onto that same document, and support panning and zooming of that observed view.

remarks.para: The user can drag around the rectangle representing the observed view's viewport in order to scroll it and can resize it to change the scale of the observed view. Clicking will move the observed view's viewport to that location in the view's document. Doing a rubber-band drag will change the observed view's position and scale to match the box that was drawn, because by default it replaces the standard tool with an instance of .
The rectangle displaying the 's is implemented by a , created by the method, and accessible by the property.

Most of the document-modifying-ability properties have been turned off: , , , , , , and AllowDrop. The user cannot pick any document object. The only pickable object is the , which is in this overview's default layer. Grids are also disabled for this view.

member.summary: This method is called when this GoView's Size (or Width or Height) is changed, to allow the view to scroll or rescale itself.

remarks.para: The behavior depends on the value of and perhaps on the size of the . When the is ., the and are set to have all of the be visible in the view. A of causes the scale to be set so that the full width of the is visible. A of causes the scale to be set so that the full height of the is visible. A of does not cause the scale to be changed. Finally, when is , or when there is no , this method does nothing. The 's are needed to decide how to scroll and scale the view, but the need not be .
For all of the values other than , this method calls to try to keep centered the document point that had been in the center of the view.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoView.RescaleToFit
member.summary: Change the and properties so that all document objects are visible.

remarks.para: This calls to determine the size and position of this view's document. If the document is very large, the method might prevent the whole document from fitting. may similarly prevent the whole document from fitting.

Calling this method will not necessarily cause the scroll bars to disappear, because the scroll bars normally show the extent of the document, which is normally greater than the extent of the actual objects in the document. This method does not modify the size and position of the view's document. Depending on your application, you may wish to shrink the size of the document in order to cause the scroll bars to disappear.
goView1.Document.Bounds = goView1.ComputeDocumentBounds(); goView1.RescaleToFit();
The value of the new will not be larger than one. In other words, if the document is small and thus fits easily in the view, it will not be scaled up beyond normal to expand to fit the view.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoView.DoAutoScroll(System.Drawing.Point)
member.summary: Start or continue automatically scrolling the view during a mouse drag.
member.param: the current mouse point, in view coordinates

remarks.para: As soon returns a new value, this method starts a Timer that waits for milliseconds. After waiting, it repeatedly sets to the latest value, until the position does not change (presumably because the 's view point is no longer in the autoscroll margin). Setting this view's occurs each milliseconds.
This method is normally called by those tools that want to support auto-scrolling during a mouse move, such as . or .. The timer is stopped when the mouse leaves this view.

member.summary: This method is called to determine the next position in the document for this view, given a point at which the user is holding the mouse during a pan operation.
member.param: The original panning point, in view coordinates.
The mouse point, in view coordinates.
member.remarks: This uses the property to calculate a new . When the current mouse point is within the width or height distance from the , no scrolling occurs. When the current mouse point is outside of this region, between the distance (width or height) and three times that distance, automatic scrolling proceeds at the smallest scrolling increment, . The farther away the is from the , the larger a multiple of the is used as a scroll step in that direction.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoView.MoveSelection(Northwoods.Go.GoSelection,System.Drawing.SizeF,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Move a collection of objects by a given offset.
member.param: The collection of objects to be moved; if null, this view's is used.
The distance the objects should be moved.
Whether to adjust the computed destination location by calling . This is normally true, to allow any relevant grids to decide how to control movement of objects.

remarks.para: This method heeds the property if is this view's , and the predicate for each that is not an . To accomplish the move, each object's is called, to support object-specific move behavior. All actions take place within a . transaction. This does not raise the SelectionMoved event; that event is raised by the tool's method. If there are any duplicates in the selection, objects may get moved multiple times. Note that an object may be moved twice if both it and one of its parents are in the selection.

When is true, each of the non-link objects in the selection is "snapped" to the proper location, by calling . It is always each object's . that is snapped to some point. However, links that are in the selection are never "snapped"; they are always moved by the distance that the first movable non-link object in the selection is moved, which may have been grid-snapped. This policy supports moving links without recalculating their paths, as long as their connected ports/nodes are all moved together by the same distance, whether those nodes are "snapped" or not.

member.summary: Return a Bitmap displaying all of the visible objects in the given collection.
member.remarks: The intended size of the Bitmap is determined by the result of calling the method on the collection. If the bitmap is too wide or too tall, the objects are drawn at a smaller scale. The bitmap is first filled with the paper color.

whether to call for the background

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoView.GetBitmapFromCollection(Northwoods.Go.IGoCollection,System.Drawing.RectangleF,System.Single,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Return a Bitmap displaying all of the visible objects in the given collection that paint within the given bounds.
member.param: The portion of the rendering, in document coordinates
The scale at which to draw; 1.0 is normal
Whether to call for the background
member.returns: A Bitmap
member.remarks:
This method creates a Bitmap whose size is determined by multiplied by the (minimum 1x1), that displays what is painted starting at the rectangle's top-left position in the document. It calls to fill in the bitmap and then calls for each object in whose property is true.
In GoDiagram Pocket, the argument is assumed to be true, because the .NET Compact Framework does not support alpha-blending.
Unlike the other methods, this method does not automatically limit the size of the Bitmap based on the and values.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoView.DrawXorLine(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Draw a line on the screen in XOR mode. [Not in GoDiagram Pocket]
member.remarks:
This is not supported in GoDiagram Pocket, because the .NET Compact Framework does not support drawing in XOR mode.
The parameters are all in view coordinates. You should call this method twice for each set of argument values-- once to draw the line and once to restore the original screen image.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoView.DrawXorRectangle(System.Drawing.Rectangle)
member.summary: Draw a rectangle on the screen in XOR mode. [Not in GoDiagram Pocket]
member.remarks:
This is not supported in GoDiagram Pocket, because the .NET Compact Framework does not support drawing in XOR mode.
The parameter is in view coordinates. You should call this method twice for each set of rectangular coordinates-- once to draw the rectangle and once to restore the original screen image.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoView.DrawXorBox(System.Drawing.Rectangle,System.Boolean)
member.summary: This convenience method erases any previous XOR-drawn rectangle and then may draw a new one with the given dimensions.
member.param: The size and location of the rectangle to draw, in view coordinates.
Whether to draw the new rectangle.

remarks.para: This always erases any earlier rectangle drawn by this method. It only draws a new rectangle if is true.

If is false, this draws a rectangle using a checkerboard pen, instead of drawing in XOR mode. In GoDiagram Pocket, this draws a gray rectangle, because the .NET Compact Framework does not support drawing in XOR mode.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoView.ReplaceMouseTool(System.Type,Northwoods.Go.IGoTool)
member.summary: Replace one of the "mode-less" tools used by this view.
member.param: the Type of the tool to be replaced; this should not be a base class of the actual tool instance type
member.returns: the tool that was replaced, or null if no such instance was found
member.remarks: When you want to customize an existing "mode-less" tool, and when setting one of its properties is insufficient, you may need to define your own subclass of that tool or define your own tool inheriting from . In order for the view to use your tool, you'll need to create an instance of your tool class for the view, and then you can either set explicitly, or let find your tool in one of the mouse tool lists, such as . For the latter case, you could just add an instance of your tool to one of those lists. But often you will not want to allow the instance of the original tool class to be used. This method makes it easy to replace an existing tool with a different one. This method searches all of the lists of mode-less tools: , , .
member.example: You have defined a new subclass of , called CustomLinkTool. For each view that you want to use of this new tool instead of the standard way for users to draw new links, call aView.ReplaceMouseTool(typeof(GoToolLinkingNew), new CustomLinkTool(aView))

member.remarks: This is most useful when you want to modify one of the standard tools, typically by setting one of its properties. This method searches all of the lists of mode-less tools: , , . Note that the class of the tool that is found must match exactly with the given --it cannot inherit from that type. This is implemented by calling FindMouseTool(tooltype, false).
member.example: (myView.FindMouseTool(typeof(GoToolContext)) as GoToolContext).SingleSelection = false; (myView.FindMouseTool(typeof(GoToolLinkingNew)) as GoToolLinkingNew).ForwardsOnly = true;

member.summary: Perform the behavior that normally occurs upon a single click.

member.remarks:
By default this picks the document object at the event's . If an object is found, it raises the ObjectSingleClicked event and calls on the object and on its s (if any) until it returns true. If no object is found at the event's point, it raises the event. This is normally called from the . method, which is called by those tools that treat clicks in the standard fashion.
In GoDiagram Pocket, this method also calls DoToolTipObject, because there is no mouse-over event.

remarks.para: When the Control key is held down, rotating the mouse wheel changes the to "zoom" the view in or out at the current mouse point. Otherwise rotating the mouse wheel scrolls the view by calling . If the Shift key is held down, the scrolling is horizontal instead of vertical.

member.summary: Perform the behavior that normally occurs when there is a change in the document object that the mouse is over.

remarks.para: By default this raises the event by calling . It calls . for the object (if not null) and the object (if not null) and proceeds up the chain for both objects. This allows groups such as nodes the ability to easily detect when the mouse enters or leaves the node, and to detect when the mouse moves over different child objects of a node. If both and are part of the same group, this method does not call twice on the common parent group. A true value from a call to will stop that chain of calls up the tree.

This is normally called from the . method, and from the . method. Therefore this event is not raised during a resize or a linking or a rubber-band selection operation. However, you may extend existing tools or define new tools to call this method under the circumstances and with the objects that your policy would indicate.

member.summary: Perform the immediate behavior normally associated with the mouse moving without a mouse button being pressed. [Not in GoDiagram Pocket]

member.remarks: This is called to handle mouse moves immediately. If you don't need the immediate response, but would prefer getting an event after the mouse has rested at one spot for a while, use the method, the method on , or the or events. By default this picks the topmost/frontmost view or document object at the event's . It calls on the result, even if it is null. If an object is found, it calls on the object and on its s (if any) until it returns true. If no object is found at the event's point, or if no object's returns true, it calls . The assumption is that any object that changes the Cursor will return true from the method. This is normally called from ., when no other more specific tools are in effect.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoView.StandardizeCursorName(System.String)
member.summary: Convert a cursor name to a standardized name.

remarks.para: Standard cursor names are basically those used by CSS2. This list includes: "default", "pointer", "move", "crosshair", "text", "help", "wait", "not-allowed", and "*-resize" where "*" is one of: "n", "ne", "nw", "s", "se", "sw", "e", "w", "col", or "row". Other names are lowercased and returned, allowing for the user of other cursors supported by Windows Forms (e.g. "pannorth") that are not recognized by CSS2, or those cursors defined by CSS for WebForms or SVG but that are not standard in Windows Forms.

This method will recognize the names of some System.Windows.Forms.Cursors properties and substitute the corresponding standard cursor names. These currently include: "Cross" (becomes "crosshair"), "Hand" (becomes "pointer"), "SizeAll" (becomes "move"), "SizeNESW" (becomes "ne-resize"), "SizeNS" (becomes "s-resize"), "SizeNWSE" (becomes "se-resize"), "SizeWE" (becomes "e-resize"), "VSplit" (becomes "col-resize"), "HSplit" (becomes "row-resize"), "No" (becomes "not-allowed"), "WaitCursor" (becomes "wait"), and "IBeam" (becomes "text").

member.summary: Copy the to the clipboard.

All of the objects in the selection will be copied by serializing them. If any of the objects, or any of the objects that they refer to, are not serializable, there will be a serialization exception, and the clipboard might not a copy of the selection. will log any exceptions to any trace listeners. member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoView.CopyToClipboard(Northwoods.Go.IGoCollection)
member.summary: Put a copy of a collection of objects in the clipboard.

remarks.para: The collection is copied into a new document of the same class as the property value. (That document class must have a public zero-argument constructor.) This method then calls this view's document and then calls to make a copy of all of the objects in in the new document in the appropriate layers. Note that in order to maintain the distinct layers of the objects being copied, each document layer needs to have a unique identifier, . The new document is then inserted into the clipboard using that document's .
To facilitate pasting into regular (not GoDiagram) documents, this method calls to support additional data formats. If the is null or empty, the clipboard is cleared of any previous data values.

All of the objects in the collection will be copied by serializing them. If any of the objects, or any of the objects that they refer to, are not serializable, there will be a serialization exception, and the clipboard might not a copy of the argument collection. Exceptions will be logged to any trace listeners. The User Guide discusses serialization and deserialization in more detail.

In GoDiagram Pocket, there is no Windows system clipboard, so the data is just stored in a static hashtable, indexed by the document's DataFormat. It does not store a bitmap or any text as an alternative format.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoView.CreateDataObject(Northwoods.Go.IGoCollection,Northwoods.Go.GoDocument)
member.summary: This method is called from to produce a DataObject representing the available data formats and their values for the objects in the clipboard.
member.param: the original collection passed to
the holding a copy of that normally should be the primary value in the clipboard, with a DataFormat as specified by .
member.remarks: In addition to using the format to store the , this calls to draw the collection into a bitmap and to insert it into the clipboard as an alternative Bitmap data format. Finally, each object in the clipboard document that implements provides a text value. The text strings are all concatenated together, separated by NewLines, to provide an alternative textual data format value in the clipboard for those applications that cannot handle bitmaps either.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoView.GetExternalDragImage(System.Windows.Forms.DragEventArgs)
member.summary: Return an image to be displayed during a drag coming from another window.
member.returns: a that is added to this view, or null not to have any such image
member.remarks: This is called by when an external drag enters this window, unless is true. The default implementation just looks at the DragEventArgs.Data. If the data is a , it calls , using to determine the size of the bitmap that is returned, and not drawing any paper background color. By default all other data formats are ignored, causing this method to return null. You can return other kinds of s besides . The object (if non-null) gets added to this view to be dragged around by the user to represent whatever might be dropped, and is discarded when the drag is finished whether or not a drop occurs. The relative position of the objects compared to the mouse position is obtained from the selection's . The object returned by this method has defined its so as to return the HotSpot point. The actual side-effects of a drop do not involve the object returned by this method.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.Document
member.summary: Gets or sets the document that this view is displaying.
member.value: The initial value is created by a call to . The value must not be null.

remarks.para: The document serves as the container of graphical objects that you want to display. Normally you should create graphical objects (instances of subclasses of ) and add them to the document, in order to make them visible to the user. Although often there will be one view for each document, there are can be more than one view displaying the same document, or sometimes no views at all for a document. Each view will have its own state, such as scroll position and selection. The document holds all of the state that should be shared by all views.

Setting this property to a different document will stop any ongoing editing in this view, clear out the selection, make this view's OnDocumentChanged method the event handler for the new document, and call to set up the document layers in this view.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.DocumentSize
member.summary: Gets the dimensions of the document.
member.value: The SizeF value measures the document in document coordinates.

remarks.para: This value is normally the same as Document.Size. However, a view may decide to change the extent of the document that the view displays.
For example, the controls whether the effective document size includes not only the whole document but also any part of the at the current given the size of this view control.

As another example, the property, when false, restricts the view to only showing non-negative positions in the document. In addition to restricting the property to non-negative positions, it adjusts this property accordingly. This property also leaves room for any shadows, as specified by .

This property is different from the result of because the latter method only takes into account what objects there actually are in the document, whereas this property will have the same value even if the document is empty.
A different document size is used when printing in WinForms, PrintDocumentSize.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.DocumentTopLeft
member.summary: Gets the top-left position of the document.
member.value: The PointF value specifies the top-left corner of the document in document coordinates.

remarks.para: This value is normally the same as Document.TopLeft. However, a view may decide to change the extent of the document that the view displays.
For example, the controls whether the effective document bounds includes not only the whole document but also any part of the at the current given the size of this view control.

As another example, the property, when false, restricts the view to only showing non-negative positions in the document by always returning the (0, 0) point. This property also leaves room for any shadows, as specified by .
A different document top-left position is used when printing in WinForms, PrintDocumentTopLeft.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.ShowsNegativeCoordinates
member.summary: Controls whether any parts of the document at negative coordinates can be seen or scrolled to by the user, when the is None.
member.value: If this value is true, the user will be able to scroll to negative coordinate positions in the document. If this value is false, the user cannot see objects located at negative coordinates. The default value is true.

remarks.para: When this value is false, it limits the values of the and properties. However, when the is not , and there is a , the view ignores this property.
For the default value is false.

member.summary: Gets the extent of the view in its document, both position and size.
member.value: The RectangleF value is in document coordinates.
member.remarks: This convenience method returns new RectangleF(this.DocPosition, this.DocExtentSize).

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.DocExtentCenter
member.summary: Gets or sets the center point of the view in the document, in document coordinates.
member.value: This returns the center of the rectangle returned by . When set, this modifies so that the center of the view is at the new point.
member.remarks: The view might not be able to be scrolled far enough to be able to actually make the new point be the center of the view, depending on the behavior of , which is normally limited by the values of and .

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.DocScale
member.summary: Gets or sets the scale at which this view displays its document.

value.para: A value of 1.0f specifies that one unit in document coordinates corresponds to one pixel in view coordinates. Values smaller than one make objects appear smaller on the screen. Larger values make it appear that you have zoomed into the diagram.
The float value must be greater than zero. The default value is 1.0f.

member.remarks: When setting this property, it first limits the value by calling . A different value is used when printing, PrintScale.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.ScrollSmallChange
member.summary: Gets or sets the distance to scroll when scrolling a small amount.
member.value: The Size value must have positive Width and Height, indicating the amount in view coordinates to scroll horizontally or vertically in either direction.
member.remarks: Setting this property also modifies the SmallChange properties of the scroll bars, if there are any.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.AutoScrollRegion
member.summary: Gets or sets the margin in the view where a mouse drag will automatically cause the view to scroll.
member.value: The Size value must have non-negative Width and Height, indicating in view coordinates the distance from the edge of the display area. Initially the value is 16x16.
member.remarks: When the mouse drag point is within AutoScrollRegion.Width of the left or right sides, the view will automatically scroll horizontally in that direction. When the point is within AutoScrollRegion.Height of the top or bottom, the view will automatically scroll vertically in that direction. You can specify a distance of zero to disable autoscrolling in a direction; a value of 0x0 turns off autoscrolling altogether.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.AutoScrollTime
member.summary: Gets or sets how quickly to change the when the mouse is in the .
member.value: The time is in milliseconds. The default is 100 (one tenth of a second). The value must not be negative.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.AutoScrollDelay
member.summary: Gets or sets how long to wait before autoscrolling.
member.value: The time is in milliseconds. The default is 1000 (one second). The value must not be negative.
member.remarks: This is helpful in avoiding autoscrolling when the user is dragging something into the view and doesn't yet intend to autoscroll.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.AutoPanRegion
member.summary: Gets or sets the region around the original pan point where automatic panning does not occur.
member.value: The value defaults to 16x16; any new values must not be negative.
member.remarks: This is used by to decide whether the current mouse point is close enough to the original pan point that no scrolling should occur.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.Layers
member.summary: Gets the collection of layers that this view displays.

remarks.para: This value is the list of layers that this view displays. The view will paint the layers in order. Picking objects at a given point searches this same list of layers, but in reverse order.

A view's collection of layers includes both view layers that it owns and document layers that it refers to. It is normal for the view to have references to all of the document's layers, in the same order as the document's layers, with a view layer on top for selection handles and the like. However, each view can have its own set of layers to display. The method is responsible for setting up the s when the view is assigned a document. It can use methods such as to create view layers or to insert references to document layers.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.BackgroundLayer
member.summary: Gets or sets the layer that is normally used for holding view-specific objects that are behind all of the document layers.
member.value: The value must not be null and must already belong to this view.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.AllowSelect
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the user can select objects in this view.
member.remarks: A false value prevents the user from selecting objects in this view by the normal mechanisms. Even when this property value is true, some objects might not be selectable by the user because the document or the object disallows it or because the object is not visible. Your code can always select objects programmatically by calling Selection.Select(obj) or Selection.Add(obj).

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.AllowMove
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the user can move objects in this view.
member.remarks: A false value prevents the user from moving objects in this view by the normal mechanisms. Even when this property value is true, some objects might not be movable by the user because the document or the object disallows it. Your code can always move objects programmatically by calling obj.Position = newPos.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.AllowCopy
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the user can copy objects in this view.
member.remarks: A false value prevents the user from copying objects in this view by the normal mechanisms. Even when this property value is true, some objects might not be copyable by the user because the document or the object disallows it. Your code can always copy objects programmatically by calling .

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.AllowResize
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the user can resize objects in this view.
member.remarks: A false value prevents the user from resizing objects in this view by the normal mechanisms. Even when this property value is true, some objects might not be resizable by the user because the document or the object disallows it. Your code can always resize objects programmatically by calling obj.Size = newSize or obj.Bounds = newRect.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.AllowReshape
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the user can reshape objects in this view.
member.remarks: A false value prevents the user from reshaping objects in this view by the normal mechanisms. Even when this property value is true, some objects might not be reshapable by the user because the document or the object disallows it. Your code can always reshape objects programmatically by calling obj.Size = newSize or obj.Bounds = newRect.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.AllowDelete
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the user can delete objects in this view.
member.remarks: A false value prevents the user from deleting objects in this view by the normal mechanisms. Even when this property value is true, some objects might not be deletable by the user because the document or the object disallows it. Your code can always delete objects programmatically by calling obj.Remove().

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.AllowInsert
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the user can insert objects into this view.
member.remarks: A false value prevents the user from inserting objects in this view by the normal mechanisms. Even when this property value is true, some objects might not be insertable by the user because the document or the object disallows it. Your code can always insert objects programmatically by calling Document.Add(obj).

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.AllowLink
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the user can link objects together in this view.
member.remarks: A false value prevents the user from linking objects in this view by the normal mechanisms. Even when this property value is true, some objects might not be linkable by the user because the document or the object disallows it. Your code can always link objects programmatically by calling Document.LinksLayers.Add(newLink), where newLink is a newly created instance of a class like or whose and properties have been set to ports in this view's document.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.AllowEdit
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the user can edit objects in this view.
member.remarks: A false value prevents the user from editing objects in this view by the normal mechanisms. Even when this property value is true, some objects might not be editable by the user because the document or the object disallows it. Your code can always edit objects programmatically by calling obj.DoBeginEdit(aView).

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.Selection
member.summary: Gets the view's selection object.
member.value: The view's collection is created by a call to during construction.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.MaximumSelectionCount
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum number of objects allowed in the selection.
member.value: The initial value is 999999. The value must be non-negative.

remarks.para: This property is checked by the 's method. If the selection's is greater than or equal to this value, will not add any objects to this collection.
If the new value is larger than the current number of selected objects, objects are removed from the until the count is less than this new value. Such removals are done between and events.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.ContextClickSingleSelection
member.summary: Gets or sets the property of the tool that is in the list.
member.value: The default value is true: a context click changes the selection so that only the object at the click point is selected. Setting this to false permits context menu actions to occur on a multiple selection.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.SelectInRectangleStyle

member.value: This value defaults to . The value must be either or .

member.name: E:Northwoods.Go.GoView.SelectionMoved
member.summary: The event that is raised after the user has finished moving the selection.
member.remarks: The is the collection of objects that were moved, although the effective selection, as determined by . may be a rather larger set of objects.

member.name: E:Northwoods.Go.GoView.SelectionCopied
member.summary: The event that is raised after the user has copied the selection.
member.remarks: The is the collection of objects that were copied, although the effective selection, as determined by . may be a rather larger set of objects if is true.

member.name: E:Northwoods.Go.GoView.SelectionDeleting
member.summary: The cancellable event that is raised just before the user has deleted the selected objects.
member.remarks: You can look at the collection to examine the objects the user is about to remove from the document.

member.name: E:Northwoods.Go.GoView.SelectionDeleted
member.summary: The event that is raised after the user has deleted the selected objects.
member.remarks: The collection has already been cleared at the time of this event. If you need access to the collection of objects to be deleted before the deletion occurs, consider implementing a event handler.

member.name: E:Northwoods.Go.GoView.ObjectGotSelection
member.summary: The event that is raised when an object gets added to this view's selection.

remarks.para: If there is a lot of work to be done in updating various Controls to reflect what is currently selected, you may be able to reduce the frequency of updates for some user actions by implementing and event handlers.
All event handlers for this event should not modify the selection.

member.name: E:Northwoods.Go.GoView.ObjectLostSelection
member.summary: The event that is raised when an object is removed from this view's selection.

remarks.para: If there is a lot of work to be done in updating various Controls to reflect what is currently selected, you may be able to reduce the frequency of updates for some user actions by implementing and event handlers.
All event handlers for this event should not modify the selection.

member.name: E:Northwoods.Go.GoView.SelectionStarting
member.summary: The event that is raised before a number of objects are selected or de-selected.

remarks.para: This is paired with the event in order to permit optimizations to skip updating other controls that depend on what is currently selected. You still need to implement and event handlers in order to detect the selection or de-selection of individual objects. Methods such as , , , , and will raise this event before (and the event after) making changes to the .

These two events are not raised when individual objects are added or removed from the , such as when the user clicks on an object. These two events have been added to allow certain optimizations to be implemented when many and events might occur "at once".
All event handlers for this event should not modify the selection.

member.name: E:Northwoods.Go.GoView.SelectionFinished
member.summary: The event that is raised after a number of objects are selected or de-selected.

remarks.para: This is paired with the event in order to permit optimizations to skip updating other controls that depend on what is currently selected. You still need to implement and event handlers in order to detect the selection or de-selection of individual objects. Methods such as , , , , and will raise this event after (and the event before) making changes to the .
These two events are not raised when individual objects are added or removed from the , such as when the user clicks on an object.
All event handlers for this event should not modify the selection.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.HidesSelection

member.value: If this value is true, all selection handles are removed from this view when it loses focus. If this value is false, all selection handles are changed to use the when this view loses focus.

members.member:
Gets or sets which key commands are disabled in the 's method.
This property is initially GoViewDisableKeys.ArrowMove: all standard keystroke commands are enabled except for moving selected movable objects using the arrow keys. See the list of flags, which can be bit-wise combined, in the description for . >

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.ArrowMoveSmall

member.summary: This property is true when this GoView is producing a Bitmap.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.DrawsXorMode
member.summary: Gets or sets whether a rubber-band box should be drawn in XOR mode. [Not in GoDiagram Pocket]
member.value: The default value is false.
member.remarks: When this value is false, will draw a rectangle using the normal drawing mechanisms. For GoDiagram Pocket, since .NET Compact Framework does not support drawing in XOR mode, this property does not exist since it is assumed to be false.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.ImageList
member.summary: Gets or sets the ImageList that GoImage objects can draw from.

member.summary: Gets or sets the border style for this view.
member.value: The default value is BorderStyle.Fixed3D.
member.remarks: The border surrounds the view's display area and its scrollbars, if any.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.Border3DStyle
member.summary: Gets or sets the 3D border style for this view. [Not in GoDiagram Pocket]
member.value: The default value is Border3DStyle.Etched.
member.remarks:
This is not supported in GoDiagram Pocket, because the .NET Compact Framework does not support customized 3D borders.
When the value is BorderStyle.Fixed3D, this property specifies what kind of 3D border is displayed.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.DisplayRectangle
member.summary: Gets the area where the view displays its document.
member.value: The Rectangle value specifies an area in control coordinates relative to the top left corner of this control.
member.remarks: The display rectangle is normally smaller than the Control.Size, because of the scroll bars and the border along the edges. Note the difference with , which gets an area in a document in document coordinates depending on the and .

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.SmoothingMode
member.summary: Gets or sets how nicely lines are drawn. [Not in GoDiagram Pocket]

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.TextRenderingHint
member.summary: Gets or sets how nicely text is rendered. [Not in GoDiagram Pocket]

member.name: E:Northwoods.Go.GoView.PropertyChanged
member.summary: Rather than having separate events whenever any view property changed, all such notifications occur through this single event.

member.name: E:Northwoods.Go.GoView.DocumentChanged
member.summary: All . events get re-raised through this event, for the convenience of writing event handlers on the document's view.
member.remarks: Because the that are passed on through this event are actually raised by and distributed by , there is no GoView.RaiseDocumentChanged method as would be conventional. As with all events, it is more efficient to override on or on than it is to register delegates as event handlers on this event.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.AllowKey
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the user can type keystroke commands in this view.
member.remarks: A false value prevents the user from entering key commands in this view by the normal mechanisms. Your code can always handle keystrokes programmatically by adding a KeyDown event handler to this control or by overriding .

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.AllowMouse
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the user can use the mouse in this view.
member.remarks: A false value prevents the user from using the mouse in this view by the normal mechanisms. Your code can always handle mouse events programmatically by adding mouse event handlers to this control or by overriding , , , or .

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.ContextClickTime
member.summary: Gets or sets how long the pointer must be held down without moving to simulate a context click. [Only in GoDiagram Pocket]
member.value: The value is measured in milliseconds. The default value is 800 milliseconds, 0.8 seconds. The value must not be negative.
member.remarks: This is only supported in GoDiagram Pocket, where most PocketPC applications do not have a mouse button for context click.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.FirstInput
member.summary: Gets the canonical event args information for the last mouse down.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.LastInput
member.summary: Gets the canonical event args information for the last mouse or keyboard input.
member.remarks: The last input event args information is used by the tools, the view, and objects to decide how to behave. Typically you will use to see where an event occurred, or to see if the Ctrl key was held down at the time of the event.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.DefaultTool
member.summary: Gets or sets the default tool.
member.value: The value must not be null. Initially this is assigned the value of .
member.remarks: When the property is set to null, we actually reset to be the value of this property. By default this value is an instance of , which handles standard keyboard commands and invokes the appropriate tool upon mouse down/move/up events.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.Tool
member.summary: Gets or sets the current tool being used by this view.

remarks.para: As standard input events occur, the event args information is canonicalized into an instance of and then the current Tool's appropriate method is called.
Setting this property to null results in setting it to the value of . A tool that has finished will probably need to reset this property to the , typically by calling the . method.
If the tool is explicitly set as a result of some user-interface command, the tool is being used in a "modal" fashion.

If the tool is set as a result of the searching through the lists of tools to be started as a result of a mouse down, a mouse move, or a mouse up, then the tool is being used in a "mode-less" fashion.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.MouseDownTools
member.summary: Gets a list of "mode-less" tools to be considered for becoming the current Tool upon a mouse down event.
member.value: The IList may be modified.

remarks.para: , an instance of which is normally the , iterates through this list when a mouse down event occurs. The first tool that it finds whose method returns true becomes this view's current . If no such tool is found, the continues its normal behavior.

By default this returns a list containing instances of the , , , , and tools, in that order. The order of the tools matters, because even if several tools can start, only the first one actually is started.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.MouseMoveTools
member.summary: Gets a list of "mode-less" tools to be considered for becoming the current Tool upon a mouse move event.
member.value: The IList may be modified.

remarks.para: , an instance of which is normally the , iterates through this list when a mouse move event occurs. The first tool that it finds whose method returns true becomes this view's current . If no such tool is found, the continues its normal behavior.

By default this returns a list containing instances of the , , and tools, in that order. The order of the tools matters, because even if several tools can start, only the first one actually is started.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.MouseUpTools
member.summary: Gets a list of "mode-less" tools to be considered for becoming the current Tool upon a mouse up event.
member.value: The IList may be modified.

remarks.para: , an instance of which is normally the , iterates through this list when a mouse up event occurs. The first tool that it finds whose method returns true becomes this view's current . If no such tool is found, the continues its normal behavior.
By default this returns a list containing only an instance of the tool.

member.summary: Gets or sets a that is copied when a new link is created.

remarks.para: The method uses this property to determine what kind of link to create. It is also used by the tool's method.

With this property, you can more easily initialize the properties of each new link to be created, by setting the properties once on this prototype object, rather than each time in a event handler. For coding purposes, it may be more convenient to refer to either the property to set properties if this object is a , or to the property to set properties, if this object is a .

member.name: E:Northwoods.Go.GoView.ObjectEnterLeave
member.summary: The mouse entered and/or left a document object, when no particular tool is running (a mouse-over) or when dragging.

remarks.para: This event is raised when the or the tool notices that a mouse move causes a change in the current document object that the mouse is over. The indicates the object that the mouse had been over, and the object that it is now over. Either object may be null, indicating that it had been or now is over the background of this view.

Because drag-and-drop is a modal operation, an external drag-and-drop from a different Control will not normally raise any ObjectEnterLeave events. However, you may be able to get such events if you set to true and to true, since then a drag enter may cause some s to be added to the document by and and then to be dragged around by the tool.

member.name: E:Northwoods.Go.GoView.ObjectSelectionDropReject
member.summary: The event that is raised during a drag's mouse over a document object; setting the property to . will reject a drop of the selection at this input event point.
member.remarks: This event is raised for the first document object found at the , excluding objects that are part of the . Unlike the . method, which proceeds up the chain until a call returns true, this event occurs only once per mouse move. Thus you will often need to look at the or in order to find the most meaningful object to really handle the event.

member.name: E:Northwoods.Go.GoView.BackgroundSelectionDropReject

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.DefaultCursor
member.summary: Gets or sets the default Cursor for this view. [Not in GoDiagram Pocket]
member.value: Setting this property to null will reset this value to the current Cursor property for this control.
member.remarks: The normal behavior for a view is that when the mouse is not over any object, or if it is over no object for which returns true, then the view's Cursor property is set to the value of its property.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.Cursor
member.summary: We override this property in order to remember the if it had not been set explicitly. [Not in GoDiagram Pocket]

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.CursorName
member.summary: Gets or sets the view's Cursor given a standard cursor name, rather than a Windows.Forms.Cursor object.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.ToolTip
member.summary: Gets or sets the ToolTip component for this view.
member.value: By default each view has a ToolTip component allocated. If the value is null, all tooltips are disabled for this view.
member.remarks: Setting this property to null to turn off all tooltip related activity will reduce the overhead involved when moving the mouse over the view.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.ToolTipText
member.summary: Gets or sets a string to be displayed in a tooltip when no tooltip text is shown for a particular .
member.value: The initial value is the empty string, which means don't display a tooltip.
member.remarks: Note that this is different from the same property that you may find on some classes such as (), since here an empty string is the same as a value of null/Nothing, meaning not to display a tooltip. For s a value from of an empty string will display an empty tooltip, and only a value of null/Nothing will indicate no tooltip for that particular .

member.name: E:Northwoods.Go.GoView.ClipboardCopied
member.summary: The event that is raised after the user has copied something into the clipboard from this document.
member.remarks: The has been copied (serialized) into the clipboard.

member.name: E:Northwoods.Go.GoView.ClipboardPasted
member.summary: The event that is raised after the user has pasted a copy of the clipboard into this document.
member.remarks: The newly copied objects that have been added by deserializing from the clipboard to this document are held in the .

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.DragsRealtime
member.summary: Gets or sets whether a user's drag of the selection occurs continuously. [In Web Forms there is no continuous visual feedback of a drag.]
member.value: If this value is true, the objects in the selection are actually moved continuously, following the mouse. If this value is false, the user actually drags around an image of the selection, and the move only happens on mouse up. The default value is false.
member.remarks: One advantage of a false value for this property is that only one undo record per moved object is generated for a user's moving operation--namely the final one on mouse up. Another advantage, when this property is false, is that a user's drag of some objects to another window will not actually modify the source document due to objects moved before the pointer leaves the view. However, many applications will need this property to be true so as to provide accurate continuous feedback to the user regarding where a move or copy will occur, particularly when grids or other snapping behaviors are involved. If you have many links that are expensive to route, but have to have this property set to true, you might want to consider setting to false, to delay routing until the end of a drag. This property is used by . This property should be set to true when ExternalDragDropsOnEnter is set to true.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.DragRoutesRealtime
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the routing of links happens continuously when is true. [In Web Forms there is no continuous visual feedback of the rerouting of links.]
member.value: The default value is true.
member.remarks: Setting this to false will improve dragging performance, particularly when there are links that , at the expense of not maintaining apparent link connections during the drag.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.AllowDrop
member.summary: Gets and sets whether this view accepts drop events of drag-and-drop operations.
member.value: The default value is true
member.remarks: If there is a SecurityException when setting this property, the property is set to false.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.AllowDragOut
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the user can drag the selection out of this view to another window.
member.value: If this value is true, the user can drag selected objects out of this view to another window. If this value is false, the user cannot do so, although drags within this view may still be allowed.

remarks.para: This property is used by the tool.
You can make a view so that the user cannot drag within it, but the user can copy out from it to another window, by setting AllowDrop to false and and to true. does this.

You can make a view so that the user can drag-and-drop around within it, but the user cannot drag anything out from it, by setting AllowDrop to true and to false. The behaviors that are allowed within the view are additionally governed by and .
This property is not supported in GoDiagram Pocket -- the value is always false.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.ExternalDragDropsOnEnter
member.summary: Gets or sets whether should call immediately, to actually create the dropped objects and add them to the document, and so that the user's drag-and-drop from another window will use an instance of a as the current for dragging around those newly dropped objects.
member.value: By default this is false. If you set this to true, you will also need to set to true.
member.remarks: The current is deleted in or when the drag-and-drop is cancelled. When this value is true, no external drag image is used (i.e., is not called). This property only makes sense when is true.

member.name: E:Northwoods.Go.GoView.ExternalObjectsDropped
member.summary: The event that is raised after the user has dropped a copy of some objects into this document.
member.remarks: The newly copied objects that have been added to this document are held in the .

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.IsPrinting
member.summary: Gets whether any painting that is ongoing is part of a printing operation.
member.value: This value is true when indirectly invoked by the method.
member.remarks: This is not supported in GoDiagram Pocket -- the value is always false, because printing is not supported by the .NET Compact Framework.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.PrintDocumentSize
member.summary: Gets the size of the document to be printed. [Not in GoDiagram Pocket]
member.value: This SizeF value represents the size of the portion of the document to be printed, in document coordinates.

remarks.para: This is normally just the size needed to include all of the objects in the document, by calling ComputeDocumentBounds(). This avoids printing a lot of empty pages if the document size is much larger than needed, perhaps because some objects have been deleted, but the document size has not been shrunk accordingly.
When the is not , only one page is printed, corresponding to where the sheet is. In these cases, this property has the value of the sheet's size.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.PrintDocumentTopLeft
member.summary: Gets the top-left position of the document to be printed. [Not in GoDiagram Pocket]
member.value: This PointF value represents the top-left document coordinate of the portion of the document to be printed.

remarks.para: This is normally the top-left point of the bounds returned by , but may be overridden for custom behaviors. When is false, this just returns the origin.
When the is not , only one page is printed, corresponding to where the sheet is. In these cases, this property has the value of the sheet's location.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.PrintScale
member.summary: Gets or sets the scale at which we should print. [Not in GoDiagram Pocket]
member.value: The value must be positive. The default value is less than 1.0f.
member.remarks: This serves a purpose very much like that of , but for printing rather than normal painting. If there is a , its , , and are rescaled accordingly. No grid properties of the sheet are modified.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoView.PrintsViewObjects
member.summary: Gets or sets whether should print objects that belong to view layers as well as all document objects.
member.value: By default this is false.
member.remarks: You can disable printing layers of objects and individual objects by setting . or . to false.

member.value: The initial value is provided by .

Setting the property to a , either explicitly, or implicitly by setting to true, will cause this property's value to refer to the 's . member.summary: Gets or sets the view that this overview is watching.
member.value: This property should not be set to itself or another GoOverview.
member.remarks: This overview is useless until it has a to observe. When this property is set, this overview becomes a document Changed event handler for the observed view's document so that it can display that document. It also becomes a PropertyChanged event handler and a Resize event handler for the observed view so that it can track the observed view's extent (position and size) in its document, as well as any replacement of the observed view's document.

member.name: T:Northwoods.Go.GoPalette
member.summary: A palette is a view holding a number of objects in a grid that the user can drag into another document.

remarks.para:
The spacing and positioning of the items is controlled by the . and
control the spacing between items--smaller values will allow the objects to be placed closer together without overlapping, but will increase the likelihood of unaligned columns (or rows) if the objects have different sizes. and control the amount of "margin" space at the top and left of the view. However, if is true and the selection objects tend to be smaller than the items, this margin should be larger to accomodate those wider item parts (unless you want to allow them to be clipped).

You can control whether the objects are sorted, and in what order they are sorted, by setting the property. You can control the way the objects are laid out in a grid, with the scrollbar (if needed) either vertical or horizontal, by setting the property. Because is designed to take this view's scale and size into accout, this class is not designed to share its document with other views.
Palettes do not support sheets or . Since users are not expected to move or resize any of the objects, the grid and behavior is ignored.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoPalette.#ctor
member.summary: Create a window that can show a collection of items arranged in a grid that the user can drag from.
member.remarks: This kind of view allows no modifications by users, but does allow copying objects by dragging objects out of the view or through clipboard copy. The grid cell size defaults to 60 by 60, with an initial origin of 20,5.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoPalette.CreateSheet
member.summary: Palettes do not support ..
member.returns: null

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoPalette.LayoutItems
member.summary: Position all of this document's objects in a grid, according to the orientation and sort order.
member.remarks: If the is Orientation.Vertical, for example, this method will position all of the objects in the document in the grid, specified by , , , and , starting at the top left corner, and proceeding to fill each row before adding rows. The order in which document objects are taken as palette items is determined by the and the comparison method.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoPalette.Orientation
member.summary: Gets or sets how to fill the palette by positioning its items.
member.value: The default value is Orientation.Vertical.
member.remarks: This property determines whether the automatic layout of the items in the palette fills and adds rows (Orientation.Vertical) or fills and adds columns (Orientation.Horizontal). A vertical orientation means that there is no horizontal scroll bar, and that the vertical scroll bar shows itself when it is needed because the rows do not all fit in the display area.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoPalette.AlignsSelectionObject
member.summary: Gets or sets whether to align each item's instead of the whole item.
member.value: The default value is true.
member.remarks: A true value causes node icons to be aligned instead of the top-left corners of the objects. The node labels, then, are unlikely to be aligned. To reduce overlap may skip cells in order to place an item.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoPalette.Sorting
member.summary: Gets or sets whether and how LayoutItems sorts before it positions all of the items.
member.value: If the value is not SortOrder.None, is used to determine the sort order. Otherwise, places the palette items in a grid in an order of its own choosing.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoPalette.Comparer
member.summary: Gets or sets the way the palette items are compared during sorting.
member.value: This defaults to a comparer that compares the strings. If the object is not a , the default comparer compares as if it were null. Attempting to set this property to null will restore the default comparer.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoPalette.AutomaticLayout
member.summary: Gets or sets whether actually positions all the items.
member.value: This defaults to true.

member.summary: The selection is a collection of s that the user can manipulate in a .
member.remarks: You should use the . to display and manipulate the selection of objects that the user sees. Occasionally you may need to have a separate collection of objects that is a , in which case you may want to call the constructor with a null/Nothing argument.

member.summary: Create an empty collection of objects representing the user's selection for a view.
member.param: if the view is not null/Nothing, this will automatically create selection handles for document objects as they are 'ed to this collection
member.remarks: The only normal use of this constructor with a non-null argument should be by .. If you do create a with a non-null that is not the value of that view's ., you need to be responsible for maintaining the selection handles in the view. member.name: T:Northwoods.Go.GoSelectionEventArgs
member.summary: Holds information for the events that involve a but are not associated with any input event.

remarks.para: Although both this kind of event and are associated with a particular , this class is used when no particular mouse input event information is relevant. Such events include: , , , , , GoView.ObjectEdited (in WinForms). With these events there is only a single object involved. The name of this class, GoSelectionEventArgs may be somewhat misleading, since not all events involve the view's . In the list above, most do, but LinkCreated and ObjectEdited might not involve selection.

Additional events are not even associated with one particular object--they use the class instead of this class. Such events include: , , , , , and . These events implicitly use the to identify the set of affected objects.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoUndoManager.StartTransaction
member.summary: Begin a transaction, where the changes are held by a .
member.returns: true if starting a top-level transaction
member.remarks:
Transactions can be nested:
StartTransaction returns true
StartTransaction returns false
FinishTransaction returns false
FinishTransaction returns true
Nested transactions will share the same compound edit as the top-level one. This will raise a event for each of the , with a hint of .

member.summary: Just call , aborting the current transaction.

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoUndoManager.FinishTransaction(System.String)
member.summary: Just call , committing the current transaction, with the presentation name for the given transaction name.
member.param: the transaction name; this value is passed to before being passed to
member.returns: the value of the call to

member.name: M:Northwoods.Go.GoUndoManager.EndTransaction(System.Boolean,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Stop the current transaction, either aborting it or committing it.
member.param: true to terminate the transaction normally; false to abort it
the internal locale-neutral name for the transaction
a string describing the transaction, used for the
member.returns: true for a committed top-level transaction

remarks.para: If this call stops a top-level transaction, a value of false for just clears the information in the . If is true for a top-level transaction, we mark the complete, call , and add the resulting to the list of compound edits that this undo manager is recording.

Committing a transaction when there have been some undos without corresponding redos will throw away the compound edits holding changes that happened after the current state, before adding this new compound edit to the undo manager's list of edits.

This method raises a event for each of this undo manager's , with a hint of , and with a . that is the that has been added to the list of . Furthermore the . will be the , and the will be the . Similarly, if the transaction is aborted, either because is false or because there is no to commit, all of the get a Changed event. The values passed in the may all be null, however.

member.name: P:Northwoods.Go.GoUndoManager.MaximumEditCount
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum number of compound edits that this undo manager will remember.
member.value: If the value is negative, no limit is assumed. A new value of zero is treated as if the new value were one. The initial value is -1.

remarks.para: This property is useful in helping limit the memory consumption of typical application usage. But note that this only limits the number of compound edits, not the size of any individual , which may still have an unlimited number of s.
Decreasing this value will not necessarily remove any existing edits if there currently exist more edits in than the new value would allow.
